title: Toy story
review: So ingenious in concept, design and execution that you could watch it on a postage stamp-sized screen and still be engulfed by its charm.

title: Toy story
review: The year's most inventive comedy.

title: Toy story
review: A winning animated feature that has something for everyone on the age spectrum.

title: Toy story
review: The film sports a provocative and appealing story that's every bit the equal of this technical achievement.

title: Toy story
review: An entertaining computer-generated, hyperrealist animation feature (1995) that's also in effect a toy catalog.

title: Toy story
review: As Lion King did before it, Toy Story revived the art of American children's animation, and ushered in a set of smart movies that entertained children and their parents. It's a landmark movie, and doesn't get old with frequent repetition.

title: Toy story
review: The film will probably be more fully appreciated by adults, who'll love the snappy, knowing verbal gags, the vivid, deftly defined characters, and the overall conceptual sophistication.

title: Toy story
review: Children will enjoy a new take on the irresistible idea of toys coming to life. Adults will marvel at a witty script and utterly brilliant anthropomorphism.

title: Toy story
review: Although its computer-generated imagery is impressive, the major surprise of this bright foray into a new kind of animation is how much cleverness has been invested in story and dialogue.

title: Toy story
review: How perfect that two of the most popular funny guys around, Tom Hanks and Tim Allen, speak for the lead boy-toys.

title: Toy story
review: The result is a visionary roller-coaster ride of a movie.

title: Toy story
review: Disney's witty, wondrously imaginative, all-computer-generated cartoon is far and away the best of the new holiday movies in town.

title: Toy story
review: Disney's first computer-made animated feature is a 3-D eye popper.

title: Toy story
review: The script, by Lasseter, Pete Docter, Andrew Stanton and Joe Ranft, is filled with clever gags that keep the two heroes at each other's throats and the plot on fast- forward.

title: Toy story
review: The one big negative about Toy Story involves Disney's overcommercialization.

title: Toy story
review: Technically, Toy Story is nearly flawless.

title: Toy story
review: It's a nice change of pace to see the studio draw magic from this modern tale about ordinary 20th-century kid Andy and his eager-to-please playthings.

title: Toy story
review: I can hardly imagine having more fun at the movies than I did at Toy Story, the miraculous new Disney feature that's the first full-length animated film to be produced entirely on computer.

title: Toy story
review: The great voice acting, the visual puns, all added up to an animation game changer.

title: Jumanji
review: A gloomy special-effects extravaganza filled with grotesque images, generating fear and despair.

title: Jumanji
review: A calculated but very entertaining special effects extravaganza.

title: Grumpy Old Men
review: Walter Matthau and Jack Lemmon are awfully good at this sort of thing.

title: Grumpy Old Men
review: Mediocre, regrettably.

title: Grumpy Old Men
review: Just don't expect their bickering to be on the level of Neil Simon, and you won't be disappointed.

title: Grumpy Old Men
review: While it won't come close to my top 10 best list for 1993, it will be right up there among the pictures that I had the most fun watching.

title: Grumpy Old Men
review: The movie is too pat and practiced to really be convincing, and the progress of Ariel's relationships with the two grumps seems dictated mostly by the needs of the screenplay.

title: Grumpy Old Men
review: If you poke through Grumpy's cheap sentimentality, you'll find a worthy picture somewhere.

title: Waiting to Exhale
review: Never escapes the queasy aura of Melrose Place: just another story about beautiful people with small problems.

title: Waiting to Exhale
review: A pleasant if undemanding piece of work that is diverting to sit through though it won't stand up to any kind of rigorous examination.

title: Waiting to Exhale
review: You want the movie to stomp and rejoice and cry like a fool; instead it meanders and lollygags, occasionally flaring up, then sputtering again.

title: Waiting to Exhale
review: This sister-celebratory adaptation of Terry McMillan's best-selling book is frequently delightful.

title: Waiting to Exhale
review: The male-bashing taken to an extreme in Waiting to Exhale is starting to seem a little like crack for the female psyche, exhilarating in the short term but ultimately crippling and dangerous.

title: Waiting to Exhale
review: Whitaker clumsily mishandles what should be a 'you go, girl!' tour de force.

title: Waiting to Exhale
review: For all the pleasure there is in seeing effective, great-looking black women grappling with major life issues on screen, Waiting to Exhale is an uneven piece.

title: Waiting to Exhale
review: With the exception of Bernadine, I never felt anything for the women populating this film, as they failed to capture my interest or sympathy.

title: Waiting to Exhale
review: An escapist fantasy that women in the audience can enjoy by musing, 'I wish I had her problems' - and her car, house, wardrobe, figure and men, even wrong men.

title: Father of the Bride Part II
review: Martin, Keaton and cinematographer William A. Fraker put this retro fluff over better than expected early on, but hour 2 is only for those who don't want their equilibriums rattled by surprises.

title: Heat
review: When Pacino's loud, bruised cop and De Niro's canny crook stare at each other, you can read something spent and weary in their eyes and voices. The heat is hell. So are their jobs -- but somebody's got to do them.

title: Heat
review: The taciturn De Niro and the braying Pacino share a flawless scene over a cup of coffee, but the real honors go to Val Kilmer and Ashley Judd as a warring, loving couple.

title: Heat
review: So why doesn't Heat, with its elaborately staged, tautly edited robberies, its killer cast, edgy score and elegant cinematography, offer more satisfaction? It's the script, stupid.

title: Heat
review: Just when it seemed that the only hope for crime movies lay in the postmodernist artifice of films like Pulp Fiction, Mann reinvests the genre with brooding, modernist conviction. This one sticks to your gut.

title: Heat
review: There's nothing really new in this lengthy 1995 thriller by writer-director Michael Mann about cops and robbers in Los Angeles, but it has craft, pacing, and an overall sense of proportion, three pretty rare classic virtues nowadays.

title: Heat
review: An odd though often entertaining blend of The Asphalt Jungle and Oprah, a traditional cops-and-robbers story weirdly fitted out with long, earnest discussions of interpersonal relationships.

title: Heat
review: There isn't much going on at this party other than what the actors bring to it. But fortunately, Mann has invited some exceptional ones.

title: Heat
review: Heat becomes consistently more interesting as it forges on toward the 180-minute mark.

title: Heat
review: Heat occupies an exalted position among the countless contemporary crime films.

title: Heat
review: Robert De Niro's last great role before he devoted himself to self-parody.

title: Heat
review: This is simply the best American crime movie -- and indeed, one of the finest movies, period -- in over a decade.

title: Heat
review: As Heat progresses, its sensational looks pale beside storytelling weaknesses that expose the more soulless aspects of this cat-and-mouse crime tale.

title: Heat
review: Michael Mann and a superlative cast have taken a classic heist movie rife with familiar genre elements and turned it into a sleek, accomplished piece of work, meticulously controlled and completely involving.

title: Heat
review: All the squealing tires, flying bullets and falling bodies cannot save Heat from drowning in its own banalities.

title: Heat
review: Michael Mann's writing and direction elevate this material. It's not just an action picture.

title: Heat
review: ... a colossal disappointment.

title: Heat
review: Heat generates lots of energy but gives off little light.

title: Heat
review: Boosters and touts use the term 'major movie' so often that it's more likely to generate yawns than excitement at this point. Back to basics. Heat is a major movie. With major stars. Doing major acting.

title: Heat
review: This is the first time De Niro and Pacino have acted together, and each gives a strong, watertight performance.

title: Heat
review: The cop/ crime stuff that makes up the bulk of the movie is well thought out and well directed.

title: Sabrina
review: This is never less than glittering entertainment, but somehow a certain measure of lead has found its way into the formula.

title: Sabrina
review: Script is long on glibly quipping dialog, dropped with a seemingly casual air, and broadly played situations. The splendid trouping delivers them style. Leavening the chuckles are tugs at the heart.

title: Sabrina
review: Wilder's tastelessness now seems his major artistic strength.

title: Sabrina
review: It's a Cinderella story that gets turned on its head, a satire about breaking down class and emotional barriers, and a confrontation between New World callousness and Old World humanity.

title: Sabrina
review: Hampered by an unimaginative script ... nevertheless manages to be a thoroughly charming, delightfully romantic variation of the Cinderella story.

title: Sabrina
review: It is a story as light as a feather and as old as yesterday's news, as transparent as a society column item and as smug as a foreign-made car. But Mr. Wilder...has made it into a commentary as crisp as a screed in a smart magazine.

title: Tom and Huck
review: A joyless lump.

title: Sudden Death
review: Reuniting Hyams and Van Damme, director and star of Timecop, this spectacular nail-biter exploits their combined, if limited, abilities to the full.

title: Sudden Death
review: Offers above-average pyrotechnics, a body count that steadily mounts, and plenty of hand-to-hand combat.

title: Sudden Death
review: Sudden Death is one of the best action thrillers of 1995. It's also the film Jean-Claude Van Damme has been building up to for 10 years.

title: Sudden Death
review: Despite the elaborate stunts, go-go-go direction from Peter Hyams, plus butt-kicking and surprise goalie action from Van Damme, Death deserves the hockey-puck booby prize for...getting its jollies by putting kids in jeopardy.

title: Sudden Death
review: A treat for Jean-Claude Van Damme fans, a superior action thriller loaded with jaw-dropping stunts and special effects, and strong in production values.

title: Sudden Death
review: Sudden Death isn't about common sense. It's about the manipulation of action and special-effects sequences to create a thriller effect, and at that it's pretty good.

title: Sudden Death
review: Though the climactic duel atop the arena roof is patently absurd, it's also exciting as events go into sudden-death overtime, just like the game being played below.

title: Sudden Death
review: Van Damme races against time, trying to thwart Boothe and defuse all the bombs. But in the hands of director Peter Hyams, these are just banal action-movie chores.

title: Sudden Death
review: About the best thing that can be said about this movie is that the action scenes, directed by Peter Hyams, are choreographed with flair. Unfortunately, the material connecting them is worthless.

title: GoldenEye
review: Brosnan, however, looks set to stay. He'll never recapture the amused cool of the young Sean Connery, but he does overcome the handicap of looking like a humorless male model.

title: GoldenEye
review: I don't know whether the Bond series has a future, but if Xenia Onatopp ever returns to try for world domination, he may finally get a battle worth fighting.

title: GoldenEye
review: There's something a mite pathetic about our culture still clinging to 007, but it's hard to deny that this is one of the most entertaining entries in the Bond cycle.

title: GoldenEye
review: Richard Kiel, you are missed.

title: GoldenEye
review: Among the better of the 17 Bonds and, perhaps more important for today's audience, a dynamic action entry in its own right, this first 007 adventure in six years breathes fresh creative and commercial life into the 33-year-old series.

title: GoldenEye
review: Director Campbell keeps matters bowling along and even manages to recapture something of the look of the earlier films.

title: GoldenEye
review: Suffers the blahs.

title: GoldenEye
review: Supercharged with spectacular, thundering, brain-numbing fun.

title: GoldenEye
review: They have given James a new car here, but it's the same old vanity plate, the one that should read: Je Me Souviens.

title: GoldenEye
review: A reasonable facsimile more than any kind of original, and it's hard not to feel a certain weariness while watching it unfold.

title: GoldenEye
review: It's BS -- Babes and Stunts -- and that's where GoldenEye excels.

title: GoldenEye
review: Directed with top-dollar proficiency (and some real wit).

title: GoldenEye
review: Perhaps the best entry in the series since The Spy Who Loved Me.

title: GoldenEye
review: Watching the film, I got caught up in the special effects and the neat stunts, and I observed with a certain satisfaction Bond's belated entry into a more modern world.

title: The American President
review: Part romantic comedy, part Capra-corny political drama, this movie exudes so much sympathy, it sweats.

title: The American President
review: Genial and entertaining if not notably inspired.

title: The American President
review: Genial middlebrow fare that coasts a long way on the charm of its two stars.

title: The American President
review: As bustling and impassioned as the best Sturges and Capra movies.

title: The American President
review: Neither bad nor unwatchable, The American President is nevertheless the second straight disappointment from director Rob Reiner.

title: The American President
review: You can't dislike this movie, but you won't be swept away by it either.

title: The American President
review: The American President will make you laugh and make you smile. But it probably won't make you change your vote.

title: The American President
review: Apart from its too-obvious political bias, The American President has romance in its heart, smarts in abundance and class to spare.

title: The American President
review: Great entertainment.

title: The American President
review: A well-modulated charmer.

title: The American President
review: The American President becomes a pretty darn entertaining and affecting movie after its first simpering 20 minutes.

title: The American President
review: Frothy.

title: The American President
review: 'Capraesque' has inevitably been affixed to The American President, but that phrase, with its implications of facile hokum, doesn't do the film justice.

title: The American President
review: Painless fun.

review: A super cast injects it with Teddy Roosevelt vitality.

title: The American President

title: The American President
review: The image of a chief executive as moonstruck single guy taps something buoyant and touching in our collective democratic imagination. And Douglas, wearing a fast-break smile in place of his usual frown, strikes a tender rapport with Bening...

title: Dracula: Dead and Loving It

review: The only real sparks are set off by MacNicol as Renfield, the solicitor who develops a taste for flies and spiders after being bitten by Dracula.

title: Dracula: Dead and Loving It
review: Brooks, as Van Helsing, is one of the more successful aspects, but he hasn't imbued in his stock company a similar ability to rise above their underwritten roles.

title: Dracula: Dead and Loving It
review: Slight but amusing.

title: Dracula: Dead and Loving It
review: Not to venture forth some sort of radical idea, but aren't comedies supposed to have jokes?

title: Dracula: Dead and Loving It
review: It's a toothless parody that misses more often than it hits.

title: Dracula: Dead and Loving It
review: This time, unfortunately, he's sucking on a dry vein.

title: Dracula: Dead and Loving It
review: If any movie proves that Mel Brooks' genius for skewering creaky genres has evaporated, it's this anemic attempt to draw new blood from low-flying vampire high jinks.

title: Dracula: Dead and Loving It
review: Dracula is anemic and mediocre, with only one or two moments to remind you of the former, funnier Brooks.

title: Dracula: Dead and Loving It
review: Nielsen makes a dapper and calmly inept Dracula, but it's Brooks' irrepressible and oblivious Van Helsing who's the main attraction.

title: Balto
review: The love story is pure mush, not helped by the bland voice work done by Kevin Bacon as Balto and Bridget Fonda as dainty husky Jenna.

title: Nixon
review: As wayward and self-regarding as its subject, the film long overstays its welcome.

title: Nixon
review: What it finally adds up to is a huge mixed bag of waxworks and daring, a film that is furiously ambitious even when it goes flat, and startling even when it settles for eerie, movie-of-the-week mimicry.

title: Nixon
review: Without question, Nixon dwarfs everything in the American cinema since Schindler's List.

title: Nixon
review: Nixon starts, like a horror movie, on a dark and stormy night, with the president prowling around a room of the White House like Dracula in his lair.

title: Nixon
review: Nixon far overstays its welcome with an increasingly tedious final hour devoted largely to slogging through the minutiae of Watergate.

title: Nixon
review: Factual or not, there's no denying that Nixon has moments when it is nothing short of compelling.

title: Nixon
review: There's no compelling structure or viewpoint to hold the picture together.

title: Nixon
review: The problem here isn't accuracy. It's absurdity.

title: Nixon
review: Thoughts of Hamlet, Macbeth and King Lear come to mind; here, again, is a ruler destroyed by his fatal flaws. There's something almost majestic about the process: As Nixon goes down in this film, there is no gloating, but a watery sigh, as of a great ship

title: Nixon
review: You will not be bored.

review: The picture is a case study.

title: Nixon
review: Casting Anthony Hopkins was a stroke of unexpected genius.

title: Nixon
review: Stone's no Shakespeare, and neither are his screenwriters.

review: Joan Allen goes beyond her chilling physical resemblance to Pat Nixon toward serious Oscar worthiness.

title: Nixon
review: I never felt that I was seeing the darkness reaching out to the darkness as Nixon was once described.

review: Real life, if it's real Nixon, is more dramatic than an Oliver Stone movie.

title: Cutthroat Island
review: What seemed like a dubious proposition on paper plays even more dubiously onscreen, as "Cutthroat Island" strenuously but vainly attempts to revive the thrills of old-fashioned pirate pictures.

title: Cutthroat Island
review: In this $90m revisionist swashbuckler, we get Geena Davis doing the all-action honours, and a hotchpotch script that seems to think pirate movies are so funny in themselves the need for more humour is superfluous.

title: Cutthroat Island
review: t's not possible to believe that Ms. Davis is the highly respected captain of a pirate ship, and it's not even fun to try.

title: Cutthroat Island
review: If the sight of half-naked, tattooed sailors firing cannons at each other shivers your timbers, climb aboard. Even passable pirate movies don't sail by every day.

title: Cutthroat Island
review: It takes a two-hour act of will to keep facing the screen during this moribund movie.

title: Casino
review: [Stone] seems to be trying to enter a more passionate movie, where a neurotic gold digger could at least have a good time. By the end of Casino, for all its craftsmanly bravura, you may want to join her.

title: Casino
review: So long as Casino stays focused on the excesses -- of language, of violence, of ambition -- in the life-styles of the rich and infamous, it remains a smart, knowing, if often repetitive, spectacle.

title: Casino
review: Simultaneously quite watchable and passionless.

title: Casino
review: Martin Scorsese's intimate epic about money, sex and brute force is a grandly conceived study of what happens to goodfellas from the mean streets when they outstrip their wildest dreams and achieve the pinnacle of wealth and power.

title: Casino
review: It's not the actors' fault that no one is able to break through the film's gorgeous but chilly surface. You watch Casino with respect and appreciation, reveling in its documentary sense of detail.

title: Casino
review: Scorsese may be flailing here, but Scorsese flailing is more formidable than most directors at the top of their form.

title: Casino
review: The result, sadly, is that contradiction in terms, a dull Scorsese movie.

title: Casino
review: Of all the bravura visual effects in Martin Scorsese's dazzlingly stylish Casino, it's a glimpse of ordinary people that delivers the greatest jolt.

title: Casino
review: It's an ambitious film, but also a scattered, unfocused one.

title: Casino
review: Visually impressive, splendidly performed, thematically significant, this is a movie in full possession of every key cinematic asset except one -- a solid script.

title: Casino
review: [A] Vegas masterpiece.

title: Casino
review: Martin Scorsese is a master filmmaker, so skilled in the manipulation of imagery he might be the most proficient of active American directors.

title: Casino
review: After coming out gangbusters in its first and finest hour, the 180-minute movie loses all its chips in the remaining two.

title: Casino
review: Martin Scorsese's fascinating new film Casino knows a lot about the Mafia's relationship with Las Vegas.

title: Casino
review: In every way -- from the fantastic sets, rich dialogue, and unapologetic violence to the well-portrayed characters and themes of loyalty and betrayal -- Casino is pure Scorsese.

title: Casino
review: Whether you find it exhilarating, expendable or exhausting -- and you will find it exhausting -- Martin Scorsese's Casino is the spectacular last word on urban sprawl.

title: Sense and Sensibility
review: Thompson's script manages the neat trick of preserving the necessary niceties and decorum of civilized behavior of the time while still cutting to the dramatic quick.

review: I can't say I remembered this 1995 feature too clearly a couple of days later; but I certainly had a good time as I watched it.

review: Thompson and Winslet give fine performances ably supported by the rest of the ensemble.

title: Sense and Sensibility
review: We need no further proof that this material is ageless.

review: The sensibility may be a bit off, but there is more than enough sense involved in this mid-Atlantic Austen to make up the difference.

review: The film is packed with pleasing performances by stage-trained actors.

review: Told with deft skill and a pleasantly humorous romantic touch.

review: It's bliss.

review: A triumph for Taiwan's most famous director, Ang Lee.

review: Thompson's script hits its peak by keeping Austen's voice yet finding the satirical smirk behind it.

review: Sense and Sensibility is funny, expansive, and a delight to spend company with.

review: The movie is good fun, boasting a dozen vivid characters and two that moviegoers will take to heart.

review: Demonstrates how little humankind has evolved in matters of the heart.

review: An exuberant, well- crafted film that gets the audience involved on a gut level.

title: Four Rooms

review: Four of the hottest indie directors--Anders, Rockwell, Tarantino, and Rodrigues--miss a unique opportunity to display their idiosyncratic talents resulting in a tedious anthology in which 2 segments are inept, one barely decent, and one OK (guess whose)

review: They should have called this One Room and released it as a Rodriguez short.

title: Four Rooms
review: The less said about this career-denting fiasco, the better.

title: Four Rooms
review: Sounds better than it is.

review: Four Rooms has been cut substantially since a disastrous September reception at the Toronto Film Festival, though it's hard to imagine it running any longer.

title: Four Rooms

title: Four Rooms

review: The segments are uniformly weak.

title: Four Rooms
review: Four Rooms has to be one of 1995's major disappointments.

review: Hardly worth the four-year wait.

review: Even if they only charged a token, it would be too much.

title: Get Shorty

review: An entertaining comedy-thriller adapted by Scott Frank from the Elmore Leonard best-seller and directed with bounce (if not much nuance) by Barry Sonnenfeld.

review: Everything clicks.

title: Get Shorty
review: It's part of the joke here that Chili is a die-hard cineaste and loves reminiscing about smart, stylish tough-guy films he has enjoyed. Get Shorty belongs on that list.

review: It's Travolta -- smooth, commanding, handsome as ever, a cool, rhythmic bop in his walk -- who owns the film.

review: The result is one of the best movies of the year and by far the most entertaining.

title: Get Shorty
review: In the category of amiable diversions it's awfully tough to improve on.

title: Get Shorty
review: Irresistibly charming.

title: Get Shorty
review: Minor, but amusingly droll.

title: Get Shorty
review: One of the pleasures of Get Shorty is watching the way the plot moves effortlessly from crime to the movies - not a long distance, since both industries are based on fear, greed, creativity and intimidation.

title: Get Shorty
review: This comic potboiler about gangsters in Hollywood would be a great piece of fun even without Travolta. But as a loan shark from Miami with a charming bedside manner and bigtime movie dreams, he raises the fun quotient into the sublime.

review: While it's quite possible for the cinematically unaware to enjoy this film, this is a real treat for movie buffs. The story is as much about the love of motion pictures as it is about gangsters.

review: Perhaps such phenomenal slaughter is best left to the imagination.

review: This movie knows exactly what it is: Gonzo silliness about bodies turned into human salsa.

review: It's a gorefest, a borefest and a snorefest.

review: Thanks to the movie's dire script, flat performances and excessively slick, tricked-out fight scenes, it gets increasingly hard to care about anything that goes on here, even when it happens to be visible without the use of night-vision goggles.

review: This one is simply a diverting, uncommonly violent action flick. No need for an extended critical postmortem. Except to say the Wachowski brothers' trademark seems to have turned into a designer brand dedicated to producing inexpensive knockoffs.

review: Rain is a very talented slaughterer. He could kill you with a pair of tweezers, a hair dryer, two bananas, whatever. Be glad he's a good ninja.

review: When a movie's first scene shows one thug getting the top of his head sliced off and another being chopped diagonally in half, you know you're not in for much of a dramatic crescendo.

title: Ninja Assassin

review: You'd think that decree No. 1 for a movie about rules would be to know exactly what kind of picture you're making and selling. Georgia Rule fails that basic test, and a whole lot of other ones besides.

title: Georgia Rule
review: As an acting showcase -- the supporting roles are as rich as the leads -- Georgia Rule is undeniably one of the year's best American dramedies.

title: Georgia Rule
review: It's a creepy, tone-deaf movie about three generations of women.

title: Georgia Rule
review: A murky blend of melodrama and comedy.

title: Georgia Rule
review: Do not take your mom to Georgia Rule unless she's Roseanne Barr. You may expect a three-generational chick flick, but what you get is a child-rape comedy.

title: Georgia Rule
review: Misguided at best and repellent at worst.

title: Georgia Rule
review: You can see what they are striving for, but Georgia Rule is so artificial, it feels like more of a flow chart than a slice of life.

title: Georgia Rule
review: Not to excuse her apparent lack of professionalism, but can you blame Lohan for showing up to work in bad shape?

title: Georgia Rule

title: Georgia Rule

title: Georgia Rule

title: Georgia Rule
review: Georgia Rule is a bad idea dreadfully executed -- On Golden Pond with fellatio jokes and whimsical incest melodrama and Fonda playing her dad (who, more and more, she eerily resembles).

title: Georgia Rule
review: Certain words should be reserved for special occasions. 'Abysmal' is one of them, and Georgia Rule is as special as such occasions get.

title: Home for the Holidays
review: Spirited but uneven.

title: Home for the Holidays
review: Neither caustic nor sentimental, it's a film that maybe half the people on Earth have at one time considered writing.

title: Home for the Holidays
review: Foster keeps the party hopping, although more dark humor would have helped before she winds it down with sentiment and bromides.

title: Home for the Holidays
review: Foster and Richter, of course, want to do more than make audiences laugh; they want us to be touched by their characters' humanity and take an interest in a budding romance, but that rarely is the case.

title: Home for the Holidays
review: With many of the conversations going on simultaneously, it's difficult -- sometimes even impossible -- to know who is saying what and to whom.

title: Home for the Holidays
review: With her keen actor's instincts, Foster piles on plenty for her terrific cast to chew on and for us to savor.

title: Home for the Holidays
review: The movie, which is about the Thanksgiving family reunion from hell, is not exactly a comedy and yet not a drama, either. Like many family reunions, it has a little of both elements, and the strong sense that madness is being held just out of sight.

review: Aside from a few effective, low-key scenes, the movie doesn't involve the viewer.

review: A spoof of eco-consciousness starring one-man toxic spill Pauly Shore.

review: As the bloodsuckers attack our 'heroes' again and again, you feel like you're watching a video game -- from dusk to dawn.

review: It's great fun, but certainly not great art.

review: The movie, which treats you with contempt for even watching it, is a monument to its own lack of imagination.

review: An enjoyable movie.

review: If you're into Will Ferrell.

review: It just plods along, harmless but lifeless, going exactly where you think it's going.

review: Sit in a room by yourself, look at a blank screen for 90 minutes, and you'll have more of a chance of laughing at your own thoughts than you will at this movie.

review: Stop me if you've heard this before.

review: Silly, mindless and derivative, but Duvall brings some bite to the proceedings and Ferrell is dependably amusing.

review: Both Duvall and Mike Ditka, who plays himself and helps coach Phil's team, spend too much of the movie on the bench, and while they're there, the jokes run thin.

review: A limping string of laboured sight gags and sentimental cliches.

review: Doesn't quite deliver the comedy goods, but it plays well in spurts and, thanks to Ferrell, remains slightly off-kilter.

title: Kicking & Screaming
review: The sort of almost-there family movie for which half-stars exist in ratings.

review: Rather shakily directed by Jesse (son of Bob) Dylan, who possibly knows something about larger-than-life fathers.

title: Kicking & Screaming

title: Les misérables

review: This film offers just about everything, including a twenty-minute white-knuckle sequence and a chance to shed a few tears. In short, it's first-rate entertainment.

review: A one-joke skit that trots in a straight line, and your enjoyment of it will depend entirely on how many times you need to see gonzo sheep rip out human entrails.

review: Rife with bloody gore and funny gags.

review: This modern fable is little more than a Murphy potboiler, something to while away a couple of hours, rather than fondly remember.

review: Zeroes in on retail mania with a flimsy wire hanger of a premise.

title: Going Shopping
review: Going Shopping...has enough smart, knowing touches and enough easy spontaneity among its well-chosen actors to make you wish it added up to more than what it turns out to be: a flighty, motor-mouthed cinematic divertissement.

title: Going Shopping
review: Henry Jaglom completes his informal trilogy on estrogen-laced obsessions with this seriocomic exploration of women and clothes.

title: Going Shopping
review: Henry Jaglom's latest study of contemporary female obsessions among a noxious clan of West L.A. bourgeoisie is of more pathological than cinematic interest.

title: City Hall
review: Its chief pleasure is the acting of the big cast, notably Pacino. At 55, he has a haggard, life-wrestling beauty and a street eloquence that has more innocence than De Niro and more sincerity than Nicholson.

title: City Hall
review: A watchable but never pulsating portrait of mayoral wheeling-dealing.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: A confident, eccentric debut about a trio of shambling and guileless friends who become the Candides of crime, Rocket feels particularly refreshing because it never compromises on its delicate deadpan sensibility.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: [Bottle Rocket] meanders pleasantly, like a road movie, with a seventies-style, anything-goes offhandedness that whisks the audience through the rough spots.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: Bottle Rocket was conceived as a low-budget family affair -- it has more Wilsons than the Beach Boys -- and outside of a few cult-intensive pockets of fandom, that's where it's likely to end up.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: This is a movie about friendship, about foolhardy endeavors that get your adrenaline going and make you feel life buzzing in your toes. Written with wit and concision and remarkable confidence, Bottle Rocket is a joyride worth taking.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: Bottle Rocket is a beguiling surprise, a terrific little movie comedy about a slightly addled gang of young criminal wannabes.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: With a wild-card character like Dignan, he could be either the most original character in many a moon -- or never convincing. Wilson, with his cockeyed grin and rapid-fire delivery, comes off as a young Dennis Hopper.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: Wes Anderson's 1996 first feature (before Rushmore and The Royal Tenenbaums) is fresh, character driven, often funny, and unfashionably upbeat (as well as offbeat).

title: Bottle Rocket
review: The title refers to cheap fireworks that fizz before they flame out quietly, and that's what three Southwestern slackers do in this amiable heist movie-cum-road flick.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: Even as you laugh at these guys, you feel an overwhelming sympathy for them. Sensing that they love each other, you want their dumb, dysfunctional lives to work out.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: Caan does a funny cameo as the local crimelord but the film belongs to Anderson's co-conspirator Wilson, whose wired performance leaps off the screen.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: Full of surprising warmth and charm, unexpected plot turns and droll characters that bounce off each other in refreshing ways, this genre-defying Columbia pickup may struggle to overcome its lack of an obvious marketing handle.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: Starts and finishes strong, but, somewhere in the middle, it loses its focus and its way.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: A hilarious, inventive and goofy breath of fresh air.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: A grueling, numbing black hole.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: I can't recommend the film -- it's too unwound and indulgent -- but I have a certain affection for it, and I'm looking forward to whatever Anderson and the Wilsons do next.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: A mildly facetious tone limits Anderson's film to the lightweight, but the collective enthusiasm behind this debut effort still comes through.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: A little deal, this movie is like a bottle rocket itself: a big bang for the money.

title: Bottle Rocket
review: Gets by on quirky charm and slacker chic -- but just barely.

title: Mr. Wrong
review: The hip, smart yarn has a bite not seen in American movies since The War of the Roses.

title: Mr. Wrong
review: A dreadful movie.

title: Mr. Wrong
review: This is a romantic comedy parody, but how can you satirize something that's a comedy to begin with? If this motion picture is an example, not only can't it be done, but the result is downright ugly.

title: Mr. Wrong
review: A sour, listless debunking of romantic comedies.

title: Mr. Wrong
review: Like its title character, Mr. Wrong doesn't know when to quit.

title: Mr. Wrong
review: As directed sloppily by Nick Castle, this comedy barely lets its main characters develop, even though either of them could be great fun.

title: Mr. Wrong
review: Pullman, who can usually shade a character so subtly between sweetie and sucker, is made to veer manically into jerkhood for no particular reason except that the filmmakers couldn't come up with anything smarter to propel this galumphing caper along.

title: Unforgettable
review: A B-grade murder mystery with a sci-fi twist.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: [A] one-joke Caddyshack for the blitzed and jaded.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: There are about three minutes of funny material in Happy Gilmore, and pretty much all of them are in the trailer.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: Superior disposable comedy.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: It may smell awful from a distance, especially if you have low tolerance for lowbrow humor, but up close this yarn about an unlikely golf star is fairly painless.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: You don't feel that Sandler and director Dennis Dugan are trying for the kind of subversiveness that might just make Happy's brutal anarchy more effective.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: Happy's tantrums, which the movie pretends are liberating explosions of self-expression, aren't nearly maniacal enough to reach comic delirium.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: Sandler plays this a lot smarter than, say, a Jim Carrey character, and with less slapstick. Still, this is not delicate, subtle stuff: It's smart low-brow, and only for those who like their humor a bit offbeat.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: The story has all the thickness of a well-trimmed green, but it's a decent excuse for some heady sight gags.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: The Happy Gilmore character is strange. I guess we are supposed to like him.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: Happy Gilmore may not be an ace in the hole, but it beats par by a long shot.

title: Happy Gilmore
review: Sandler's movie is worth a few laughs, but not many of the comic sequences are original, and even fewer are inspired.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: With Eastwood as Kincaid and Meryl Streep as Francesca, this carefully observant love story turns Waller's pop-lit passion into screen art.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Bridges is an admirable achievement, one that probably does more to reposition its maker as someone who can carry a movie without carrying a gun than as the director/star of a Love Story for the Loving Care set.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: The result, if rather thin and certainly far from a masterpiece, is nevertheless quite lovely. This affecting little film is easily one of Eastwood's best efforts as a director.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: The two leads' sly comic rhythm is miles removed from the book's failing solemnity.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Eastwood's Bridges has the energy and spontaneity of a picture that was shot quickly. And that serves the material well, because it removes the solemnity that could stiffle a modern classic.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Despite all his craft and sincerity, [Eastwood] and screenwriter Richard LaGravenese can't quite turn Robert James Waller's cardboard best-seller into flesh and bone.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Bridges is an old-fashioned "women's film" that pits the heroine's romantic urges against her matriarchal duties. In fact, the film is at its dramatic best when Francesca is finally obliged, like Sophie, to make her choice.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Streep makes her character known in no time flat. Intelligence, humor, blocked ambition, self-irony -- they're all contained in Francesca's quick response when Robert asks if she has any plans for the afternoon.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Meryl Streep and Clint Eastwood, as Waller's tenderly plaintive heartland lovers, are so visually and spiritually right they seem to have walked right off the page.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: What follows is, essentially, gothic-romantic bunk. But there's a nicely stylized, below-the-surface courtship between the performers. They make you forget that, at their very core, they are hackneyed creations.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Madison County is Eastwood's gift to women: to Francesca, to all the girls he's loved before -- and to Streep, who alchemizes literary mawkishness into intelligent movie passion.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Given the intelligent restraint of the treatment, this is about as fine an adaptation of this material as one could hope for...

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Immaculately performed, and assembled with wit and sensitivity, this is one of the most satisfying weepies in years.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Limited by the vapidity of this material while he trims its excesses with the requisite machete, Mr. Eastwood locates a moving, elegiac love story at the heart of Mr. Waller's self-congratulatory overkill.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: What the movie does that the book couldn't do is tap into the poignancy that comes of seeing two stars who used to be young and beautiful suddenly looking very mortal.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: Screenwriter LaGravenese ought to get the Croix de Guerre for doing battle with Waller's fatuous prose and paring Bridges down to its most appealing fantasy romance essence.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: The Bridges of Madison County is a beautiful film, not only in the way it was photographed, but for the manner through which the characters are revealed to us.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: I've seen the movie twice now and was even more involved the second time, because I was able to pay more attention to the nuances of voice and gesture.

title: The Bridges of Madison County
review: The gap between touchy-feely and touching isn't easy to span, so credit judicious pruning on the one hand and a beefed-up script on the other for getting perhaps the best possible movie out of Robert James Waller's The Bridges of Madison County.

title: Muppet Treasure Island
review: Geena Davis and Renny Harlin couldn't cut it with Cutthroat Island. Steven Spielberg nearly got the hook for Hook. But leave it to Miss Piggy and Kermit to discover uncharted gold in the shipwrecked-pirate genre.

title: Braveheart
review: As the star of the new, epic-scaled Braveheart, Gibson celebrates yet another man of selfless valor. And as its director, he displays some daring of his own.

title: Braveheart
review: A lavish, entertaining spectacle full of manly men, dastardly villains, rousing battles and women who easily see Mel's hero potential through all that messy hair.

title: Braveheart
review: In addition to staging battle scenes well, Gibson also manages to recreate the filth and mood of 700 years ago.

title: Braveheart
review: Mel Gibson throws his whole heart into a role. No one acts with more conviction, and his errors are honest ones.

title: Braveheart
review: Braveheart has a gut-wrenching, bone-breaking, sword-thwacking verve.

title: Braveheart
review: Many movies deal with battlefield heroics. Few seriously attempt to define heroism.

title: Braveheart
review: In this mix of historical tragedy and hip adventure, Gibson may be as galvanic a movie swashbuckler as Errol Flynn and Burt Lancaster were in their day.

title: Braveheart
review: The political argument that ensues is pretty dull, but the battle scenes are the loudest and most convincing in years: Gibson has learned from Kurosawa in lending a clarifying thrust to what is, essentially, chaos.

title: Braveheart
review: Braveheart looks like a true epic -- even if it is both bloody and bloody long.

title: Braveheart
review: A huge, bloody and sprawling epic, Braveheart is the sort of massive vanity piece that would be easy to disparage if it didn't essentially deliver.

title: Braveheart
review: Pure hokum.

title: Braveheart
review: Though the film dawdles a bit with the shimmery, dappled love stuff involving Wallace with a Scottish peasant and a French princess, the action will pin you to your seat.

title: Braveheart
review: As a filmmaker, [Gibson] lacks the epic gift, but the movie, scripted by Randall (no relation) Wallace, works on a fairly basic level as a hiss-the-English medieval Western.

title: Braveheart
review: Braveheart opts to turn cowardly, settling for the magnification of Gibson's idol status, forfeiting the complex, more nebulous magnificence of the real Sir William Wallace and virtually excising the strategic brilliance of Robert The Bruce.

title: Braveheart
review: At times the film seems an obsessive ode to Mel Gibson machismo.

title: Braveheart
review: Gibson's raw energy and storytelling power in Braveheart are undeniable. If the film doesn't meet his ambitions, it's because he set the bar so high.

title: Braveheart
review: With its clashing armies, heartstopping action, and grand sense of romance, this is the sort of film it's a pleasure to see and review.

title: Braveheart
review: An action epic with the spirit of the Hollywood swordplay classics and the grungy ferocity of The Road Warrior.

title: Braveheart
review: One of the most spectacular entertainments in years.

title: Braveheart
review: Everybody knows that a non-blubbering clause is standard in all movie stars' contracts. Too bad there isn't one banning self-indulgence when they direct.

title: Hung fan kui
review: Chan's insistence on his own fallibility and vulnerability, taken with virtuoso scenes like the fight involving 101 domestic appliances, shows why he means more to his countless fans than six US action stars put together.

title: Hung fan kui
review: It's light on plot and character, but the stunts are well staged.

title: Hung fan kui
review: For once a film's ad line has a whiff of truth about it: 'No Fear. No Stuntman. No Equal.'

title: Hung fan kui
review: The fun of Rumble in the Bronx is watching Chan build up one inventive and off-the-wall action scene after another.

title: Hung fan kui
review: An awkward hybrid of Asian and American film techniques.

title: Hung fan kui
review: The whole point is Jackie Chan - and, like Astaire and Rogers, he does what he does better than anybody.

title: Hung fan kui
review: It's not often you find a movie as exciting and awful as Rumble in the Bronx.

title: Hung fan kui
review: Unlike most action stars, Chan understands acting. His face is as flexible as his body, and, when he's moving, he's like a violent, supercharged combination of Gene Kelly, Fred Astaire, and Buster Keaton.

title: Hung fan kui
review: You can smirk at Rumble and deny its pedigree with some justification, as long as you concede that it's 10 times more fun to watch than Before and After and Mary Reilly put together.

title: Hung fan kui
review: Awe-inspiring.

title: Hung fan kui
review: The very medium of the moving picture exists to create the suspension of disbelief, and there is no greater live performer than Chan to make us believe you can beat up a street gang with a linen jacket and refrigerators.

title: Hung fan kui
review: A giddy triple somersault of a film that makes no sense whatsoever, although in its best moments it is as much fun to watch as a death-defying circus act.

title: Hung fan kui
review: More than a martial arts whiz, the 41-year-old Chan possesses the comic timing of a born clown, the grace of a Broadway hoofer and the daredevil bravado of an Evel Knievel.

title: Hung fan kui
review: As the star cheerfully camouflages massive bandages on a twisted ankle, we also get a glimpse of just how far Chan is willing to go to please his audience.

title: Hung fan kui
review: As the guy who cleans up a ghetto, helps a crippled kid and does battle with a rampaging Hovercraft, Chan shows off the muscle of a superhero and the charm of a deft comedian.

title: Hung fan kui
review: Chan, doing everything at once including all his own stunts, has an infectious energy that will help to remind you why you love movies.

title: Before and After
review: Despite Meryl Streep, Liam Neeson and the usually estimable Edward Furlong, this nonevent huffs and puffs to attain even the level of an ordinary motion picture.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: New insignts about Anne's spicy personality and immense curiosity are revealed by Holocaust survivors Hanneli Goslar and particularly Miep Gies, an office employee of Anne's father who was one of the main helpers to the families in hiding.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: Just when you might well have thought that pretty much all had been said and done about Anne Frank, this film makes us realize how much there still is to know about her and her times.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: Remarkable, deeply moving work that attempts to answer the haunting question, Who was Anne Frank?

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: If the story of each of Hitler's victims was told with the sensitivity and power of Anne Frank Remembered, there would not be enough buckets in the world to hold all the tears.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: Anne's story of courage in the face of horrendous circumstances is a fine legacy, and Anne Frank Remembered reaffirms how relevant her message is today.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: The film's accumulated force is a testament to the power of understatement.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: Anne Frank Remembered tells the audience very little about Anne, but the film speaks volumes concerning the problematic aspects of Holocaust representation.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: In the film's most extraordinary discovery, we see the only existing film footage of Anne Frank, taken one day in 1941, before the Franks went into hiding.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: If this is not the best film about the Holocaust, it does strongly chronicle the sad fate of one of its most famous victims.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: The interviews constitute the emotional backbone. The mere existence of these survivors is eloquent testimony to events so cruel they defy belief.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: Of all the movies and television productions that have told her story, this is the most valuable and satisfying.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: In retracing the short life and grotesque death of the century's best known diarist, Anna Frank, it has its own private dignity.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: A tender, elaborately detailed account of a life curtailed.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
review: The film adds little to previous factual knowledge, but it deepens our connections with the story through the power of film itself.

title: If Lucy Fell
review: A bleak, annoyingly quirky Gen-X recasting of the When Harry Met Sally notion that true love is based on friendship.

title: If Lucy Fell
review: All coy grins and daffy mugging, Mr. Stiller plays the role as if aspiring to become the Elliott Gould of his generation. Compared with jumping off the Brooklyn Bridge, that's a reasonable goal.

title: If Lucy Fell
review: If Lucy Fell is funnier more often than not, and when it's not being funny it's at least being strange. I'll take strange over what most major-distributor comedies are when they're not being funny.

title: If Lucy Fell
review: There is an affectation that I find particularly annoying, and that is when people choose to perform at a level below their natural intelligence.

title: If Lucy Fell
review: It's airy, fluffy and ultimately uninteresting.

title: If Lucy Fell
review: If Lucy Fell should be a chore, and yet I kept catching myself having a good time.

title: If Lucy Fell
review: Sadly, the story is nowhere as original as the details and performances.

title: If Lucy Fell
review: A disappointingly superficial romantic comedy. There's no chemistry between any of the characters. The acting is mediocre, with Schaeffer and Parker exhibiting no screen presence.

title: Steal Big Steal Little
review: Overlong and overreaching.

title: Boomerang
review: In Boomerang Eddie Murphy straitjackets himself in an ill-fitting comedy vehicle that's desperately in need of a reality check.

title: Boomerang
review: The general idea is to exploit a certain amount of role reversal, and Reginald Hudlin, who directed House Party, does a fairly good job of making this fun.

title: Boomerang
review: The film is far too slick to be ineffective, but its attempts to play with the sex-war theme are often unbelievably crass.

title: Boomerang
review: There's something paradoxical about the ease he radiates in playing a man who is supposed to be a smashing success. As an underdog, Mr. Murphy worked much harder.

title: Boomerang
review: For all the sex talk in Boomerang, there's very little nudity. The only thing naked is Murphy's vanity.

title: Boomerang
review: Boomerang is the funniest, most sophisticated movie of Eddie Murphy's career.

title: Boomerang
review: Whatever [Murphy] was thinking during the dark days of his career slump, it seems to have paid off handsomely.

title: Boomerang
review: Murphy gives his most appealing performance to date, using his smug, self-satisfied, sly smile as a joke on his own well-known screen persona.

title: Chung Hing sam lam
review: As fresh as falling rain, a pair of love stories full of pain and humor.

title: Chung Hing sam lam
review: It's interesting enough to watch for most of its length because of Wong's incisive camera work and his intense immersion of the Hong Kong night culture.

title: Chung Hing sam lam
review: This is the kind of movie you'll relate to if you love film itself, rather than its surface aspects such as story and stars.

title: Chung Hing sam lam
review: Once the viewer gets past bouts of confusion (the film demands more than one viewing), the result is a uniquely memorable look at the ties that bind all people.

title: Chung Hing sam lam
review: A frenetic one-way ride through The Land of Vaporous Plot, with stops along the way at Irritatingly Cute Extended Metaphor City.

title: Chung Hing sam lam
review: More impressive than engaging.

title: L'uomo delle stelle
review: The movie is not as special as Cinema Paradiso, but in its own way it is enchanted, too. Mother of God, what faces.

title: L'uomo delle stelle
review: The central story, belatedly introduced, may prove rudely downbeat for viewers who lapped up Paradiso's sentiment.

title: Flirting with Disaster
review: David O. Russell has a twisted mind; I like that in a man.

title: Flirting with Disaster
review: This whacked-out road comedy about a young man's search for his real parents takes any number of unexpected turns, most of them bitingly funny.

title: Flirting with Disaster
review: The neurotic frenzy threatens to annoy, but Russell's edgy, abbreviated style generates farcical comic friction without sacrificing character.

title: Flirting with Disaster
review: There are conventions in this sort of story, and Russell seems to violate most of them. He allows the peculiarities of his characters to lead them away from the plot line and into perplexities of their own.

title: Flirting with Disaster
review: Hang on and prepare to laugh continually.

title: Flirting with Disaster
review: The perpetual motion is a deliciously hysterical rush. This offbeat, documentary-like comedy becomes geometrically funnier as it goes along.

title: Flirting with Disaster
review: [A] wonderfully mad odyssey of a movie, in which a man sets out to find his biological parents and winds up meeting more weirdos than Alice found down the rabbit hole.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: The film isn't wrenching enough to do it justice.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: If Parker had aimed more at capturing the author's unique voice, and worried less about getting the details right, his movie might have been extraordinary.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: There is in the film a beauty and ambition rare in most current movies.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: Mostly misses the humor, lyricism and emotional charge of Frank McCourt's magical and magnificent memoir.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: Watson, the queen of suffering-female roles, is as good as ever.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: Angela's Ashes is the soggiest dud of all the major holiday releases.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: Mostly it's a series of visits to the welfare line.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: Lacking a heart.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: The film is too often trapped in its own reverence and solemnity.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: I'm sure the producers of Angela's Ashes meant well, but they got the wrong guy to direct it.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: As well-crafted and sensitive as it is, the movie remains one step removed from inspiration.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: Primitive peoples, or so it's said, resist being photographed, believing that the creation of an image robs them of their souls. A quaint notion, perhaps, but how else can you explain what's happened to Angela's Ashes?

title: Angela's Ashes
review: For all its fidelity to the spirit and, in extended passages, to the letter of McCourt's book, however, Parker's film falls short.

title: Angela's Ashes
review: There's a compelling momentum to Angela's Ashes, Alan Parker's very faithful, if poetically subordinate, version of McCourt's book, which imposed elegance on squalor and intelligence on the indolence cultivated by poverty.

title: Down Periscope
review: It's good-natured, innocuous frivolity that should raise a few smiles and generate good but not great spring box office.

title: Down Periscope
review: he construction is so ramshackle (or the mood so PC) that the film-makers put a woman (Holly) on board, then can't find a thing to do with her.

title: Down Periscope
review: A soggy sub sandwich layered with cheesy action, stale jokes and gung-ho baloney.

title: Down Periscope
review: The tone of the acting, which is set by Mr. Grammer's blandly laid-back performance, is all wrong for a genre that demands over-the-top hamming.

title: Down Periscope
review: More laid-back here than he is on television, Grammer seems to barely break a sweat.

title: Down Periscope
review: After that auspicious opening, it sinks.

title: Down Periscope
review: There are occasional laughs, but, as with most movies that think they're funnier than they actually are, most of the jokes fall flat.

title: Man of the Year
review: Levinson has written and directed in many genres. But rarely has he made a film as indecisive and diffident as Man of the Year.

title: Man of the Year
review: A surprisingly complex and dark satire that skewers the media as well as the political process.

title: Man of the Year
review: Man of the Year makes telling points and has a lot to say, but it loses its voice along with its consistency around the mid-way point, and that will likely make it an also-ran in the box office race.

title: Man of the Year
review: It's a comedy, a political thriller, a love story: Barry Levinson's Man of the Year tries to be all things to all people and fails on every count -- a little like the generic, ineffectual politicians it's pretending to excoriate.

title: Man of the Year
review: A few observations about the hollowness of party politics, plus Robin Williams doing lots of funny shtick as a Jon Stewart-like comic running for president, have been thrown together with low regard for logic or consistent tone.

title: Man of the Year
review: Barry Levinson's Man of the Year squanders a promising premise; it's ultimately overlong, underwritten and strangely unfunny.

title: Man of the Year
review: A genre-less, imaginative riff by an intelligent filmmaker on the state of the country.

title: Man of the Year
review: It's a nearly tone-deaf satire of American politics and the culture of celebrity, a comedy without enough laughs, a satire without enough bite.

title: Man of the Year
review: Only in filmmaking does one very good idea plus another very good idea sometimes add up to one less-than-great picture.

title: Man of the Year
review: Man of the Year is longer than the FDR administration, less funny than Calvin Coolidge and deader than Abe Lincoln.

title: Man of the Year
review: A few moments do not make a new Mr. Smith Goes to Washington. Frank Capra can continue to rest in peace.

title: Man of the Year
review: The second half of Man of the Year bears practically no relation to the irreverent comedy the movie's trailer sells you -- much like a politician who doesn't keep any of the promises that lured you to vote for him.

title: Man of the Year
review: Man of the Year isn't Movie of the Year. It might have been an ironic condemnation of electoral fraud and the malignant sway of corporate profits. But for a while, anyway, it had my vote.

title: Man of the Year
review: Man of the Year is a moderately funny little movie that isn't pointed enough to successfully skewer its political targets.

title: Man of the Year
review: Man of the Year is a well-intentioned mess, a dated, yuk-it-up sloppy civics lesson with such a lack of conviction that it backs away from the very questions it poses.

title: Man of the Year
review: No one will mistake Man of the Year for movie of the year, but it says some things worth being said without the usual straight face.

title: Man of the Year
review: Man of the Year starts out funny -- at least that's the intention -- and then morphs into a kind of paranoid thriller. Neither one of the movie's split personalities is particularly good.

title: Man of the Year
review: There's a Preston Sturges lesson in Man of the Year: Entertaining folks is its own civic duty. At times, making citizens laugh (and think) might be the most honorable profession of all.

title: Hard Target
review: A disappointing American debut of the Hong Kong cult director John Woo is a decent action vehicle by standards of its star Jean-Claude Van Damme but, hampered by a B script and flat characters, it doesn't bear Woo's auteurist signature and unique vision

title: Hard Target
review: It's what Hollywood wanted Woo for: bigger, brighter explosions.

title: Hard Target
review: Presenting Mr. Van Damme as reverentially as Sergio Leone did the young Clint Eastwood, Mr. Woo displays a real aptitude for malignant mischief, which is this story's stock in trade.

title: Hard Target
review: Even when the acting is hammy, notably Wilford Brimley's turn as Chance's Cajun uncle, Woo stages every fight with hypnotic grace.

title: Hard Target
review: Woo, a master of stylized violence and explosive action, has had to buy into America's fascination with explosive effects and reaction. Something gets lost in the transition.

title: Hard Target
review: Its characters are poorly-developed, the plot is the pinnacle of absurdity, and the acting, at best, is well over-the-top. Nevertheless, on the most basic, visceral level, the film succeeds.

title: Hard Target
review: Essentially, Hard Target is a risk-averse Van Damme vehicle, steered by many hands, and set on tracks leading directly to the delivery entrances of the country's video stores.

title: Up Close & Personal
