review: Three female friends grow up in a small town in Ireland in the mid-50s and attend college in Dublin in this nostalgic soap opera that's vaguely evocative of Peyton Place, though generally less memorable.

title: Circle of Friends
review: Old-fashioned and nostalgic, Pat O'Connor's nicely directed tale of friendship between three Irish girls features a strong central performance from Minnie Driver that promises a bright future in Hollywood pictures.

title: Circle of Friends
review: The fizzing dialogue gets all the little details right, but the plot's nothing new, and the lingering shots of hibernian greenery aim straight for mid-Atlantic bland-out.

title: Circle of Friends
review: Beyond eliciting warm, animated performances from his actors (with a cast that also includes Alan Cumming as a hair-raising suitor of Benny's), Mr. O'Connor gives Circle of Friends an enveloping look and sound.

title: Circle of Friends
review: Driver's tough core of honesty and wit is bewitching. So's the movie.

title: Circle of Friends
review: Young Benny has a nice smile, and she and Jack seem like pleasant people, but in the end (and in the beginning and in the middle) it's hard to get worked up about them.

title: Circle of Friends
review: It's not a challenging movie or an original one, but it does have its pleasures -- most notably a radiant, soulful debut performance from Driver.

title: Circle of Friends
review: Driver is impulsively sweet, touching and hilarious as she copes with her new, romantic life.

title: Circle of Friends
review: Heartwarming and poignant, a love story that glows with intelligence and feeling.

title: Circle of Friends
review: A lot of films, especially love stories, seek a level of comfort through predictability, but this one goes too far.

title: Circle of Friends
review: Like an old-fashioned theater program, it tells you early on who and what each of its characters is -- and so they prove to be, enjoyably.

title: Death and the Maiden
review: Polanski certainly gets the maximum voltage and precision out of his story and actors, keeping us preternaturally alert to shifting power relationships and delayed revelations.

title: Death and the Maiden
review: Kingsley shrewdly tantalizes the viewer about his identity, and gets to deliver the text's most riveting monologue at the end. The lesser-known Wilson may be the first among equals, impressing strongly as the equivocating husband.

title: Death and the Maiden
review: Polanski wisely never opens out the action from the remote clifftop house. In keeping things claustrophobic, close-up and ambivalent, he heightens the suspense (not to mention the sexual tension).

title: Death and the Maiden
review: Mr. Polanski treads lightly on the clumsier lines, and sustains tension by creating an elegant, unobtrusive dance with the camera.

title: Death and the Maiden
review: Death and the Maiden forces the audience to confront questions about torture and punishment.

title: Death and the Maiden
review: Polanski keeps the situation ambiguous to provoke questions of guilt and responsibility.

title: Death and the Maiden
review: Any degree of tension cultivated by Polanski is frequently undermined by Rafael Yglesias and Ariel Dorfman's sputtering script.

title: Death and the Maiden
review: Richer than its materials might promise.

title: Death and the Maiden
review: The Polanski touch -- apart from a little suspense here and there -- is limited.

title: Death and the Maiden
review: The fundamental strength of Weaver's personality doesn't work here. Nor does her particular style of rage and sorrow.

title: Dumb & Dumber
review: Dumb and Dumber, which features Carrey and Jeff Daniels as nitwits traveling cross-country, is a frayed string of gags posing as a movie. Carrey, though, does literal-minded doofdom with peerless enthusiasm.

title: Dumb & Dumber
review: The wholeheartedness of this descent into crude and rude humor is so good-natured and precise that it's hard not to partake in the guilty pleasures of the exercise.

title: Dumb & Dumber
review: This is a long way from the social comedy of Jerry Lewis. The characters here are ultimately turned into punching bags or punch-line dispensers.

title: Dumb & Dumber
review: Given American cinema's current obsession with innocence and ignorance, at least this never romanticises its protagonists. They are genuinely, irredeemably, 100 per cent no-hopers.

title: Dumb & Dumber
review: A movie that fully lives up to its name, right down to an opening credit sequence rife with intentional misspellings and grammatical errors.

title: Dumb & Dumber
review: An uneven collection of bodily function jokes, facial gyrations, sexual jibes and pedestrian slapstick.

title: Dumb & Dumber
review: An execrable catalogue of doody jokes, Dumb and Dumber is an abominable, abdominal comedy.

title: Dumb & Dumber
review: Inspired, irreverent, spark-driven comedy that takes you places you never thought a movie would go -- even a Jim Carrey movie.

title: Dumb & Dumber
review: Carrey, I am now convinced, is a true original. In The Mask, he had the screenplay and production to back him up. Here, the filmmaking is more uncertain.

title: Dumb & Dumber
review: While I won't claim to have gone through this entire film without laughing, there are some long periods between chuckles.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: Lee's Eat Drink Man Woman is tender without being mushy, sweet without being syrupy -- and surprising in ways that can only make you smile.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: But by the end, I felt that Lee had, so to speak, stuck a little too closely to the recipe: His movie is moderately enjoyable in a been-there, done-that sort of way.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: Eat Drink Man Woman may not just amuse and entertain you. It's likely to make you very hungry, too-perhaps for more than food.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: That guarantee of good taste is, finally, a bit of a downer; there are plenty of surprises, but no hint of risk.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: Mildly charming.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: Ambitious and entertaining.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: The food metaphor never carries weight, and the characterisations are too shallow to lend the film emotional punch.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: Wonderfully seductive, and nicely knowing about all of its characters' appetites.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: The movie's main appeal -- beyond stomach yearnings caused by its cuisine -- comes from the actors, who infuse their archetypal roles with comedic appeal.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: Eat Drink Man Woman is a delicacy but also something more -- something like food for the heart.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: Who said foreign films can't be fun?

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: A spicy, well-written comedy about family, food and independence.

title: Yin shi nan nu
review: The personalities in this well-drawn family combine to produce subtle new flavors -- and in the end, no one is spiced as you'd imagined they'd be.

title: Ed Wood
review: Beguiling rather than thrilling, oddly charming instead of transporting, meaning that Disney will have its work cut out for it with what is at heart a cult movie and a film buff's dream.

title: Ed Wood
review: It certainly succeeds as a funny, touching tribute to tenacity, energy, ambition and friendship.

title: Ed Wood
review: Mr. Depp isn't best known as a comic actor, but he gives a witty and captivating performance, bringing wonderful buoyancy to this crazy role.

title: Ed Wood
review: Outrageously disjointed and just as outrageously entertaining, the picture stands as a successful outsider's tribute to a failed kindred spirit.

title: Ed Wood
review: In his finest, funniest, most poignant film to date, Tim Burton plays cinematic alchemist, turning drive-in schlock into movie gold.

title: Ed Wood
review: This Ed Wood is dead wood.

title: Ed Wood
review: [An] oddly affectionate bio-pic.

title: Ed Wood
review: An entertaining, oddly affectionate look at the cross-dressing grade-Z moviemaker.

title: Ed Wood
review: The movie's black and white photography convincingly recaptures the look and feel of 1950s sleaze, including some of the least convincing special effects in movie history.

title: Ed Wood
review: Given the finished film, one also has to wonder if Ed Wood was interesting enough to base a two- hour movie on.

title: Ed Wood
review: Making a movie about the life of Ed Wood certainly qualifies as an impossible dream, but Burton has pulled it off with wit, imagination and something amazingly close to grace.

title: Ed Wood
review: Burton has evoked the surface of Ed Wood's life, but in a story about a man who loves angora and frilly panties, he has barely unbuttoned Wood's uniform.

title: French Kiss
review: The delicate air of romance that often makes this sort of film worthwhile is absent.

title: Forget Paris
review: Like the relationship it depicts, everything goes terribly slack in the middle.

title: Forget Paris
review: Mr. Crystal's style as a director is smoothe and bland.

title: Forget Paris
review: Since the stories are none too startling, it's hard to see why these otherwise bright people should be so enthusiastic about boring themselves.

title: Forget Paris
review: With its uneven tone, Forget Paris doesn't have enough comedy or heartfelt romance to eclipse its faults.

title: Forget Paris
review: It all works.

title: Forget Paris
review: This movie has such a naked desire to evoke the human condition, you want to throw a blanket over it.

title: Forget Paris
review: Shamelessly schmaltzy.

title: Forget Paris
review: In the marriage-go-round Forget Paris, Debra Winger falls for Billy Crystal because he makes her laugh. Likewise, you will forgive Forget its faults because it will make you chuckle. Hard. And often.

title: A Goofy Movie
review: Insipid songs and not much story.

title: A Goofy Movie
review: An incoherent mess that jumps from one unlikely, brainless, crash-bang situation to another.

title: Fluke
review: This strange family fare, about a dog that was once a man, tries unsuccessfully to combine the expected magic of animal adventures with some more serious ideas.

title: Fluke
review: As if banal platitudes about work-vs. -family aren't insufferable enough, there's a kicker gag involving Jackson that'll even have Mister Rogers begging for Pulp Fiction II.

title: Farinelli
review: Artistry abounds in every aspect of the film.

title: Farinelli
review: There's something too artificial and highfalutin about the movie.

title: Farinelli
review: A fascinating, if occasionally overly melodramatic, recreation of a period when Baroque music ruled Europe.

title: Farinelli
review: Because Carlo Broschi, the 18th-century castrato singer known as Farinelli, was himself such an exotic and sensationalistic figure, you'd think that creating a dull movie out of his flamboyant life would be next to impossible. Think again.

title: Farinelli
review: Glossy and histrionic, salacious and empty, Farinelli reduces a fascinating story to a series of hissy fits and leering glances.

title: Farinelli
review: Farinelli, one of the 1995 Oscar nominees in the foreign film category, is onto an interesting story, all right, but it leaves us feeling, like some of Farinelli's lovers, that something is missing.

title: Flash Gordon
review: The expensive new version of Flash Gordon is a lot more gaudy, and just as dumb, as the original series starring Buster Crabbe.

title: Flash Gordon
review: A respectable time-waster.

title: Flash Gordon
review: The narrative is a little plodding, but adult punters will soon slip back into areverie for the lost visions of Saturday morning cinema.

title: Flash Gordon
review: Is it fun? Yeah, sort of, it is.

title: The Glass Shield
review: Ambition is something to respect in an artist, but Charles Burnett's police-corruption drama The Glass Shield is such a maladroit piece of filmmaking that its weighty themes and sclerotic tangle of a plot end up making it a trial to sit through.

title: The Glass Shield
review: A powerful moral drama that tries to deal with the racism at the root of many problems in contempo American society.

title: The Glass Shield
review: The movie feels sketchy, as if Burnett chopped the flesh off his screenplay and left us only the bare bones.

title: The Glass Shield
review: It's a rigorous, angry piece of work, but it misses out on the psychological depths that have made Burnett's previous films among the glories of recent American independent moviemaking.

title: The Glass Shield
review: An implausible, wearisome clunker trying to ring true but making only dull thuds.

title: The Glass Shield
review: Burnett's screenplay has a tendency to be a little too preachy, especially during the unsatisfying final scene. There's a fine line between getting the message across through subtlety and becoming didactic...

title: The Glass Shield
review: It has both ideas and a point of view. But the ideas are far from new, and the point of view is blatantly knee-jerk.

title: The Glass Shield
review: Though no masterpiece, the film is an interesting sidebar for moviegoers who try to keep up; it's like a '50s film noir oddity you catch on 3 a.m. TV, only to find that it's become a more scintillating view than Ben-Hur.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: It's about three hours long. But it moves like Isiah, fast and smooth, and it's over in a heartbreak.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: Hoop Dreams has shown us that the rules of the game are stacked against kids like Gates and Agee. Even better, it shows us how they fight back, with the inside moves of hope.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: A heady dose of the American dream and the American nightmare combined -- a numbing investigation of how one point on an exam or one basket or turnover in a game can make all the difference in a family's fortunes.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: A prodigious achievement that conveys the fabric of modern American life, aspirations and incidentally, sports, in close-up and at length, Hoop Dreams is a documentary slam dunk.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: Unforgettable.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: An ironic drama so beautifully sculpted it could be transposed without alteration into a fictional film.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: The film's great achievement is to reveal the relentless way in which coaches and recruiters refuse to see Arthur and William as anything other than social cliches.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: Along the way it becomes a revealing and heartbreaking story about life in America.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: The most powerful movie about sports ever made.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: An extraordinarily affecting documentary.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: This picture has a legitimate dramatic structure that is equally as compelling as a scripted slice of fiction.

title: Hoop Dreams
review: A documentary that breathes new life into the subject by showing the everyday reality of that dream.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: Lynskey and Winslet are extraordinary actresses.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: Combines original vision, a drop-dead command of the medium and a successful marriage between a dazzling, kinetic techno-show and a complex, credible portrait of the out-of-control relationship between the crime's two schoolgirl perpetrators.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: Unlike the campy excess of Jackson's earlier Dead Alive, deliberate overkill ltimately points toward a dearth of ideas rather than a surfeit.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: Acted with conviction, and directed and written with febrile vibrancy.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: Stylish and eerily compelling before it overplays its campy excesses, Heavenly Creatures does have a feverish intensity to recommend it.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: 1994 spellbinder.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: Revealed in unforgettable fashion by a capable director, the events that unfold in this film are not easily forgotten.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: Jackson (who wrote the script with Frances Walsh) evokes the girlsa(TM) fantasy world with scenes featuring plasticene figures, creating an eerie, metaphysical dimension to the movie.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: Powerful, evocative movie.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: An unforgettable experience.

title: Heavenly Creatures
review: What makes Jackson's film enthralling and frightening is the way it shows these two unhappy girls, creating an alternative world so safe and attractive they thought it was worth killing for.

title: Houseguest
review: Turns out to be an inane fish-out-of-water comedy. Along the way it turns into a virtual McDonald's commercial, too. The fact that you can hardly tell the difference is a good clue to the movie's bad-television flavor.

title: Houseguest
review: As good-natured as its big, beefy star, comedian Sinbad.

title: Houseguest
review: In its worst moments, Houseguest becomes a struggle in which a very human comedian fights to project his personality over the director's technological muddle. But the good news is that Sinbad wins.

title: Houseguest
review: Plot-wise, there's little here beyond a few insubstantial strands.

title: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles
review: It's about seduction, and either you succumb to its inky entrapments or you resist. When its mojo was working, I was happy to be had.

title: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles
review: Why would Tom Cruise be playing Lestat, a gaunt, suave European vampire with a taste for young men? Because a big movie star can do whatever he wants.

title: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles
review: The leading performances, if acceptable, are not everything they needed to be to fully flesh out these elegant immortals.

review: The major problem lies with Rice's own script, which is dramatically repetitive and philosophically banal.

title: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles
review: Interview with the Vampire promises a constantly surprising vampire story, and it keeps that promise.

title: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles
review: For all its visionary brilliance, the movie version of Interview never lets us close enough to see ourselves in Louis. We're dazzled but unmoved.

title: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles
review: When Interview with the Vampire works, it's as compelling and engrossing a piece of entertainment as is available on film today. When it falters, the weaknesses seem magnified.

title: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles
review: My complaint about the film is that not very much happens, in the plot sense.

title: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles
review: Passionately anticipated and much ballyhooed, the film, alas, is little more than a foppish, fang de siecle costume drama. Its pulse barely registers.

title: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles
review: The movie's energy starts to drain like blood from a vampire's victim. You'll feel that ebb, sooner or later, as you begin to glance regularly at your watch.

title: Junior
review: A happy, healthy, bouncing baby of a movie.

title: Junior
review: The plot is a more fertile ground for comedy than the 'sperm milkshake' that made Schwarzenegger and Danny De Vito brothers in Reitman's Twins.

title: Junior
review: Junior demands more range from its leading man than he's capable of giving. The predictable result is a big-budget mess more likely to elicit groans than laughter.

title: Junior
review: A fleecy romantic caper with a dusting of feminism, the picture is basically a one-joke movie successfully nursed by director Ivan Reitman.

title: Junior
review: For the right audience, Junior may deliver. But there's a whole lot of pregnancy to go through first.

title: Junior
review: It's goofy and ridiculous and preposterous, and yet it makes you feel good, and there is something oddly heartwarming about the sight of this macho guy melting with feelings of protectiveness and maternal concern.

title: Junior
review: As a comedy, Junior has its share of laughs -- but no more than its share.

title: Just Cause
review: In Connery it has a hero who is inescapably appealing.

title: Just Cause

title: Just Cause
review: It doesn't bog down in the bogs, but it's slow-moving just about everyplace else.

title: Just Cause
review: There is no psychological depth, no real motivation, no human values to weigh, just characters jerked here and there like puppets in an arbitrary plot.

title: Just Cause
review: The longer you stay with it, the more routine and uninspired it seems -- not to mention cowardly.

title: Just Cause
review: It's brutal, horribly manipulative, and we've seen this stuff before in better pictures.

title: Just Cause
review: Despite its tendency to tread well-traveled roads, Just Cause is filmed with enough energy and craft that, for the majority of its one-hundred minute running time, it's reasonably entertaining.

title: A Kid in King Arthur's Court
review: Sitting through it, I found myself shuddering at what Disney may have in store for next summer.

title: A Kid in King Arthur's Court
review: It is numbingly bland, homogenized and deflated by an utter lack of original wit or charm. Worst of all, it is subtly but conspicuously condescending to its target audience.

title: A Kid in King Arthur's Court
review: It's a missed opportunity for introducing the Mortal Kombat generation to medieval combat that was really mortal.

title: A Kid in King Arthur's Court

title: A Kid in King Arthur's Court
review: Sluggish and low-energy.

title: A Kid in King Arthur's Court
review: This lively time-travel fantasy is the clear result of imagination and reflection on the part of writers Michael Part and Robert L. Levy and director Michael Gottlieb and their colleagues, who possess a crucial light touch.

title: A Kid in King Arthur's Court
review: There's nothing particularly wrong with A Kid in King Arthur's Court and nothing right with it, either.

title: A Kid in King Arthur's Court
review: Because of the square, lackluster way that director Michael Gottleib has staged his material, the whole production seems sort of limp and perfunctory.

title: Kiss of Death
review: What's most effective about the new Kiss of Death is Tucci's marvelously slimy prosecutor.

title: Kiss of Death
review: A crackling thriller that feels unusually attuned to its lowlife characters.

title: Kiss of Death
review: Cage and Caruso strike sparks in this riveting piece of pulp fiction, but it's that first Kiss you'll remember.

title: Kiss of Death
review: It's a sleek, muscular thriller played by a terrific ensemble cast...

title: Kiss of Death
review: A riveting crime drama.

title: Kiss of Death
review: Cage, one of the few American actors who gets more interesting from film to film, comes close to kidnaping the picture as Little Junior, a pumped-up but asthmatic thug who, like King Kong, is a gorilla with a wistful air about him.

title: Kiss of Death
review: It shouldn't be disjointed and uncompelling, but it is.

title: Kiss of Death
review: Caruso's acting is vivid, but amazingly quiet and internal, and it's fascinating to watch the kaleidoscopically conflicted emotions battle beneath his controlled surface.

title: Kiss of Death
review: Cage dominates the camera, stealing scenes by the sheer intensity of his inimitable strangeness.

title: Kiss of Death
review: The picture is watchable, but nothing about it will linger, except perhaps the feeling that, with a more polished script, it might have been significantly better.

title: Kiss of Death
review: If you savor movies about sleazy plea bargains and other lawyer hardballing, Death has its moments. Otherwise the latest from director Barbet Schroeder is only a movie of moments.

title: Star Wars
review: What places it a sizable cut about the routine is its spectacular visual effects, the best since Stanley Kubrick's 2001.

title: Star Wars
review: There's no breather in the picture, no lyricism; the only attempt at beauty is in the double sunset.

title: Star Wars
review: George Lucas, who made American Graffiti, has put together a sci-fi film that draws on any number of associations. Star Wars is both amazing and familiar.

title: Star Wars
review: A grand and glorious film that may well be the smash hit of 1977, and certainly is the best movie of the year so far.

title: Star Wars

title: Star Wars
review: Has distinct limitations, but the current return to a cinema of spectacle and wonder is wholly encouraging.

title: Star Wars
review: It is, all in all, hard to think of a place or an age group that would not respond to the enthusiastic inventiveness with which Lucas has enshrined his early loves.

title: Star Wars
review: Lucas fills his screen with loving touches.

title: Star Wars
review: Compelling backstory, exciting action and pleasantly archetypal characters.

review: A dynamic entertainment, efficiently and exuberantly setting up its mythic tale of heroes and villains, rebels and rogues, princesses and monsters, good and evil.

title: Star Wars
review: A pop-culture landmark!

title: Star Wars
review: A grandiose and violent epic with a simple and whimsical heart.

review: Like some indefatigable King of the Hill, it stands alone and triumphant, regardless of the many imitators that assail its position.

title: Star Wars
review: It's fun and funny.

review: Twenty years later, George Lucas' loved saga of the war between good and evil in a distant galaxy returns in digitally enhanced and augmented form.

review: His work here seems less inventive than in THX 1138.

review: Darth Vader and his James Earl Jones voice is a bad egg no matter how much we know about his screwy upbringing.

review: Backgrounds in some sequences are now more populated than they were, and it's fun to see all the creatures that make up the "wretched hive of scum and villainy" that Alec Guinness' Obi-Wan Kenobi describes.

review: George Lucas has made the kind of sci-fi adventure movie you dream about finding!

title: A Little Princess

review: An exemplary version of Frances Hodgson Burnett's novel.

review: A bright, beautiful and enchantingly childlike vision.

review: Cuaron's version of magic realism consists of seeing incredibly fanciful sets and situations in precise detail.

review: The 1939 Shirley Temple version of this book came closer to capturing Sara's vitality.

title: A Little Princess
review: It's not only suitable for consumption by those over age 10, it's actually enjoyable.

review: A Little Princess exquisitely re-creates the ephemeral world of childhood, an enchanted kingdom where everything, even make-believe, seems possible.

title: A Little Princess
review: There are moments in A Little Princess when you may just want to clap from pleasure.

title: Losing Isaiah

review: This is an absorbing and involving picture, but the terms propounded here limit the story, which depends almost entirely on emotions rather than on thought.

review: Not only does this lowest-common denominator conclusion backfire, it insults anyone who invested their time getting involved in the whole thing.

review: While the subject may be controversial enough to merit an Oprah free-for-all, this evenhanded melodrama is neutral to a fault.

review: The movie, directed by Stephen Gyllenhaal and written by Naomi Foner, deals with all of those issues, but in a finally unsatisfactory way.

title: Losing Isaiah
review: Thought-provoking and dramatically-solid.

title: The Madness of King George
review: Hytner's version of Bennett's comic-tragic drama of the tormented king who almost lost his mind confirms that power games, family scandals, and personal intrigues have always been integral to the British Crown, an institution both revered and reviled.

review: In its own shambling, elliptical way it's an entertaining, memorable movie whose 2 1/2 hours go by without strain.

review: Hawthorne is by turn outrageous and pathetic and imperious and poignant and very funny.

title: The Madness of King George
review: The thrill of Hawthorne's astounding performance is not something you want to miss.

review: For those who, like myself, were disappointed in the play, the film contains pleasant surprises, all of them resulting from differences between the two arts.

title: The Madness of King George
review: Without exception, the acting is top-notch.

review: Somehow ... this frail figure [George] is an immensely likable -- and, at times, deeply moving -- character.

review: The battle of wills between these two strong men [George and Willis] is the centerpiece of the movie, and hugely entertaining.

review: [Hawthorne] turns what would surely be an unsympathetic role in lesser hands into something poetic -- and hysterical.

review: [Whale] did it in the Grand Guignol manner, with as many queer sounds, dark corners, false faces and cellar stairs as could possibly be inserted.

review: Maximum of stimulating shock is there, but the thing is handled with subtle change of pace and shift of tempo that keeps attention absorbed to a high voltage climax.

review: This makes an even worse job of its premise than you might expect, leaving it to the usual sidekick, Cedric the Entertainer, to provide the occasional laugh as a convict-turned-holy man.

title: Man of the House
review: Dull comedy.

review: A juggernaut of exaggeration, momentum and thrills.

review: A Perfect Getaway is a clever, heart-pounding thriller, and a welcome return to form for the director.

title: A Perfect Getaway

review: It probably sounded terrific in the pitch meeting.

title: What's Love Got to Do with It

review: Angela Bassett shakes her tail feather with aplomb and pins down the singer's gestures with amazing precision. Top honours, however, belong to Fishburne's swaggering, savage portrayal of Ike.

title: What's Love Got to Do with It
review: A handsome woman with the lanky appeal of Katharine Hepburn, Bassett brays and bruises with equal effectiveness.

review: This is as close as any of us is likely to get to witnessing life in prehistoric times.

review: The film is not as amusing as the premise, and there were long stretches when I'd had quite enough of Mrs. Doubtfire.

review: The 3-D pops out to enhance the drama or energy of scenes in which settings are large and integral to the action.

review: Its animators' pens are wands; their movement enchants.

review: A uniquely elegant and entertaining mix of hand-drawn classicism and high-tech innovation.

review: There's still room in this world for innocent love stories -- and tales as old as time.

review: A sporadically brilliant escape that at times stops to preen and pose, like that he-man lout Gaston.

title: The Wild Bunch

title: The Wild Bunch

title: The Wild Bunch
review: It's a towering achievement that grows more riveting and resonant with the years.

review: Not only does The Wild Bunch illustrate Peckinpah's mastery of his medium, but it presents a story that is effective on nearly every level.

title: Fargo
review: A small, supremely satisfying film. Heck and you betcha, it is.

review: A few scenes go around in circles, as if snow-blind, and the humor may be too inward and contorted for some tastes. But McDormand brings order to the weirdness and warms it up.

review: Uniquely fascinating.

review: Whether these characters are lovable or detestable, they're lovable or detestable in a TV way -- defined by a minimal set of traits that are endlessly reiterated and incapable of expansion or alteration, a fixed loop.

review: Like every other critic I'm aware of, I loved this movie.

review: Mr. Lee isn't as successful at shaping a story around Girl 6, but enjoying her company is all his slender, sunny film really tries to do.

review: The French idea of a 'family film' is a bit kinkier than what we're accustomed to.

review: These are two great actors giving top-notch performances, and the restrained romance they project is fascinating.

title: The Craft

title: The Craft
review: If only The Craft were as fresh as its enchanting lead quartet.

title: Cold Comfort Farm

title: Cold Comfort Farm
review: Dickens meets the Beverly Hillbillies.

title: Heaven's Prisoners
review: [A] bayou slog.

title: The Rock
review: The yarn has its share of gaping holes and jaw-dropping improbabilities, but director Michael Bay sweeps them all aside with his never-take-a-breath pacing.

title: The Rock
review: Slick, brutal and almost human, this is the team-spirit action movie Mission: Impossible should have been.

title: The Rock
review: Fake countdown and knowing reactionary tone, but the best SF car chase to date.

review: A violence-intoxicated, far-fetched, morally corrupt drama.

title: The Rock
review: From a helicopter's point-of-view, The Rock is just typical big American dumb fun. It's only when you look underneath at the film's underlying assumptions that you want to recoil.

title: The Rock
review: A popcorn-movie deluxe.

title: The Rock

title: The Rock
review: Producers Jerry Bruckheimer and the late Don Simpson have a highly-successful resume that includes Top Gun and Crimson Tide. The Rock will add more luster to that reputation.

title: The Rock
review: The movie deteriorates into a long commercial for the home-game version of itself.

title: The Rock
review: When film more or less took over melodrama from the theater ninety years ago, it proudly provided real oceans instead of canvas waves rippled by stagehands; but the plots remained humbug ... The Rock is as ridiculous an example as one could want.

title: The Rock
review: Pure why-not bravado, pumped-up and staggeringly dishonest but exciting just the same.

title: The Rock
review: Excitement may be The Rock's selling point, but it has plenty more to offer than you bargained for.

title: The Rock
review: Cage steals the show, adding a touch of wimpiness to the high-decibel bravado.

title: The Rock
review: [A] 2 1/4-hour exercise in overkill.

title: The Rock
review: A first-rate, slam-bang action thriller with a lot of style and no little humor.

title: The Rock
review: Even in a movie that's all noise and bluster, Cage and Connery inject tasty bits of personality into their roles.

review: ...a distasteful affair that should embarrass all concerned...

title: Twister
review: You know a movie is in trouble when a cow provides its only moment of authentic human interest.

title: Twister
review: Even more than with most of Michael Crichton's concoctions, this one conveys the overwhelming impression of a mechanical entertainment, a very high concept in which the characters and their problems seem like utterly arbitrary creations.

title: Twister
review: Effects apart, this is dire: predictable, cliched, sloppily written, pitifully performed and surprisingly short of real shocks and suspense.

title: Twister
review: It looks real, and Director Jan De Bont keeps the action coming so fast there's no time to question it.

title: Twister
review: An expert in making audiences squirm and twist, at making us feel the rush of experience right along with the actors, De Bont choreographs action and suspense so beautifully he makes it seem like a snap.

title: Twister
review: A summer crowd-pleaser worthy of its wind.

title: Twister
review: The movie is wall-to-wall with special effects, and they're all convincing, although it's impossible for me to explain how Bill and Jo escape serious injury while staring right up into the Suck Zone of the Finger of God.

title: Twister
review: It's a perfect motion picture roller coaster -- fun, fast, and furious... as long as you don't think too hard.

title: Twister
review: Science aside, it's not hard to feel that these excitable characters are a wee bit berserk. But the movie works as escapism even if you do know enough to come in out of the rain.

title: Spy Hard
review: The jokes come in sporadic volleys rather than the steady machine-gun pace of The Naked Gun and Airplane!, and, with a few exceptions, they are less truly aimed.

title: Spy Hard
review: As funny as Nielsen can be, like all comic actors he still needs the quick-thinking jokes and zingy one-liners to be genuinely funny.

title: Spy Hard
review: Spy Hard just comes off as a long commercial. And yes, that means most of the best moments you've seen in the movie's trailer.

title: Spy Hard
review: More of a cinematic joke book than a real movie, Spy Hard hits you with gags faster than Henny Youngman on speed. Even when individual bits misfire, the unrelenting barrage of silliness can break down your resistance.

title: Spy Hard
review: Spy Hard is a loose send-up of the Bond series and other overly expensive action flicks, but after Hot Shots! Part Deux and National Lampoon's Loaded Weapon 1 who needs another action parody?

title: Spy Hard
review: Never mind that the smutty, high-tech 007 capers already wink at the conventions of the bikini-clad, gizmo-strewn genre. If the martini is shaken, not stirred, why beat it to death with a swizzle stick?

title: Spy Hard
review: The picture that will test the durability of Leslie Nielsen's lowbrow franchise, Spy Hard sticks closely to the Naked Gun formula. Not only is the formula itself wearing thin, but the gags themselves feel recycled.

title: Spy Hard
review: Like Hot Shots! there's the same mistaken belief that simply tagging other films will be intrinsically funny...

title: Spy Hard
review: Nielsen, with his expert deadpan and sense of comic timing, creates the illusion of humor -- for about 15 minutes.

title: Spy Hard
review: This movie unfortunately wastes a perfectly promising idea -- satirizing James Bond films along with any other pop-culture celluloid phenomenon that crosses the filmmakers' minds.

title: Spy Hard
review: A dreadfully unfunny comedy that takes Naked Gun-like sketches and rehashes them without a whit of style or energy.

title: Spy Hard
review: When Spy Hard abruptly ends after only 81 minutes, you sense that it has used up every last round of available ammunition. It was simply exhausted and couldn't move another inch.

title: Spy Hard
review: You won't laugh hard at Spy Hard. And that's not because the jokes aren't funny. Most of them aren't even jokes.

title: Force of Evil
review: For all its unpleasant nature, it must be said that this film is a dynamic crime-and-punishment drama, brilliantly and broadly realized.

title: Force of Evil

title: The Arrival

title: The Arrival
review: It's a strong, lean piece of writing that moves quickly. Nothing is wasted, and nothing happens the way you'd expect.

title: The Arrival

title: The Arrival
review: The movie is as smart as ``Mission: Impossible'' is dumb.

title: The Arrival
review: This is not a dumb movie; in fact, with its heavy reliance upon real science, it's startlingly credible.

title: The Arrival
review: [Sheen] spends most of the movie in a kind of sweaty apoplexy that makes one worry for his health.

title: Careful

title: Careful
review: Uniquely weird, subtly macabre, and utterly compelling.

title: Careful
review: There's something wonderfully unique about the project but the reasons for doing it remain buried.

title: Careful
review: Careful, the hilariously bizarre new film from Canadian director Guy Maddin, is like some lost masterpiece from a time-warped alternative dimension -- a strange artifact that time forgot.

title: A Month by the Lake
review: Vanessa Redgrave has never been more likable on screen than in her buoyantly athletic turn here.

title: Gold Diggers: The Secret of Bear Mountain
review: Dig if you must, but this is fool's gold.

title: Maya Lin: A Strong Clear Vision
review: No masterpiece, but a portrait worthy of the extraordinary woman it salutes.

title: Striptease
review: Moore's body is in better shape than her acting.

title: This Is Spinal Tap
review: For music biz insiders, This Is Spinal Tap is a vastly amusing satire of heavy metal bands.

title: This Is Spinal Tap
review: For all its japes and jokes, the movie is really about exhaustion of the spirit: sitting in a bleak hotel suite at 4 a.m. with the bad taste of last night in the mouth and the feeling that tomorrow will not be a better day.

title: This Is Spinal Tap
review: The material is consistently clever and funny, though ultimately the attitudes are too narrow to nourish a feature-length film.

title: This Is Spinal Tap
review: Reiner's brilliantly inventive script and smart visuals avoid all the obvious pitfalls, making this one of the funniest ever films about the music business.

title: This Is Spinal Tap
review: It stays so wickedly close to the subject that it is very nearly indistinguishable from the real thing.

title: This Is Spinal Tap
review: The film is a composite of classic moments, all of which we sense could have happened to any of the classic heavy metal bands -- or at least to those whose members combined delusions of greatness with low I.Q.s.

title: This Is Spinal Tap
review: This Is Spinal Tap doesn't pull punches...

title: This Is Spinal Tap
review: The satire has a deft, wicked touch.

title: Jack
review: Someone deserves a timeout for letting this mawkish misfire get to the screen.

title: I Shot Andy Warhol

title: La môme
review: The Israeli documentary Stalags, by Ari Libsker, should be subtitled, How To Turn a Sexy Subject Into a Boring Film.

title: La môme
review: Stalags carries this line of inquiry forward, cramming an overwhelming amount of information and ideas into its 63 minutes -- not nearly enough time to explore satisfactorily all that it raises.

title: La môme
review: Unfortunately, Ari Libsker's hour-plus docu on this potentially mind-boggling topic meanders disconnectedly, as various experts, collectors and storytellers kick around anecdotes and theories that tend to cancel each other out.

title: La môme
review: However artless its presentation, Stalags imparts material that's difficult to shake off and impossible to dismiss.

title: Histoires extraordinaires

review: [Toby Dammit] is marvelous: a short movie but a major one. The Vadim is as overdecorated and shrill as a drag ball, but still quite fun, and the Malle, based on one of Poe's best stories, is simply tedious.

title: Trainspotting
review: Trainspotting's saving grace is that there's a heck of a lot of entertainment value in this particular form of shallowness.

title: Trainspotting
review: Trainspotting, buoyed by a great Brit Pop soundtrack and Brian Tufano's agile cinematography, captures the stoned-out, gut-churning experience of hardcore addiction with hallucinogenic acuity.

title: Trainspotting
review: Trainspotting is a searing pop-art portrait of a lost generation blowing out its brains. As they rail, chuckle, shout and dive into darkness, you're trapped yourself between a bellylaugh and a scream.

title: Trainspotting
review: The film is about joy -- in conniving and surviving, in connecting with audiences, in its own fizzy, jizzy style. And that's why, compared with it, most other films look zombified.

title: Trainspotting
review: A cocktail of scuzzy charm, nerve and despair that seduces and repulses in nearly equal proportions. It packs a jolt, all right. But it leaves you with a brutal hangover, too.

title: Trainspotting
review: It would be hard to imagine a movie about drugs, depravity, and all-around bad behavior more electrifying than Trainspotting.

title: Trainspotting
review: Scabrous, brutal and hip, Trainspotting is a Clockwork Orange for the '90s.

title: Trainspotting
review: This may not have the weight of 'Great Art', but it crystallises youthful disaffection with the verve of the best and brightest pop culture. A sensation.

title: Trainspotting
review: The experience of watching Trainspotting -- the electric, nasty and slick descent into the milieu of young Scottish junkies -- is a little like speeding through the digestive tract of some voracious beast.

title: Trainspotting
review: Trainspotting is a singular sensation, a visionary knockout spiked with insight, wild invention and outrageous wit.

title: Trainspotting
review: Exuberant and pitiless, profane yet eloquent, flush with the ability to create laughter out of unspeakable situations, "Trainspotting" is a drop-dead look at a dead-end lifestyle that has all the strength of its considerable contradictions.

title: Trainspotting
review: Far from nihilistic, though certainly calculated to butt up against various puritanical norms, [the film is a] feel-good jaunt about young Scottish heroin addicts and their degradation and betrayals of one another.

title: Trainspotting
review: This isn't an examination of the Scottish drug culture from the outside looking in, it's one from the inside looking out.

title: Trainspotting
review: Hip, brutally honest and humane...

title: Trainspotting
review: The movie has been attacked as pro-drug and defended as anti-drug, but actually it is simply pragmatic. It knows that addiction leads to an unmanageable, exhausting, intensely uncomfortable daily routine, and it knows that only two things make it bearable

title: Trainspotting
review: For better or worse, sometimes strictly for the sake of shock value, the stylish irreverence of "Trainspotting" mimics that drug high and delivers its own potent kick.

title: Trainspotting
review: This is not dour social realism. It's a shot- from-a-cannon youth movie, with likable young people sticking needles in their arms in working-class Edinburgh.

title: Trainspotting
review: ...rapid-fire youth-culture freak show: random sex, in-your-face scatology, senseless violence and rampant profanity delivered in haggis-thick brogues.

title: Trainspotting
review: A few patches are subtitled, but the general effect is of watching an opera without having read the libretto.

title: 'Til There Was You

title: 'Til There Was You
review: A tired piece of romantic cornball fare that harks back to a bygone era, the film is a badly conceived, poorly executed fairy tale guaranteed to make audiences squirm in their seats.

title: 'Til There Was You
review: Tripplehorn and McDermott are likable enough in their roles, but Holzman's precious, overwritten script gives them few genuinely honest moments.

title: 'Til There Was You
review: Here is the most tiresome and affected movie in many a moon, a 114-minute demonstration of the Idiot Plot, in which everything could be solved with a few well-chosen words that are never spoken.

title: 'Til There Was You
review: A fragmentary and amateurish fairy tale.

title: 'Til There Was You
review: Tripplehorn and McDermott don't look as if they belong together and aren't strong enough actors to overcome their physical incompatibility. So there's no sense of urgency about them getting together.

title: 'Til There Was You
review: The payoff, such as it is, is distressingly anticlimactic, and results in frustration.

title: 'Til There Was You
review: Winnie Holzman's screenplay is uneven.

title: 'Til There Was You
review: The studio left this alleged romantic comedy sitting on the shelf for a year -- and it didn't improve with age.

title: Independence Day
review: Splendidly cheesy entertainment.

title: Independence Day
review: It's the first futuristic disaster movie that's as cute as a button. Which, when all the special effects blow over, is what we Americans like in a monster hit.

title: Independence Day
review: If I were a 10-year-old boy, I'd probably think it was the coolest movie going.

title: Independence Day
review: As unavoidably entertaining as it is hopelessly cornball.

title: Independence Day
review: Maybe the moviemakers' mission was to boldly go where everyone in Hollywood has gone before: the bank.

title: Independence Day
review: The earnestness, the effects, and the notion of a whole world forgetting its differences to defeat a common foe carry a certain charm.

title: Independence Day
review: Everything feels anti-climactic after the fireworks, but the moral is clear: it's the end of the world as we know it. And we feel fine.

title: Independence Day
review: The picture is ultimately fun, thanks mostly to the colorful characters and the mock-hero ic spirit that kicks in full-throttle after the world has almost been destroyed.

title: Independence Day
review: So much about ID4 is so old it's inevitable that homesick audiences, eager for familiar scenarios, will embrace it as if it's nothing but new.

title: Independence Day
review: The film has a genial it's-only-a-movie attitude that sets it apart, quite emphatically, from other blockbuster action movies.

title: Independence Day
review: As for the human characters, they give merely adequate back-seat support to the special effects that drive this big-budget thriller.

title: Independence Day
review: Unfortunately, and perhaps not unexpectedly, it doesn't live up to the hype.

title: Independence Day
review: There's precious little reward in plumbing the world-historical implications of the screenplay.

title: Independence Day
review: The aliens, when we finally see them, are a serious disappointment; couldn't they think of anything more interesting than octopus men?

title: Independence Day
review: Though the movie isn't too deep, it's certainly a rousing state-of-the-art cartoon capped by an aerial-combat climax that, to its credit, isn't anti-climactic.

title: Independence Day
review: You know going in that Independence Day will have terrific effects and loads of action. But the filmmakers have also carefully crafted appealing characters and several good relationships, which they develop as the story unfolds.

review: [A] hilariously inscrutable exercise in pseudo-profundity.

review: A civilized, mellow, and generally graceful chamber piece.

title: Stealing Beauty
review: A welcome reminder of Bertolucci's directorial assurance.

review: [Bertolucci] builds an homage to beauty around a sullen void.

review: In contrasting the sexuality and rebellion of Lucy's generation with his own, Bertolucci clearly yearns to rekindle his creative spirit.

title: Stealing Beauty
review: Even a lesser Bertolucci is an event, and Stealing Beauty has its charms.

title: Stealing Beauty
review: The movie plays like the kind of line a rich older guy would lay on a teenage model, suppressing his own intelligence and irony in order to spread out before her the wonderful world he would like to give her as a gift.

title: Stealing Beauty
review: It may not be epic in scale; in artistic terms, though, it's huge.

title: Stealing Beauty
review: What do you call a character study with shallow, sketchily-drawn characters, but a gorgeous setting? A scenery study, perhaps. Or an atmosphere study.

review: For all the film's missteps, there is cause to echo the uncritical compliment bestowed by the playwright (Jeremy Irons) upon the film's ingenue (Liv Tyler): 'I so enjoyed watching you.'

title: Eraser
review: Welcome back, big guy.

review: The advanced weaponry and nifty scopes notwithstanding, most of the gunplay is pretty standard-issue, with most of the victims being anonymous targets present just to be picked off.

review: It's a movie constructed around three or four self-consciously 'cool' episodes, and passably entertaining as such, but there's also an awful lot of uncool contrivance, coincidence and contempt for the audience.

title: Eraser
review: This is one of those movies where good guys don't miss, and bad guys can't shoot to save their lives.

title: Eraser
review: The bang-for-the-buck ratio is high enough to appease even the thinnest wallet.

title: Eraser
review: Arnold Schwarzenegger tries his hardest to look formidable, forbidding and stern in Eraser, but what he mostly looks is tired.

title: Eraser
review: The middling result, diverting while it lasts but too silly to recommend, is merely this week's funhouse action pic.

title: Eraser
review: Even for escapism, this is on the crazy side.

title: Eraser
review: Good action fun, with spectacular stunts and special effects.

title: Eraser
review: The premise is moderately intriguing.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: [Murphy] is able to invest his Professor Klump with an endearing dignity, give his lounge lizard alter ego, Buddy Love, an alligator's bite and then go on from there to play Klump's grandma. Also his mother, father and brother.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: Murphy's most assured work in some time.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: This is good, seamless comedy.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: This is a chance to see Murphy doing what he does best, and for that alone it's worth seeing.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: The flick is sketch comedy spun out to feature length.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: Eddie Murphy is funny again. Sadly, he lacks the guts to follow through on the cathartic self-satire that gives the film its distinction.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: Messy, raucous, crude and undisciplined though this remake of the 1963 Jerry Lewis vehicle is, it also creates more laughter (and poignancy) than any Eddie Murphy movie has in quite some time.

review: Murphy proves himself a surprisingly strong actor here, playing Sherman with sweetness and poignancy, not to mention loads of funny weight-related humor.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: This movie is a little too interested in easy jokes to bother with having a heart.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: The movie succeeds in two different ways: It's sweet and good-hearted, and then again it's raucous slapstick and bathroom humor.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: At long last again, an Eddie Murphy movie has its plug in the socket.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: Murphy outdoes himself by bringing pathos as well as sweetness to the character, arguably making him a viable update of Lewis's bucktoothed Julius Kelp.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: An uneven but hilarious remake.

title: The Nutty Professor
review: The Nutty Professor isn't much of a movie, but it's certainly a prime showcase for Eddie Murphy's enormous talent.

title: The Frighteners

title: The Frighteners
review: A mess with sporadic flashes of creativity.

title: The Frighteners
review: The Frighteners is ... that rare horror film that actually gets better as it proceeds; this scare machine has a heart and a brain.

title: Harriet the Spy

review: There's dancing, and bubble blowing and bed bouncing that's entirely aimless and Harriet's neighborhood sleuthing becomes particularly pointless.

review: The film's OK, a little thick with sensory overload, but it wasn't made for old guys like me.

title: Harriet the Spy
review: ...a tedious adaptation...

review: As the film progresses, the story becomes engaging.

title: Harriet the Spy

review: ...the pacing is slow and there are scenes that seem amateurish...

title: Harriet the Spy
review: Fresh and charming, it never plays down to kids.

review: Comes perilously close to becoming a gab-fest treadmill.

title: She's the One
review: Burns manages to take on a laundry list of touchy issues in a relatively frank, unflinching manner. His characters retain their dignity and integrity without false dramatic redemption. It's a true adult saga.

title: She's the One
review: A bland, so-so romantic comedy without the charm to see it through.

title: She's the One
review: She's the One isn't slick, smooth or particularly good, and it offers only a perfunctory exploration of the human heart.

title: She's the One
review: Edward Burns returns to the themes of family and love that he examined in The Brothers McMullen.

title: She's the One
review: Sadly, the 28-year-old Irish auteur from New York lost his footing while stepping up the Hollywood food chain. Slickness set in.

title: She's the One
review: A funnier, more polished variation on actor/director Ed Burns' The Brothers McMullen.

title: She's the One
review: Burns emphatically avoids sophomore slump with an inviting, ruefully funny film that lives up to his initial promise.

title: She's the One
review: Although the movie disappointed me, it did not dishearten me about Edwards Burns as an actor or filmmaker.

title: She's the One
review: The sophomore jinx, the bane of hot, young film makers, has struck again.

title: She's the One
review: A quality, offbeat movie.

title: She's the One
review: Light but hilarious...

title: A Time to Kill
review: A likable -- maybe even lovable -- movie.

title: A Time to Kill
review: Although it has its share of implausibilities, A Time To Kill is generally the most satisfying of the John Grisham screen adaptations to date.

review: Justice may be blind, but rarely have courtroom dramas presumed quite so heavily on cultural myopia as this heinous version of John Grisham's first novel.

title: A Time to Kill
review: If the film doesn't add up to a cogent legal argument, neither does it have trouble delivering 2 hours and 20 minutes' worth of sturdy, highly charged drama.

title: A Time to Kill
review: Untrained as an actor, with only three minor roles to his credit, McConaughey holds the screen against Samuel L. Jackson, Sandra Bullock and Kevin Spacey, and completely justifies the buzz surrounding his role...

title: A Time to Kill
review: McConaughey, 26, is dynamite in a performance of smarts, sexiness, scrappy humor and unmistakable star sizzle.

title: A Time to Kill
review: A skillfully constructed morality play that pushes all the right buttons and arrives at all the right conclusions.

review: Like many artists today, Grisham and Schumacher exploit racial tension without understanding it.

title: A Time to Kill
review: Despite certain drawbacks, A Time to Kill is involving, energetic, and occasionally thought-provoking. All things considered, this film will make for a worthwhile trip to the cinema for all, not just those who have time to kill.

title: A Time to Kill
review: A handsome but riotously cluttered melodrama with maybe 145 subplots.

title: Les rendez-vous de Paris

title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade

review: What was conceived as a child's dream of a Saturday matinee serial has evolved into a moving excursion into religious myth.

title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade
review: The fast pace and force-fed wisecracks are as seamless as ever, but rarely has audience laughter sounded as hollow.

title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade

title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade
review: Of the three Jones films, The Last Crusade may well become the sentimental favorite, the Indiana to end them all.

title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade
review: You want Adventure? Thrills? How about Rats?

title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade
review: The final section, in which Indy must claim the Grail and save his father's life, is imbued with a turgid, pop-mystical tone.

title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade
review: As I watched it, I felt a real delight, because recent Hollywood escapist movies have become too jaded and cynical, and they have lost the feeling that you can stumble over astounding adventures just by going on a hike with your Scout troop.

title: Shall We Dance

title: Shall We Dance

title: Shall We Dance

title: Shall We Dance
review: Occasionally charming but ultimately forgettable bit of fox-trot fluff.

title: Shall We Dance
review: Takes a small, exquisite Japanese movie and turns it into a big, stupid American movie. Still, it must be said that as glossy and overproduced as the thing is, it's a good Big Stupid American movie.

title: Shall We Dance
review: Turns a sweet, lilting story into a clunky, cliched and tedious movie sitcom.

title: Shall We Dance
review: The original remains the standard, and it's a far deeper work, but this paint-by-numbers project manages to get by on its good humour and undeniably entertaining ensemble cast.

title: Shall We Dance
review: This mildly entertaining bauble will disappear from your memory even before you've dislodged the last popcorn husks from your back teeth.

title: Shall We Dance
review: Where the original soared, the new version hugs the ground. It's like the difference between Fred Astaire's dancing and Richard Gere's.

title: Shall We Dance

title: Shall We Dance
review: The central idea -- that losing yourself in a small, private world can help you to better engage the larger world -- isn't lost in translation.

title: Shall We Dance
review: A pleasant, uncomplicated, adult night out -- an event nearly as rare as a new romantic Hollywood musical.

title: Shall We Dance
review: There isn't even any exciting dancing here, and what hoofing there is has been heavily edited, usually with the dancers' feet cropped off.

title: Shall We Dance
review: A comedy with two left feet.

title: Shall We Dance
review: A sleek Hollywood crowd-pleaser, more movie than art film, but its makers have wisely stuck not only to the spirit but often even to the letter of the original.

review: A funny, well-acted adult tale about the difficulty of holding onto happiness.

title: Shall We Dance
review: Sayonara sushi, hello turkey.

review: Invigorating, hopeful, funny and perfectly consciously corny at times.

review: Waltzes us into a world where interesting emotional realities give way to stock responses.

review: While the film remains a respectable thriller, only Ryan's crafty, quietly deranged performance lifts it out of the ordinary.

title: Crossfire
review: A thematically articulate film.

title: Macao

review: Is it the finest, smartest, most visually savvy horror film ever made by a big studio?

review: Sends some formidable chills down the spine.

title: Sleeper

title: Sleeper
review: Sleeper is terrific.

title: Bananas

review: Wonderfully incoherent.

title: Bananas
review: Allen's view of the world is fraught with everything except pathos, and it's a view I happen to find very funny.

title: A Fish Called Wanda

review: Somehow, the movie manages to do the impossible: It makes John Cleese less than hilarious.

title: A Fish Called Wanda
review: The movie's basic joke holds that the overbearing, unselfconscious Americans will do anything and say anything (and usually as loudly as possible), while the timorous British are nearly too polite to breathe.

review: Wanda defies gravity, in both senses of the word, and redefines a great comic tradition.

review: Like many of the best English comedies, much of the humor here is based on character, good-natured high spirits, and fairly uninhibited vulgarity.

title: A Fish Called Wanda
review: Though it is less tasteless, irreverent and satirical than the Python pics, film still is wacky and occasionally outrageous in its own, distinctly British way.

review: There's nothing deep, nothing ground-breaking, but it's a never-dull, tightly scripted yarn with some very funny gags.

review: It's not easy to describe the movie's accumulating dimness or to understand what went wrong.

title: A Fish Called Wanda
review: It'll keep you amused enough to sit still and even remember it fondly. But it seems a light day's fishing for Messers Cleese and Palin.

title: A Fish Called Wanda
review: It's a deliciously dishy comedy, but like sushi an acquired taste.

title: A Fish Called Wanda
review: The funniest movie I have seen in a long time.

title: A Fish Called Wanda
review: When it comes to comedians, everyone has their favorite. Mine is John Cleese.

review: Just as wacky and imaginative as their earlier film outings.

review: Bad taste of this order is rare but not yet dead.

review: Still holds up beautifully, as both pointed satire and silly, stakes-free comedy.

review: There is little doubt that The Life of Brian represents some of the most daring and cutting edge comedy of the 1970s.

title: Victor Victoria

review: Don't miss this one. It sends sparks.

title: The Manchurian Candidate

title: The Manchurian Candidate

review: Has an excoriating, destabilizing wit that seems as knowingly sophisticated today as it must have then.

review: Not a moment of The Manchurian Candidate lacks edge and tension and a cynical spin.

title: The Manchurian Candidate
review: Its story of Cold War intrigue, murky East-West dealings, assassination, brainwashing -- and the idea of a glorified cue-card reader playing president -- resonates today like never before.

title: Bonnie and Clyde

review: It should readily be apparent that there is something special about the production, with its brash, vivid style, indelible performances by movie icons, and bold mixture of violence and comedy, romance and tragedy.

review: When I saw it, I had been a film critic for less than six months, and it was the first masterpiece I had seen on the job. I felt an exhilaration beyond describing.

review: Was by far the most visually compelling of studio stereoscopic movies.

title: Dirty Dancing

review: Smart and funny, touching and unabashedly sensual.

title: Dirty Dancing
review: This is a shapely film, considered and concise. And if its rhetorical slickness eventually covers up its emotional core, that slickness has a pleasure of its own.

review: While the music on the soundtrack is predictably overloud, the period detail is refreshingly soft-pedaled.

review: Good production values, some nice dance sequences and a likable performance by Grey make the film more than watchable.

review: The film's easy charm, infectious soundtrack and tidy choreography should still win over new fans as well as old.

title: Dirty Dancing
review: Dirty Dancing works best when it's most direct and unpretentious.

review: The movie plays like one long, sad, compromise; it places packaging ahead of ambition.

title: Reservoir Dogs

review: It's dynamite on a short fuse.

review: You may not like the terms Tarantino sets, but you have to admit he succeeds on them.

review: A tour de force.

title: Reservoir Dogs
review: It's extremely well-acted, written with flair and directed by a 29-year-old first-timer, Quentin Tarantino, who always knows where to put the camera, when to cut to a flashback and how to draw the best work from his brilliant cast.

review: The writing is crisp and clean, providing line after line of snappy dialogue designed to leave the viewer alternately pondering and laughing aloud.

review: It's brutal, it's funny and you won't forget it.

title: Platoon

review: This is movie-making with a zealot's fervor.

review: Stone's eye-blistering images possess an awesome power, which sets the senses reeling and leaves the mind disturbed.

title: Platoon

title: Platoon
review: Platoon is one of those movies that, once seen, will never be forgotten, and, at least for those who were not in Vietnam, will forever alter the way in which the war is considered.

title: Platoon
review: I know that Platoon is being acclaimed for its realism, and I expect to be chastened for being a woman finding fault with a war film. But I've probably seen as much combat as most of the men saying, 'This is how war is.'

title: Platoon
review: The movie is beautifully written (by Stone), constructed with strong, clean lines, immaculately paced and regularly surprising.

title: Platoon

title: Platoon
review: Platoon is like the Wall -- a dark and unforgettable memorial to the dead of Vietnam and an awesome requiem to the eternity of war.

review: ...it's still the standard against which all other movies about the Vietnam War are judged.

title: Basic Instinct

title: Basic Instinct

title: Basic Instinct

title: Basic Instinct
review: Call me a prude, but it's not sexy watching an erotic thriller in which every time a couple does it, one of them gets it with an ice pick. I don't care how many firmly toned tummies and tushes are bared.

review: Douglas and Stone are superb, and George Dzundza (as sidekick Gus) delivers another classic hard-boiled cameo.

review: These actors seem driven less by real emotions than Eveready bunny batteries.

review: Watching the movie is like being stuck in a bar with an obnoxious drunk, when you're not drinking.

title: The Crying Game
review: This thriller gives you an entertaining run for your money and some offbeat frissons along the way.

title: The Crying Game

review: An astonishingly good and daring film that richly develops several intertwined thematic lines, The Crying Game takes giant risks that are stunningly rewarded.

review: Tthe film does work, raises a plethora of questions concerning loyalty, violence and the nature of desire, and is in some respects a summation of the various themes that have emerged from Jordan's work.

title: The Crying Game
review: The physical production is as lush as the film's romantic longings.

title: The Crying Game
review: The Crying Game ventures into such exquisitely unique territory that you feel giddy from the pleasure of being allowed to travel along.

title: The Crying Game
review: Reasons remain to watch this movie: the development of Fergus and the fine performances, most notably Whitaker and Richardson, who plays her character with just the right number of screws loose.

title: The Crying Game
review: If you're waiting for something explosive to happen, that may be the case, but if you're absorbing the meticulous and subtle character interaction, the pacing is perfect.

title: Glengarry Glen Ross

review: Though the performances are satisfying in a projected way, they're nullified by an uninspired atmosphere around them. Despite the colorful and witty utterances of its characters, "Glengarry" feels artificial and rarefied.

review: Foley is as adept at managing this intensely psychodramatic material as he is handling an ensemble cast with the combined power of a runaway locomotive.

review: A breath of fresh air.

review: Too good to miss.

review: There is certainly enough of wit and beauty, though, to keep the film afloat.

review: Godard is as relaxed in the film as in the title.

title: Dear God

title: Dear God
review: A goofy, goodwill gesture toward the U.S. Postal Service, it's never funny and moves slower than an unaddressed letter without postage.

title: Dear God

title: Dear God
review: A sickeningly bad pastiche of much better pictures.

title: Dear God
review: It is a limp, lifeless story starring Greg Kinnear as a con man who becomes a do-gooder, and one of its many problems is that he was a lot more entertaining as a con man.

title: Bob Roberts
review: A sometimes brilliant if overloaded pseudodocumentary satire.

title: Bob Roberts
review: A sort of political This Is Spinal Tap, Bob Roberts is both a stimulating social satire and, for thinking people, a depressing commentary on the devolution of the American political system.

title: Bob Roberts
review: Bob Roberts is not merely a satirical fictional biopic, but a wry exploration of the relationship between political reality and manufactured image.

title: Bob Roberts
review: A very funny, sometimes prescient satire of American politics, and of the comparatively small, voting portion of the electorate that makes a Bob Roberts phenomenon possible.

title: Bob Roberts

title: Bob Roberts
review: Robbins, who scripted and directed, creates more than enough on his own. Bob's un-hackneyed character is the prime case in point.

title: Bob Roberts
review: Watching it might be an education for some voters, who will recognize in the movie political techniques they see being practiced all the time in real life.

title: Bob Roberts
review: A welcome injection of venom.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: Still rapturous after all these years, Cinema Paradiso stands as one of the great films about movie love.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: This director's cut -- which adds 51 minutes -- takes a great film and turns it into a mundane soap opera.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: Where the original release was an essay in childish delight and adolescent longing, topped off by a muted coda implying that you really can go home again, the reissue is a fully realized epic of the heart.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: I'm happy to have seen it -- not as an alternate version, but as the ultimate exercise in viewing deleted scenes.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: Less front-loaded and more shapely than the two-hour version released here in 1990.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: As it turns out, you can go home again.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: I don't think most of the people who loved the 1989 Paradiso will prefer this new version. But I do.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: This version moves beyond the original's nostalgia for the communal film experiences of yesteryear to a deeper realization of cinema's inability to stand in for true, lived experience.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: The new version isn't just endless. It heightens the deeply conservative spirit of Giuseppe Tornatore's fable in a surprising new way.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: More romantic, more emotional and ultimately more satisfying than the teary-eyed original.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: Anyone who feels as attached to the history of movies as Tornatore obviously does, there are more than enough irresistible moments.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: This film is sometimes funny, sometimes joyful, and sometimes poignant, but it's always warm, wonderful, and satisfying.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: It is, in a word, exquisite.

title: Nuovo Cinema Paradiso
review: For the most part, this hamfisted movie is very enjoyable.

title: The Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover

title: The Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover
review: For a Jacobean-style drama about deadly emotions, the film lacks passion; only in the final half-hour, with Michael Nyman's funereal music supplying a welcome gravity, does it at last exert a stately power.

title: The Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover
review: A work so intelligent and powerful that it evokes our best emotions and least civil impulses, so esthetically brilliant that it expands the boundaries of film itself.

title: The Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover
review: It doesn't simply make a show of being uncompromising -- it is uncompromised in every single shot from beginning to end.

title: The Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover
review: Greenaway, the bemused, coolly ironic truth-teller, has painted a cruel portrait for a cruel time.

title: The Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover
review: Taboos? If director Peter Greenaway has any, you can't tell by this film.

title: The Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover
review: Give or take another masterpiece coming down the pike, this intricately assembled, viscerally provocative tract on consumerism gone full and grisly circle, is without a doubt, the most accomplished, astounding film of the year.

title: The Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover
review: It's probably safe to say that the British director Peter Greenaway holds the ugliest view of mankind ever put forth by a maker of feature films.

title: Delicatessen

title: Delicatessen
review: All of this is handled in a breezy, off-handed, nutsy manner, as the superb cast combines to help bring it off.

title: Delicatessen
review: Delicatessen is a fearsomely intense movie that mixes moods with formidable assurance.

title: Delicatessen
review: With their detached, sardonic and decidedly sick slant, Jeunet and Caro have served up a burnt-to-a-crisp feast.

title: Delicatessen
review: There are no characters to care about or remember afterward -- just a lot of flashy technique involving decor, some glib allegorical flourishes, and the obligatory studied film-school weirdness.

title: Delicatessen
review: A zany little film that's a startling and clever debut for co-helmers Jean-Pierre Jeunet and Marc Caro.

title: Delicatessen
review: Increasingly inventive as it progresses, Jeunet and Caro's fast, funny feature debut entertains from sinister start to frantic finish.

title: Delicatessen
review: Its last half-hour is devoted chiefly to letting the characters wreck the sets, and quite literally becomes a washout when the bathtub overflows.

title: Delicatessen
review: A laboriously self-conscious attempt at being avant-garde.

title: Delicatessen
review: Marc Caro and Jean-Pierre Jeunet's film leaves you overwhelmed and breathless.

title: La double vie de Véronique
review: We see through a glass darkly, and often confusingly, but at least we see.

review: Don't even attempt to resolve that paradox, and The Double Life of Veronique will work on its own poetic terms.

title: La double vie de Véronique
review: A mesmerizing poetic work composed in an eerie minor key.

title: La double vie de Véronique
review: It operates purely on visual juxtapositions, emotion and the presence of lead actress Irene Jacob. In its own terms, it's subtly precious.

title: La double vie de Véronique
review: The parts do not quite fit, and anyway this is not a puzzle to be assembled. It is a romance about those moments we all sometimes have when we think we see ourselves at a distance.

title: Enchanted April
