title: Enchanted April
review: Strong cast's reliable playing is undercut by a script that dawdles over well-trod territory.

title: Enchanted April
review: Personalities clash but are cheerfully reconciled, and marital tensions are swiftly resolved.

title: Enchanted April
review: The ladies are well bred, the scenery is lovely and the dialogue is polished and polite. It helps that the same villa in Portofino where Miss von Armin wrote the novel has been used to fine effect as the film's principal setting.

title: Enchanted April
review: Is it fair to ask why usually sophisticated Americans turn to mush over this particular variety of moribund ersatz art?

title: Enchanted April
review: Personalities clash but are cheerfully reconciled, and marital tensions are swiftly resolved.

title: Enchanted April
review: It would seem from a spate of films lately that the English can only find their warmer, truer selves abroad -- usually in Italy. Enchanted April takes this familiar path, but traipses along with charm and glory, as if for the very first time.

title: Enchanted April
review: That's what's appealing about the movie (everyone walks away happy) and also forgettable (everyone walks away mush).

title: Paths of Glory
review: More than 20 years after Mr. Cobb's novel was first published, Mr. Kubrick reminded us that human folly is rarely checked for long. A half-century on, he is still right.

title: Paths of Glory
review: Kirk Douglas gives one of his finest performances as the intelligent and courageous Col. Dax.

title: Paths of Glory
review: The sardonic rhetoric may be laid on a little heavily at times, but the movie is blunt and scornfully brilliant.

title: Paths of Glory
review: While the subject is well handled and enacted in a series of outstanding characterizations, it seems dated and makes for grim screen fare.

title: Paths of Glory
review: This masterpiece still packs a wallop, though nothing in it is as simple as it may first appear; audiences are still arguing about the final sequence, which has been characterized as everything from a sentimental cop-out to the ultimate cynical twist.

title: Paths of Glory
review: The final scene, in which Kubrick presents close-ups of soldiers watching a captured German girl being forced to sing for their pleasure is nothing short of masterful.

title: Paths of Glory
review: Songs at the ends of dramas usually make us feel better. They are part of closure. This song at the end of this movie makes us feel more forlorn.

title: Paths of Glory
review: Paths of Glory is all about that greatest of all movie subjects: power.

title: Paths of Glory
review: There's a near mathematical logic to the scenario and the cruelty is compounded by class.

title: Paths of Glory
review: Both a terrifying, grim look at battle and an excruciatingly tense courtroom thriller. Together, it's a devastating indictment of war as conducted by opportunists and liars.

title: Paths of Glory
review: As for the picture's significance, it comes to an inconclusive point.

title: The English Patient
review: Could this possibly be the Casablanca of the late 20th century?

title: The English Patient
review: It's the sort of solemn production that is often mentioned as an Academy Award contender.This says less about the quality of the film than it does about its self-consciously lofty tone and its sense of self-importance.

title: The English Patient

title: The English Patient
review: With its fine acting, sumptuous visuals and levels of intrigue, The English Patient boasts the elements of something greater than a love story. Too bad it devotes them to something less than a great love story.

title: The English Patient

title: The English Patient
review: The cast is superb: Binoche, with her thin, seraphic smile; Scott Thomas, aware of the spell she casts but not flaunting it; Fiennes, especially, radiating sexy mystery, threat shrouded in hauteur. Doom and drive rarely have so much stately star quality.

title: The English Patient
review: A respectable, intelligent but less than stirring adaptation of an imposingly dense and layered novel.

title: The English Patient
review: This is the real thing, and real things don't come along very often, so you'd better snap them up when they do.

title: The English Patient
review: For all the film's effectiveness as a love story, I often felt I was being hurried through a busy itinerary.

title: The English Patient
review: The result is completely intoxicating.

title: The English Patient
review: Needless to say, the performances are flawless; more surprising is the fluency, poetry and scale of Minghella's direction.

title: The English Patient
review: Torrid, witty, passionate and intelligent.

title: The English Patient
review: Get ready for the great romance of the movie year.

title: The English Patient
review: The English Patient captivates as only the grandest and most consuming passions can.

title: The English Patient
review: A stunning feat of literary adaptation as well as a purely cinematic triumph.

title: The English Patient
review: The English Patient, the superb new film by Anthony Minghella, is that rarest of things: a film based on a great contemporary novel.

title: The English Patient
review: This poetic, evocative film version of the famous novel by Michael Ondaatje circles down through layers of mystery until all of the puzzles in the story have been solved, and only the great wound of a doomed love remains.

title: The English Patient
review: This is one of the year's most unabashed and powerful love stories, using flawless performances, intelligent dialogue, crisp camera work, and loaded glances to attain a level of eroticism and emotional connection that many similar films miss.

title: My Left Foot: The Story of Christy Brown

title: My Left Foot: The Story of Christy Brown
review: For all his character's travails the film as a whole winds up surprisingly upbeat.

title: My Left Foot: The Story of Christy Brown

review: An intelligent, beautifully acted adaptation of Christy Brown's first book.

title: My Left Foot: The Story of Christy Brown

title: My Left Foot: The Story of Christy Brown
review: Not only does Day-Lewis master the physical aspects of the role, the minute-to-minute struggle of almost complete paralysis, he lives the painful genesis of an artistic character.

title: My Left Foot: The Story of Christy Brown
review: Jim Sheridan's My Left Foot must be the most passionately empathetic film about a physical affliction ever made.

title: Sex, Lies, and Videotape
review: What amazes is that at just 26, Soderbergh displays the three qualities associated with mature filmmakers: a unique authorial voice, a spooky camera assurance, and the easy control of ensemble acting.

title: Sex, Lies, and Videotape
review: This is a sexy, nuanced, beautifully controlled examination of how a quartet of people are defined by their erotic impulses and inhibitions.

title: Sex, Lies, and Videotape
review: The actors are superb; working from Soderbergh's funny, perceptive, immaculately wrought dialogue, they ensure that the film stimulates both intellectually and emotionally.

title: Sex, Lies, and Videotape
review: A film whose enormous authority and intelligence extend to every detail.

title: Sex, Lies, and Videotape
review: A movie of prodigious power and feeling that is also high-spirited, hilarious and scorchingly erotic.

title: Sex, Lies, and Videotape
review: Inspired chitchat, a barefaced Louisiana gabfest written and directed by Steven Soderbergh, a 26-year-old Wunderkind preoccupied with l'amour.

title: Sex, Lies, and Videotape
review: Wwriter/director/editor Soderbergh has composed a wry, highly watchable piece that comes across as a great first effort by a film-school graduate.

title: Sex, Lies, and Videotape
review: It is never boring, and there are moments when it reminds us of how sexy the movies used to be, back in the days when speech was an erogenous zone.

title: Sex, Lies, and Videotape
review: Lean, economical, relatively unpretentious (or at least pretentiously unpretentious), and purposefully small-scale.

title: Átame!
review: Mr. Almodovar's comic invention runs out too soon, leaving the audience to giggle weakly in anticipation of the big laughs and disorienting shocks that never arrive.

title: Átame!
review: A writer-director driven by his passion, Almodovar allows his movies to moan and sweat and writhe. Sex looks like sex, not pornographic but messy and warm. The curtains do not billow, the sheets burn.

title: Átame!
review: Almodovar's polarities are so perfectly lined up in opposition to my own that it is quite possible for one of his movies to shoot right through my brain without striking a single cell.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: There's a lot here. But with a classic like Cuckoo's Nest, too much is never enough.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: One Flew over the Cuckoo 's Nest is an earnest attempt to make a serious film. But in the end the movie backs away from both the human reality and the cloudy but potent symbolism that Ken Kesey found in the asylum.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Viewed 30 years after its release, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest remains a very good motion picture, although one that perhaps just misses the pinnacle of greatness where its reputation suggests it resides.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Jack Nicholson stars in an outstanding characterization of Ken Kesey's asylum anti-hero, McMurphy, and Milos Forman's direction of a superbly-cast film is equally meritorious.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Jack Nicholson plays McMurphy as if he were born to it, and the supporting cast provides fine, detailed performances.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Set in an insane asylum, the film involves the oppression of the individual, a struggle spearheaded by an ebullient Nicholson, turning in a star performance if ever there was one.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Even granting the artist his license, America is much too big and various to be satisfactorily reduced to the dimensions of one mental ward in a movie like this.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Is One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest not a great film because it is manipulative, or is it great because it is so superbly manipulative? I can see it through either filter.

title: Up in Smoke
review: What's lacking in Up in Smoke is a cohesiveness in both humor and characterization.

title: Up in Smoke
review: Director Lou Adler (the record producer) finds a few chuckles, but mostly it's amateur night.

title: Up in Smoke
review: As the most fun comes not from watching the movie but from recalling great lines later, it would seem that the audio success of C & C has not translated too well into visuals.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: In many ways the new film is a better film than Star Wars, visually more exciting, more artful and meticulous in detail.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: The Empire Strikes Back is a worthy sequel to Star Wars, equal in both technical mastery and characterization, suffering only from the familiarity with the effects generated in the original and imitated too much by others.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: Irvin Kershner directed the actors this time around, and without the benefit of Lucas's personal affection they seem stiffer, more clenched.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: An extended ricochet from one incendiary set-piece battle to another which still finds time to attend to plot, pace and character.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: The total effect is fast and attractive and occasionally amusing. Like a good hot dog, that's something of an achievement in a field where unpalatable junk is the rule.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: It is a visual extravaganza from beginning to end, one of the most visionary and inventive of all films.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: The Empire Strikes Back is a technological triumph, a cornucopia of intergalactic tchotchkes.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: The balance between action and mysticism in Empire provides fascinating energy.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: A superior motion picture!

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: In the glory days of science fiction, critics wrote about the 'sense of wonder.' That's what The Empire Strikes Back creates in us

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: I found myself glancing at my watch almost as often as I did when I was sitting through a truly terrible movie called The Island.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: A dramatic illustration of the continued technical brilliance and leadership of the Lucas production team.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: Star Wars made my eyes pop out when I first saw it in 1977!

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: The most classic in its style, design and narrative.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: It balances bloodshed with charm, spectacle with childlike glee. It's a near flawless movie of its kind.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: For many Star Wars fans, this second installment is the best of the George Lucas trilogy: a dark, ultimately melancholy, even philosophical episode that has no triumphant happy ending.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: The storytelling is the series' best, with a zingy balance of drama, humor, and Deep Thoughts.

title: The Princess Bride
review: As you watch this enchanting fantasy, feel free to be thrilled or to giggle, as you wish.

title: The Princess Bride
review: Patinkin, the most dazzling movie swordsman since Errol Flynn, steals the movie with his athletic grace and delivery of lines like: "My name is Inigo Montoya! Prepare to die!"

title: The Princess Bride

title: The Princess Bride
review: Heroic fantasies, we often feel, should be lighter than air, hot as dragon fire, fast as a sword in sunlight. And that's mostly what we get from the delightful The Princess Bride -- along with some bracing humor and foolery.

title: The Princess Bride
review: The film works well enough, providing its fair share of laughs and thrills, and in technical terms it is by far Reiner`s most professional job of direction.

title: The Princess Bride
review: Based on William Goldman's novel, this is a post-modern fairy tale that challenges and affirms the conventions of a genre that may not be flexible enough to support such horseplay.

title: The Princess Bride
review: Rob Reiner's friendly 1987 fairy-tale adventure delicately mines the irony inherent in its make-believe without ever undermining the effectiveness of the fantasy.

title: The Princess Bride
review: The leads are vacuous; the absurdities sometimes forced and obvious.

title: The Princess Bride
review: Since its release more than 15 years ago, The Princess Bride has often been copied, but never equaled.

title: The Princess Bride
review: This material might easily have lent itself to broad parody or become too cute for its own good. But Mr. Reiner presents it as a bedtime story, pure and simple.

title: The Princess Bride
review: It is filled with good-hearted fun.

title: The Princess Bride
review: Bride achieves much more than most film comedies.

title: The Princess Bride
review: It's a lively, fun-loving, but nevertheless epic look at the nature of true love.

title: Raiders of the Lost Ark
review: Yes, it's as entertaining as you have heard. Maybe more so. Raiders of the Lost Ark is, in fact, about as entertaining as a commercial movie can be.

title: Raiders of the Lost Ark
review: Raiders of the Lost Ark has it all -- or, anyway, more than enough to transport moviegoers back to the dazzling, thrill-sated matinee idyls of old.

title: Raiders of the Lost Ark
review: The thrills are fully consumed while you're seeing this movie, and it's totally over when it's over. It's a workout. You feel as if you'd been to the desert digs: at the end your mind is blank, yet you're parched, you're puffing hard -- you want relief.

title: Raiders of the Lost Ark
review: ...a crackerjack fantasy-adventure that shapes its pulp sensibilities and cliff-hanging serial origins into an exhilarating escapist entertainment that will have broad-cased summer audiences in the palm of its hand.

review: Francis Ford Coppola pulls it off in grand style.

review: The performances, Gordon Willis' memorably gloomy camerawork, the stately pace and the sheer scale of the story's sweep render everything engrossing and so, well, plausible that our ideas of organised crime in America will forever be marked by this movie.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: The stunning text of The Godfather is replaced in Part II with prologues, epilogues, footnotes, and good intentions.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: It's a second movie made largely out of the bits and pieces of Mr. Puzo's novel that didn't fit into the first. It's a Frankenstein's monster stitched together from leftover parts. It talks. It moves in fits and starts but it has no mind of its own.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: Few sequels have expanded upon the original with the faithfulness and detail of this one.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: If his considerable achievement in this long- awaited film falls short of his Olympian standards, there is a reason that ought to give Kubrick some satisfaction. The world has caught up with Kubrick and what he has to say.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: It may seem too spare, too clinical, its moments of war even too familiar for some. But, aiming for minds as well as hearts, Kubrick hits his target squarely.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: What gives this story its power is not really its originality, but the relentlessness of Kubrick's black-comic vision and the tightness of his focus.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: There is a real fear at the heart of this monstrously armored, desperately defensive film.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: It's a great piece of filmmaking, diminished only by a second act that fails to live up to the first act of the Marines in training.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: Full Metal Jacket is not a realistic film -- it is horror-comic superrealism, from a God's-eye view -- but it should fully engage the ordinary movie grunt.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: This is the most tightly crafted Kubrick film since Dr. Strangelove, as well as the most horrific; the first section alone accomplishes most of what The Shining failed to do.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: An intense, schematic, superbly made Vietnam War drama.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: Kubrick's direction is as steely cold and manipulative as the regime it depicts, and we never really get to know, let alone care about, the hapless recruits on view.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: Although the elements of the story are simple and precise, Kubrick infuses a dreamlike, fatalistic quality.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: Full Metal Jacket, ice and wildfire, order and chaos, is intellectual war, hard thought.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: No one who sees Full Metal Jacket will easily put the film's last glimpse of D'Onofrio, or a great many other things about Kubrick's latest and most sobering vision, out of mind.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: [A] strangely shapeless film from the man whose work usually imposes a ferociously consistent vision on his material.

title: Full Metal Jacket
review: Kubrick's harrowing, beautiful and characteristically eccentric new film about Vietnam, is going to puzzle, anger and (I hope) fascinate audiences as much as any film he has made to date.

title: Henry V
review: A stirring, gritty and enjoyable pic which offers a plethora of fine performances from some of the U.K.'s brightest talents.

title: Henry V
review: The cast -- including Derek Jacobi as the modern-dress chorus, Paul Scofield, Judi Dench, Ian Holm, Emma Thompson, and Robbie Coltrane in an effective cameo as Falstaff -- is uniformly fine without any grandstanding.

title: Henry V
review: Branagh succeeds in his blunt, robust portrayal of the Soldier-King, hauling the film along in the wake of his own gung-ho performance.

title: Henry V
review: Mr. Branagh's Henry has psychological heft and intellectual weight.

title: Henry V
review: More questioning, more agonized, finally more humble.

title: Henry V
review: Everything about this remarkable production is exhilaratingly unexpected.

title: Henry V
review: What works best in the film is the over-all vision.

title: Henry V
review: In this alert, rousing interpretation of Henry V, Branagh beats down the doors of high art and drags the sleeping bard into the light of modern day.

title: Amadeus
review: The performance of Abraham, who won the Best Actor Oscar for it, is monumental, and so is Forman's direction.

title: Amadeus
review: The subject of artistic creation is typically handled badly in the movies.... [Amadeus] treats the subject of creativity in a fresh way.

title: Amadeus
review: A grand movie entertainment.

title: Amadeus
review: On a production level and as an evocation of a time and place, Amadeus is loaded with pleasures.

title: Amadeus
review: Peter Shaffer's shrewdly orchestrated cultural evening gets a steady, dignified, moderately dull treatment from Milos Forman.

title: Amadeus
review: The entire cast speaks in horribly intrusive American accents, but Forman makes some perceptive connections between Mozart's life and work.

title: Amadeus
review: It is arguably the best motion picture ever made about the process of creation and the creator.

title: Amadeus
review: As Mozart, Tom Hulce, though extremely American in looks and voice, gets better and better as the drama progresses.

title: Amadeus
review: This dark, exuberant epic is nearly 18 years old, yet remains the most popularly successful film ever to render the inner life of an artist.

title: Amadeus
review: Reminds us that movies can be lyrical as well as vulgar, ambitious as well as playful, brilliant as well as down and dirty -- just like Amadeus himself.

title: Amadeus
review: Remains a beautiful, deftly directed and superbly acted version of a witty and poignant drama.

title: Amadeus
review: In a film of grand gestures, some of the finest moments are very subtle.

title: Amadeus
review: A gloriously colorful confection of music, theater and emotion.

title: Amadeus
review: It's got more music, more drama, more of what made it a big winner with audiences and critics 18 years ago.

title: Amadeus
review: Like the composers the film so wondrously depicts, Amadeus: Director's Cut is a divine work in need of a little earthly restraint.

title: Amadeus
review: In any incarnation, Amadeus is beautiful to behold.

title: Amadeus
review: The principal additions ... are more Amadeus, but not better.

title: Amadeus
review: Still a work of consummate artistry and craftsmanship.

title: The Quiet Man
review: This is a robust romantic drama of a native-born's return to Ireland. Director John Ford took cast and cameras to Ireland to tell the story [by Maurice Walsh] against actual backgrounds.

title: The Quiet Man
review: John Ford's 1952 Oscar winner is a tribute to an Ireland that exists only in the imaginations of songwriters and poets like Ford.

title: The Quiet Man
review: The illusion/reality theme underlying immigrant boxer Wayne's return from America to County Galway is soon swamped within a vibrant community of stage-Irish 'types'.

title: The Quiet Man
review: Let's face it. Mr. Ford is in love with Ireland, as is his cast, and they give us a fine, gay time while they're about it.

title: The Quiet Man
review: Although not a true classic, The Quiet Man is worth more than a cursory glance, especially for those who like Wayne or would like to experience more of his work.

title: Once Upon a Time in America
review: Sergio Leone's languid, lovely and lengthy ode to Lower East Side mobsters (more specifically, mobster films) ...

title: Once Upon a Time in America
review: Leone is less interested in arousing an audience's easier emotions than in presenting, at a dispassionate distance, the horror of two men warily walking toward each other on a tightrope suspended above the snake pit of their , deepest compulsions.

title: Once Upon a Time in America
review: Every gesture is immediate, and every gesture seems eternal.

title: Once Upon a Time in America
review: A disappointment of considerable proportions.

title: Once Upon a Time in America
review: While Leone's vision still has a magnificent sweep, the film finally subsides to an emotional core that is sombre, even elegiac, and which centres on a man who is bent and broken by time, and finally left with nothing but an impotent sadness.

title: Once Upon a Time in America
review: There are times when we don't understand exactly what is happening, but never a time when we don't feel confidence in the film's narrative.

title: Once Upon a Time in America
review: As one would expect from Leone, the film is a brilliant stylistic accomplishment.

title: Once Upon a Time in America
review: A lazily haullucinatory epic that means to encapsulate approximately 50 years of American social history into a single film.

title: Once Upon a Time in America
review: The film slips easily back and forth in time, dancing between the decades, often making the connection from one era to another solely by means of brilliant cuts that work like magic.

title: Once Upon a Time in America
review: Seeing what Leone always intended is like getting your dirty glasses washed.

title: Raging Bull
review: When has a performer as fully and uniquely sacrificed himself to the moving-picture cause as De Niro?

title: Raging Bull
review: De Niro is always absorbing and credible, even when his character isn't.

title: Raging Bull
review: Martin Scorsese makes pictures about the kinds of people you wouldn't want to know.

title: Raging Bull
review: I can't pan it, but this 1980 fantasy biography of fighter Jake LaMotta seems unquestionably Martin Scorsese's weakest work, at least to that point in his career.

title: Raging Bull
review: This film does more than make you think about masculinity, it makes you see it -- in a way that's relevant to all men, not just Bronx boxers.

title: Raging Bull
review: The film that many consider the finest of its decade.

title: Raging Bull
review: An underdog in its day and a classic today.

title: Raging Bull
review: Though Raging Bull has only three principal characters, it is a big film, its territory being the landscape of the soul.

title: Raging Bull
review: The most obvious basis for the film's claim to greatness lies in Scorsese's devastating critique of the very codes of masculinity that shaped him as a filmmaker, and in Robert De Niro's performance, through which that critique is made flesh.

title: Raging Bull
review: It's the best film I've seen about the low self-esteem, sexual inadequacy and fear that lead some men to abuse women.

title: Raging Bull
review: There's no room for romanticism in the ring with inky black blood staining the canvas. During fight sequences, the director also uses a number of point-of-view shots designed to show the world, however briefly, from La Motta's perspective.

title: Annie Hall
review: Allen joins the Catskills tummler's anything-for-a-laugh antics with a Eurocentric art-house self-awareness and a psychoanalytic obsession in baring his sexual desires and frustrations, romantic disasters, and neurotic inhibitions.

title: Annie Hall
review: This is the link between Allen's "earlier, funnier" stuff and more probing works like Interiors and Manhattan. Would that we all could build such masterful bridges.

title: Annie Hall
review: Personal as the story he is telling may be, what separates this film from Allen's own past work and most other recent comedy is its general believability.

title: Annie Hall
review: A touching and hilarious love story that is Allen's most three-dimensional film to date.

title: Annie Hall
review: Visually and structurally it's a mess, but many of the situations are genuinely clever, and there are plenty of memorable gags.

title: Annie Hall
review: If you can forgive the fact that it's a ragbag of half-digested intellectual ideas dressed up with trendy intellectual references, you should have a good laugh.

title: Annie Hall
review: There will be discussion about what points in the film coincide with the lives of its two stars, but this, I think, is to detract from and trivialize the achievement of the film, which, at last, puts Woody in the league with the best directors we have.

title: Annie Hall
review: Watching it again, 25 years after its April 1977 premiere, I am astonished by how scene after scene has an instant familiarity.

title: Stalker
review: Tarkovsky realizes the allegorical tale with an overwhelming density of visual detail ...

title: Stalker
review: Not an easy film, but almost certainly a great one.

title: Stalker
review: Tarkovsky conjures images like you've never seen before; and as a journey to the heart of darkness, it's a good deal more persuasive than Coppola's.

title: Stalker
review: Stalker, a somber futuristic fantasy from the Soviet Union, attempts to build an apocalyptic vision out of the most impoverished materials imaginable.

title: Das Boot
review: Everything described in the film is authentic.

title: Das Boot
review: The film has no qualities beyond its formal polish.

title: Das Boot
review: Agripping, impressively detailed account of one harrowing voyage by a German U-boat during World War II.

title: Das Boot
review: Petersen's shooting style displays a breathtaking, if impersonal and faintly academic, virtuosity comparable to that of Lean or Coppola.

title: Das Boot
review: Das Boot is yet another moving testament to the wastefulness of battle.

title: Das Boot
review: The film reaches right out to grab us by the neck and squeeze hard.

title: Das Boot
review: Wolfgang Petersen's direction is an exercise in pure craftsmanship.

title: Das Boot
review: This film takes all of the drama and suspense inherent in a submarine-based story and delivers it in a near- perfect package, establishing Das Boot as not just a terrific adrenaline rush, but one of the best movies ever made.

title: Das Boot
review: You're drawn in powerfully as the crew members experience a psychologically maddening cycle of lull and storm.

title: Das Boot
review: Suspenseful when it needs to be and intelligent in its depiction of the horrors of war and the sweaty claustrophobia of submarine life. On occasion, it's even -- pardon the pun -- deep.

title: The Sting
review: Newman and Redford pass a few facial expressions between them and try to cool each other out. If there ever was much of a script, it can be said to have gone to waste.

title: The Sting
review: Extremely handsome production values and a great supporting cast round out the virtues.

title: The Sting
review: Top-notch entertainment.

title: The Sting
review: The film ends up relying on different chapter headings to explain what's going on, but it's all very professional, with fine attention to period detail.

title: The Sting
review: The film is so good-natured, so obviously aware of everything it's up to, even its own picturesque frauds, that I opt to go along with it.

title: The Sting
review: The movie has a nice, light-fingered style to it.

title: Harold and Maude
review: The fact that [it] isn't very funny and, like its 80-year-old heroic, long outlives its necessary life, is less important than the fact that the characters frequently react gently or like credible human beings to the script's impossible notions.

title: Harold and Maude
review: Simpleminded, but it's fairly inoffensive, at least until Ashby lingers over the concentration-camp serial number tattooed on Gordon's arm. Some things are beyond the reach of whimsy.

title: Harold and Maude
review: It is most successful when it keeps to the tone of an insane fairystory set up at the beginning of the movie.

title: Harold and Maude
review: [Bud Cort and Ruth Gordon] both are so aggressive, so creepy and off-putting.

title: Harold and Maude
review: The visual style makes everyone look fresh from the Wax Museum, and all the movie lacks is a lot of day-old gardenias and lilies and roses in the lobby, filling the place with a cloying sweet smell. Nothing more to report today.

title: Harold and Maude
review: Marked by a few good gags, but marred by a greater preponderance of sophomoric, overdone and mocking humor.

title: Trust the Man
review: I saw this at a festival and hated it, then sat through it again a year later and decided it wasn't so bad, aside from the god-awful ending.

title: Trust the Man
review: It's a pity, because few romcoms pull off the basically sympathetic mining of personal vanities and social embarrassment that the film manages in its opening hour.

title: Trust the Man
review: Freundlich's outstanding cast (including Garry Shandling, Eva Mendes, Ellen Barkin, Bob Balaban and James LeGros) -- his best since 1997's The Myth of Fingerprints -- glosses over miscalculations with sheer star power.

title: Trust the Man
review: Two couples in trouble, one with kids, another considering them. Writer-director Bart Freundlich's challenge is to stress them and find a resolution to their conflicts in ways that aren't banal, predictable or witless. And he settles for one out of three.

title: Trust the Man
review: The fact that Freundlich tries to put some thoughtful commentary into a formulaic story is commendable, but in the end either his faith wavers or the studio intervened.

title: Trust the Man
review: I wish the film were true to itself and its quartet of puzzled, struggling lovers; their collapse into sitcom idiocy felt uncomfortably close to betrayal.

title: Trust the Man
review: A lot more smug and a lot less insightful than writer-director Bart Freundlich apparently assumes, and it's burdened even more by its surfeit of unsympathetic characters.

title: Trust the Man
review: Screenwriter and director Bart Freundlich fails to offer fresh insights into the problems of contemporary relationships, and many of his comic targets are easy and conventional.

title: Trust the Man
review: There's nothing terribly wrong with this comedy about the romantic dalliances of four New Yorkers, but there's nothing terribly right about it, either.

title: Trust the Man
review: The people behind this film would not recognize complex, honest emotion if it hit them in the face with a frying pan.

title: Trust the Man
review: Trying to mimic the Woody Allen films is not a bad thing to do, but why not put a spin on it?

title: Trust the Man
review: Is this farce, drama, satire? Who knows?

title: Trust the Man
review: This comedy about two self-absorbed New York couples feels like wan Woody Allen.

title: Trust the Man
review: Trust the Man has a sketchy overall feel, as if Freundlich didn't finish thinking it through.

title: Trust the Man
review: Trust the Man is a mildly amusing movie, but that's chiefly a result of its stars -- or, more specifically, its female stars -- elevating the material.

title: Trust the Man
review: As faux Woody Allen movies go, Trust the Man is one of the more diverting recent entries in the genre, with a top-drawer cast, well-chosen Manhattan locations and a sharper script than Allen himself has managed in a while.

title: Trust the Man
review: In the end, you're left feeling a little empty, as if you've been eavesdropping on a conversation in a restaurant and neglected to eat your dinner.

title: Trust the Man
review: The actors gamely keep up their spirits, but the male characters are too one-dimensional and the female characters too bizarrely divorced from reality to be at all engaging.

title: Det sjunde inseglet
review: Bergman's visually striking medieval morality play [was] the work that gained him an international reputation.

title: Det sjunde inseglet
review: Film has superior technical narrative, impressive lensing and thesping.

title: Det sjunde inseglet
review: Its view of a seemingly godless landscape in the grip of plague is still bold and frightening.

title: Det sjunde inseglet

title: Det sjunde inseglet
review: Not only highly impressive but thought-provoking, relevant and intensely moving in our present, nervous, times.

title: Det sjunde inseglet
review: Essentially intellectual, yet emotionally stimulating, too, it is as tough -- and rewarding -- a screen challenge as the moviegoer has had to face this year.

title: Det sjunde inseglet
review: This is an uncompromising film, regarding good and evil with the same simplicity and faith as its hero.

title: Local Hero

title: Local Hero
review: [It's] loaded with wry, offbeat humor and is the sort of satisfying, personal picture that is becoming an increasingly rare commodity these days

title: Local Hero
review: Forsyth cannot quite tease out of his characters the kind of strange sublety that Powell and Pressburger delivered, but it is enough that he and producer David Puttnam succeed in making you realise just how badly this kind of film has been missed.

title: Local Hero
review: Here is a small film to treasure, a loving, funny, understated portrait of a small Scottish town and its encounter with a giant oil company.

title: Local Hero
review: It demonstrates Mr. Forsyth's uncanny ability for making an audience sense that something magical is going on, even if that something isn't easily explained.

title: Terminator Salvation

title: Terminator Salvation
review: A shambolic, deafening, intelligence-insulting mess, a crushing failure on almost all counts.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: This is the worst big budget summer release I've seen in some time.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: It's a fun time at the movies.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: Terminator Salvation is a confused, humorless grind, with nobody, from the stars to the set designers, prepared to prick its self-importance.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: The digital effects are mostly quite dazzling-not just the depictions of towering marauders...but a memorably scary sequence in which a little serpentine robot that's been taken captive thrashes furiously to save its nonlife.

review: T4 is a mixed bag, but it's not f------- amateur.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: Message to Hollywood: Stop with the time-travel stuff.

review: McG, a music video maven whose previous credits include the Charlie's Angels movies, directs the action passably well.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: Intensity need not be the enemy of personality, but in Bale's work it too often has been.

title: Terminator Salvation

title: Terminator Salvation
review: A good summer movie isn't just an uninterrupted crescendo of cacophony. You need stuff in between the fireballs and the cyborgs.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: Terminator Salvation is so programmed, so impersonal, that it practically dares you to warm to its characters.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: One could argue Connor's grim demeanor is precisely what a global disaster demands. But Bale's turn has a bass-note feel that is anti-charismatic.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: The movie's only unmitigated pleasure is a too-brief fight scene between Connor and a naked combatant made up to look precisely like Arnold Schwarzenegger, the relentless cyborg of the first three installments.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: The latest installment in the venerable sci-fi action franchise turns out to be a straight-up war film, grim and muscular and thundering and joyless. It's the color of cement, and it weighs as much, too.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: The Terminator franchise was built on thrills, imagination, narrative, emotion, believability, character development and watchability. Terminator Salvation has plenty of thrills.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: Too bad Schwarzenegger is otherwise occupied these days.

title: Terminator Salvation
review: Skynet may not have ensured its own future, yet. But their robots have clearly made serious inroads in our movies.

title: Braindead
review: The best to date from Kiwi gore specialist Peter Jackson.

title: Braindead
review: The finale, in which Lionel reduces a horde of flesh-eaters to a mulch of blood, flesh and offal with the aid of a flymo, is probably the goriest scene ever.

title: Braindead
review: Because all of this looks blatantly unreal, and because the timing of the shock effects is so haphazard, Dead Alive isn't especially scary or repulsive. Nor is it very funny.

title: Braindead
review: Horror films used to be primordial spook shows, tapping midnight-dark fears. Now they tap bodily goo: rivers of blood, dripping limbs, eyeballs that go pop in the night.

title: Glory

title: Glory
review: A stirring and long overdue tribute to the black soldiers who fought for the Union cause in the Civil War.

title: Glory
review: A pretty watchable and always interesting period film, well photographed by English cinematographer Freddie Francis.

review: The stark clarity of Freddie Francis' cinematography combined with Zwick's intimate style evokes immediacy and fear.

title: Glory
review: This is a good, moving, complicated film.

review: Matthew Broderick [is] catastrophically miscast as Shaw.

review: A strong and valuable film.

title: Glory
review: It's hard not to get carried along.

title: Glory
review: Generally engrossing and always well-acted.

title: Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Dead
review: Both Oldman and Roth turn in flat and uninspiring performances.

review: As happens at the opera, one usually laughs (if one laughs at all) not because something is funny, but because one has successfully recognized that it is supposed to be funny.

title: Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Dead
review: As a movie, this material, freely adapted by Stoppard, is boring and endless. It lies flat on the screen, hardly stirring.

review: Staged as they are here, the jokes and the fourth-wall gamesmanship don't seem as funny as they did on the page.

title: Manhattan
review: The film should not come as a complete surprise to anyone who has been paying attention to Allen's doings lately. This is the movie that Annie Hall hinted at and to which last year's Interiors, flawed as it was, seems to have served as a necessary prelude.

title: Manhattan
review: Allen serves up a nostalgia that was utterly of its time; he incarnates an idea of the city that, even now, remains as strong as its reality and refracts his disappointed ideals into high existential crises.

title: Manhattan
review: Manhattan is not just Woody Allen's dream movie. Wistful as it is witty, it's his dream of the movies.

title: Manhattan
review: Allen has, in black and white, captured the inner beauty that lurks behind the outer layer of dirt and grime in Manhattan.

title: Manhattan
review: Woody Allen's great leap forward into character development and dramatic integrity.

title: Manhattan
review: This is a deeply self-critical film about immaturity and the gift of real love. Many films can be said to put an epitaph on the decade, but few remain as relevant.

title: Manhattan
review: Woody Allen's gem of comic kvetching.

title: Manhattan
review: Mr. Allen's progress as one of our major filmmakers is proceeding so rapidly that we who watch him have to pause occasionally to catch our breath.

title: Manhattan
review: If Manhattan was only a romantic comedy, it would be a very good one, but the fact that the movie has so much more ambition than the 'average' entry into the genre makes it an extraordinary example of the fusion of entertainment and art.

title: Manhattan
review: Seeing it again I realize it's more subtle, more complex, and not about love, but loss.

title: Miller's Crossing
review: Substance is here in spades, along with the twisted, brilliantly controlled style on which filmmakers Joel and Ethan Coen made a name.

review: It never fully convinces in terms of either period or plot.

review: The Coens' take on Depression-era gangster flicks, looks gorgeous and showcases John Turturro's best acting ever.

review: It's arguably the US mainstream's first art movie since Days of Heaven; and quite wonderful.

title: Miller's Crossing
review: Without much point at all.

review: Crossing is the kind of movie that benefits from a second sitting, to get a complete grip on the plot.

title: Miller's Crossing
review: While Miller's Crossing is not as messy or inspired as Martin Scorsese's GoodFellas, or as richly suggestive as The Godfather, it accomplishes exactly what it sets out to do.

title: Miller's Crossing
review: There is a lot here to admire.

title: Miller's Crossing
review: As disturbing and densely beautiful as its opening image.

title: Dead Poets Society

review: The moral divisions set up between characters are childishly overdrawn; and, worst of all, the behavior shown by the boys and adults frequently reeks of falsity and contrivance.

review: Weir infuses the film with his customary mysticism, but more importantly, draws sensitive performances from his largely inexperienced cast.

title: Dead Poets Society
review: The movie undercuts Mr. Williams's exceptionally fine performance, making the character seem more of a dubious fool than is probably intended.

title: Dead Poets Society
review: It's a literate though strained uplifter, a not altogether compatible coupleting of Rocky Balboa and the Bard.

title: Dead Poets Society
review: Not the worst of the countless recent movies about good kids and hidebound, authoritatian older people. It may, however, be the most shameless in its attempt to pander to an adolescent audience.

review: Solid, smart entertainment.

title: The Graduate
review: The emotional elevation of the film is due in no small measure to the extraordinarily engaging performances of Anne Bancroft as the wife-mother-mistress, Dustin Hoffman as the lumbering Lancelot, and Katherine Ross as his fair Elaine.

review: The film itself is very broken-backed, partly because Anne Bancroft's performance as the mother carries so much more weight than Katharine Ross' as the daughter, partly because Nichols couldn't decide whether he was making a social satire or a farce.

review: Makes you feel a little tearful and choked-up while it is making you laugh yourself raw.

title: The Graduate
review: A delightful, satirical comedy-drama.

review: A simple romantic comedy whose "countercultural" message, insofar as it has one, is decidedly retrograde.

review: It is a good topical movie whose time has passed

title: The Graduate
review: Few movies have communicated with such dark hilarity all the anxiety and flamboyant misery of youthful sexual initiation

title: The Graduate
review: What I don't enjoy is the cruelty, the glib mindlessness, and the insulated, pampered narcissism that makes the whole thing possible.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
review: Has no one else found it highly peculiar that damn near everybody's choice for the best movie of (let's say) the decade should be dedicated, inferentially but absolutely, to the proposition that Courage is Madness and Cowardice is Best?

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
review: Part of the success of The Bridge is that its courageous hero is shown from all angles, in all kinds of mirrors. He is strong, stubborn, fallible, maniacal, silly, and wise; and in the end he is pathetic, noble, and foolish.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
review: From sky to ground in two shots, and it already feels like we've traversed a great distance, with two and a half hours of skillful, suspenseful WWII adventure to go.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
review: It is a whale of a story, and in the telling of it, British Director David Lean does a whale of a job.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
review: A gripping drama, expertly put together and handled with skill in all departments.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
review: For what it is, it ain't bad, though it serves mainly as an illustration of the ancient quandary of revisionist moviemakers: if all you do is systematically invert cliches, you simply end up creating new ones.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
review: A classic example of a film that fudges the issues it raises.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
review: In my opinion, it is one of the two best films to emerge from a very strong decade of cinema.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
review: Brilliant is the word, and no other, to describe the quality of skills that have gone into the making of this picture.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
review: Most war movies are either for or against their wars. The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957) is one of the few that focuses not on larger rights and wrongs but on individuals.

title: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre
review: Treasure of Sierra Madre is one of the best things Hollywood has done since it learned to talk; and the movie can take a place, without blushing, among the best ever made.

title: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre
review: John Huston has rarely been in better form than in this 1948 study of gold fever and worse obsessions among an unlikely trio of prospectors...

title: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre
review: There's a quite enjoyable yarn buried under the hollow laughter.

title: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre
review: The movie has never really been about gold but about character, and Bogart fearlessly makes Fred C. Dobbs into a pathetic, frightened, selfish man -- so sick we would be tempted to pity him, if he were not so undeserving of pity.

title: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre
review: Greed, a despicable passion out of which other base ferments may spawn, is seldom treated in the movies with the frank and ironic contempt that is vividly manifested toward it in Treasure of Sierra Madre.

title: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre
review: The characters here are probed and thoroughly penetrated, not through psychoanalysis but through a crucible of human conflict, action, gesture and expressive facial tones.

title: Bad Taste
review: A climatic rebirth-by-chainsaw scene almost makes it all worthwhile, though you may have had to visit the bathroom once or twice in the wait.

title: Duck Soup
review: Duck Soup should make practically everybody laugh.

title: Duck Soup
review: The Marx Brothers' best movie...

title: Duck Soup
review: It also includes what is perhaps the Brothers' funniest scene ever: an immaculately timed and performed sequence with a broken mirror in which Groucho, Chico and Harpo look absolutely identical. A masterpiece.

title: Duck Soup
review: This production is, for the most part, extremely noisy without being nearly as mirthful as [the Marx brothers'] other films.

title: Duck Soup
review: The Marx Brothers created a body of work in which individual films are like slices from the whole, but Duck Soup (1933) is probably the best.

title: Better Off Dead...
review: The film doesn't seem to have much of a focus. But it doesn't seem to want one, either.

title: The Shining
review: A masterpiece.

title: The Shining
review: Kubrick has made a movie that will have to be reckoned with on the highest level.

title: The Shining
review: As a ghost story and adaptation of the Stephen King novel, it's largely a failure. On the other hand, as an example of directorial bravura and as a study of madness and the unreliable narrator, it's a brilliant success.

title: The Shining
review: Kubrick is after a cool, sunlit vision of hell, born in the bosom of the nuclear family, but his imagery -- with its compulsive symmetry and brightness -- is too banal to sustain interest, while the incredibly slack narrative line forestalls suspense.

title: The Shining
review: The movie is not about ghosts but about madness and the energies it sets loose in an isolated situation primed to magnify them.

title: The Shining
review: With everything to work with, director Stanley Kubrick has teamed with jumpy Jack Nicholson to destroy all that was so terrifying about Stephen King's bestseller.

title: The Shining
review: I fear all work and no play has made Stanley a dull boy.

title: The Shining
review: Kubrick isn't out for screams, but he manages to make his movie thoroughly unnerving by keeping the horror so close to home.

title: Evil Dead II
review: Just when things start getting too grisly, Raimi rushes in with a hilarious, sendup joke to remind us that all this blood and guts is meant in spooky Grand Guignol fun.

title: Evil Dead II
review: Evil Dead 2 is, pardon the expression, consistently lively -- a ghoulish splatter comedy that uses wildly excessive gore to provoke the kind of shock that lies between a laugh and a scream.

title: Evil Dead II
review: Good acting would not have served the material well, since it would have diluted the comedy quotient and made the campy elements seem cheap and cheesy.

title: Evil Dead II
review: A flashy good-natured display of special effects and scare tactics so extreme they can only be taken for laughs.

title: Evil Dead II
review: The pop-up humor and smirkiness suggest Raimi's aspiring to the fashionable company of the brothers Coen, though on the basis of this strained effort I'd say he's overshot the mark.

title: Evil Dead II
review: Delirious, demented and diabolically funny.

title: Evil Dead II
review: Genuine, if bizarre, proof of Sam Raimi's talent and developing skill.

title: Evil Dead II
review: If you know it's all special effects, and if you've seen a lot of other movies and have a sense of humor, you might have a great time at Evil Dead 2.

title: Evil Dead II
review: The acting is straight out of '50s B movies. The exposition is clumsy, the sound track corny, the denouement silly. Then again, who said bad taste was easy?

title: The Deer Hunter
review: Is it as good as its advance word and nine Academy Award nominations suggest? Yes.

title: The Deer Hunter
review: This excruciatingly violent, three-hour Viet Nam saga demolishes the moral and ideological cliches of an era: it shoves the audience into hell and leaves it stranded without a map.

title: The Deer Hunter
review: The film is ambitious and it succeeds on a number of levels and it proves that Cimino is an important director who deserves to be watched carefully.

title: The Deer Hunter
review: A disgusting account of what the evil Vietnamese did to poor, innocent Americans stands at the center of this Oscar-laden weepie about macho buddies from a small industrial town.

title: The Deer Hunter
review: This is probably one of the few great films of the decade.

title: The Deer Hunter
review: It is a heartbreakingly effective fictional machine that evokes the agony of the Vietnam time.

title: The Deer Hunter
review: Its feelings for time, place and blue-collar people are genuine, and its vision is that of an original, major new film maker.

title: Diva
review: The movie's a maelstrom of possibilities touching ethnic relations, high art, fashion and modern morality, not to mention cinema.

title: Diva
review: As with so many pop moments a quarter-century on, what once looked sexy now smells a little sexist.

title: Diva
review: Diva, as a lifestyle, a fantasy, a model for alienation and solipsism and eccentricity, has gone deep into all of us.

title: Diva
review: An elaborate, subtitled exercise in blowing hot air.

title: Diva
review: A light-headed, fleet-footed French caper, Jean-Jacques Beineix's ultra-stylish Diva stormed the art houses when it was released in 1982, and it's still a lot of fun now -- though its hip patina feels more quaint these days than cool.

title: Diva
review: I still loved every minute of it.

title: Diva
review: Made with wit and humor, this French stunner abounds in the go-for-broke spirit of a first film made by a talented, nervy director.

title: Diva
review: This is style as a force of nature.

title: Diva
review: It's a supremely gorgeous and supremely shallow motion picture, but it believes in art with a capital A. And practically nobody does anymore.

title: Diva
review: Any film with this much stylistic assurance is impossible to fully resist.

title: Diva
review: The novel touches, bizarre chases and plot twists, breathtaking camerawork by Philippe Rousselot and tension-filled editing, make Diva a superior piece of entertainment.

title: Diva
review: Half a century later, a glut of uber-groovy meta-thrillers has blunted the novelty of Diva, but its gamboling flair is still a kick.

title: Diva
review: The most exciting debut in years, it is unified by the extraordinary decor - colour supplement chic meets pop art surrealism - which creates a world of totally fantastic reality situated four-square in contemporary Paris.

title: Diva
review: Here is a director taking audacious chances, doing wild and unpredictable things with his camera and actors, just to celebrate moviemaking.

title: Diva
review: ...frightfully chic-looking...

title: Groundhog Day
review: Groundhog Day may not be the funniest collaboration between Bill Murray and director Harold Ramis... Yet this gentle, small-scale effort is easily the most endearing film of both men's careers, a sweet and amusing surprise package.

title: Groundhog Day
review: Murray hasn't made a comedy this winningly dumb and smart and -- yes -- sweet in a long time. If, indeed, he ever has.

title: Groundhog Day
review: A movie that continually replays a single day could quickly become tedious but, strangely enough, Groundhog Day never does.

title: Groundhog Day
review: Murray's wiseacre persona is perfect for what could be saccharine material in other hands.

title: Groundhog Day
review: Even if you applaud Bill Murray's evolution from inspired comedian to minimalist seriocomic actor, it's a relief to revisit his most varied and charming role as Phil Connors.

title: Groundhog Day
review: Bill Murray is the one veteran of the Saturday Night Live/SCTV axis who still knows how to enter into a giddy conspiracy with his audience.

title: Groundhog Day
review: Considering that none of the characters is fresh or interesting, it's a commendable achievement that the quality of the storytelling alone keeps the movie watchable and likable.

title: Groundhog Day
review: [Murray] carries Groundhog Day with his uniquely frittery nonchalance and makes the movie a comic time warp anyone should be happy to get stuck in.

title: Groundhog Day
review: Ramis' direction is often too cool and restrained. He wisely avoids playing into the tale's underlying sentimentality.

title: Groundhog Day
review: Since arriving as a mild success in 1993, Groundhog Day has gradually achieved the status of beloved. The American Film Institute rates it No.34 on its list of all-time funniest movies, and it's a story that bears frequent repeat viewings.

title: Groundhog Day
review: Ramis directs this surreal suburban fantasy with an admirably light touch, revelling in its absurd repetitions, surprising us with narrative ellipses, and allowing Murray ample space to indulge his special mix of sarcasm and smarm.

title: Groundhog Day
review: Mr. Murray is back in top form with a clever, varied role that draws upon the full range of his talents.

title: Groundhog Day
review: Groundhog will never be designated a national film treasure by the Library of Congress. But, in terms of vehicle selection, this is one of the better ones Murray has hitched himself to.

title: Groundhog Day
review: The film is lovable and sweet.

title: Groundhog Day
review: This movie has all the qualities necessary to be a crowd-pleaser: likable characters, charismatic performers, a strong, capably-executed premise, and lots of laughs.

title: Groundhog Day
review: ... brilliantly imaginative ...

title: Unforgiven
review: It shouldn't be missed by anyone with a taste for Eastwood's typically slanted morality. It's the actor/director's best movie -- and the best Western by anybody -- in over 20 years.

title: Unforgiven
review: Unforgiven ain't nuthin' new, y'unnerstan', but it's a good, old-fashioned western-type pitcher with plenty o' rootin' tootin' action 'n' big ol' horses 'n' 10-gallon hats 'n' sech.

title: Unforgiven
review: Eastwood deliberately upends the conventions of the western, subverting his own image in the process.

title: Unforgiven
review: The Western is back. With a vengeance. Saddle up or get out of the way.

title: Unforgiven
review: This is the finest set of performances ever to grace a Clint Eastwood movie, and this time Eastwood even does a good job directing Eastwood. Every bullet in this movie matters.

title: Unforgiven
review: This dark, melancholic film is a reminder-never more necessary than now-of what the American cinema is capable of, in the way of expressing a mature, morally complex and challenging view of the world.

title: Unforgiven
review: Eastwood's meditation on age, repute, courage, heroism -- on all those burdens he has been carrying with such good grace for decades.

title: Unforgiven
review: One of Unforgiven's assets is the way it overturns conventions, taking the man who is typically the hero and making him the villain, while transforming the traditional bad guy into a sympathetic protagonist.

title: Unforgiven
review: A classic Western for the ages.

title: Unforgiven
review: There's not much dramatic urgency apart from the revisionist context.

title: Unforgiven
review: In this dark, timeless terrain, the film achieves a magnificent intensity.

title: Unforgiven
review: Unforgiven is a most entertaining western that pays homage to the great tradition of movie westerns while surreptitiously expressing a certain amount of skepticism.

title: Unforgiven
review: That implacable moral balance, in which good eventually silences evil, is at the heart of the Western, and Eastwood is not shy about saying so.

title: Unforgiven
review: In three decades of climbing into the saddle, Eastwood has never ridden so tall.

title: Unforgiven
review: Jumps adroitly between the macho and anti-macho, the romantic and anti-romantic.

title: Unforgiven
review: By now ... Eastwood has little more than a paint-by-numbers approach to acting. As a result, we relate to Munny more as a compendium of Eastwood's earlier characters.

title: Unforgiven
review: This is the best work Eastwood has done as a director since The Outlaw Josey Wales 16 years ago.

title: Unforgiven
review: Enjoy it for the handsome wide-screen vistas, the interplay of the actors, the classical sweep of its story line. Just don't expect the new, soul-searching Eastwood to be any more dramatically convincing than the old.

title: Pump Up the Volume
review: The perfectly cast Slater effectively propels the film, his intensity and dry delivery giving it a definite edge, as does a soundtrack which includes Ice T, Concrete Blonde and the Cowboy Junkies.

title: Pump Up the Volume
review: It's a howl from the heart, a relentlessly involving movie that gives a kid every reason to believe that he or she can come of age.

title: Arsenic and Old Lace
review: Despite the fact that picture runs 118 minutes, Frank Capra has expanded on the original play [by Joseph Kesselring] to a sufficient extent to maintain a steady, consistent pace.

title: Arsenic and Old Lace
review: The timing is abysmal throughout, turning fast pace into numbing frenzy.

title: Arsenic and Old Lace
review: Good macabre fun.

title: Arsenic and Old Lace
review: Dusty but gentle entertainment.

title: Back to the Future
review: It isn't often that extremely clever moviemakers use their brains in the service of pure fun. But that's just what the people who made Back to the Future have done. This brilliant contraption of a film could become the hit of the summer.

title: Back to the Future
review: It's big, cartoonish and empty, with an interesting premise that is underdeveloped and overproduced.

title: Back to the Future
review: Zemeckis and Gale... give us two priceless scenes in which the young time-traveler simply regards his parents-to-be with wonderment, delight and empathy. And we cannot help but share that emotion and relate it to our own lives.

title: Back to the Future
review: The picture packs a wonderful wallop.

title: Back to the Future
review: Performances by the earnest Fox, the lunatic Lloyd, the deceptively passionate Lea Thompson, and, particularly, the bumbling-to-confident Glover, who runs away with the picture, merrily keep the ship sailing.

title: Back to the Future
review: Director Robert Zemeckis confronts the oedipal heart of the time-travel genre with this zestfully tasteless 1985 tale about a teenager (Michael J. Fox) who is projected back to 1955 and then must arrange the romance of his parents.

title: Back to the Future
review: The movie has all the benign good nature of a Frank Capra.

title: Back to the Future
review: Mr. Zemeckis is able both to keep the story moving and to keep it from going too far. He handles Back to the Future with the kind of inventiveness that indicates he will be spinning funny, whimsical tall tales for a long time to come.

title: Back to the Future
review: So busy being clever that it trips over its own ingenuity.

title: Back to the Future
review: Shows not only a fine comic touch but also some of the lighthearted humanism of a Frank Capra.

title: Back to the Future
review: One of the mid-'80s most enduring and enjoyable confections: an infectious mix of comedy, fantasy, satire, excitement, and nostalgia.

title: Patton
review: George C. Scott's performance cannot be praised highly enough for capturing both the violence and the vulnerability of the Patton personality without degenerating either into vulgar caricature or cardboard sentimentality.

title: Patton
review: War is hell, and Patton is one hell of a war picture, perhaps one of the most remarkable of its type ever made.

title: Patton
review: Nixon's favorite movie, which proves he was blind to ambiguity as well as a few other things.

title: Patton
review: The film lays bare the roots of Patton's lust for power in his willingess to sacrifice everything to his vaunting ego, a trait which is mirrored in George C Scott's superb performance.

title: Patton
review: It's both fascinating and appalling the sort of extravagant technically superior spectacle that only a big Hollywood movie company could afford to make, and the story of a man about whom only the Establishment could become genuinely sentimental.

title: Patton
review: Scott strikes an unforgettable figure.

title: Patton
review: Scott's theatricality is electrifying.

title: Patton
review: Remains to this day one of Hollywood's most compelling biographical war pictures.

title: Down by Law
review: The Jim Jarmusch penchant for off-the-wall characters and odd situations is very much in evidence.

title: Down by Law
review: On the whole I've had more fun in Cleveland.

title: Down by Law
review: After the initial establishment of character and atmosphere, the laughs come thick and fast, most notably from the marvellous [Roberto] Benigni.

title: Down by Law
review: The excitement (of Down by Law) comes from the realization that we are seeing a true film maker at work, using film to create a narrative that couldn't exist on the stage or the printed page of a novel.

title: Down by Law
review: A true original that kind of grows on you.

title: Down by Law
review: Pure pleasure for comedy connoisseurs.

title: Down by Law
review: It's not that the movie doesn't move fast enough, it's that while it dawdles, it doesn't give you enough to dwell on.

title: Akira
review: Pounding away, it becomes monotonous.

title: Akira
review: A compendium of the worst cliches of Japanese animation -- two hours of chases, laser attacks, machine-gun battles, spilled stage blood, computer-animated backgrounds and hokey dialogue.

title: Akira
review: The movie, even at 124 minutes, has the densely packed sweep and go-for-it pep of a pop epic.

title: Akira
review: Grade-school violence freaks may find a few kicks here, but even they may have trouble coping with this ugly movie's ending about eight separate times.

title: Akira

title: Akira
review: An impressive achievement, often suggesting a weird expressionist blend of 2001, The Warriors, Blade Runner and Forbidden Planet.

title: Akira
review: A phenomenal work of animation with all the hallmarks of an instant cult classic.

title: Akira
review: Easily the most breathtaking and kinetic anime ever made.

title: Akira
review: The most expensive animated feature ever made in Japan... and it's easily the most impressive, as well.

title: Highlander
review: Lambert, with his beetle brow, broken nose, and vaguely crossed eyes, remains an amiable oddball presence, and Sean Connery radiates charm and nobility in a bit as an elder immortal who shows Lambert the rules of the game.

title: Highlander
review: It's a lot of utterly preposterous fun, even if it doesn't quite hang together.

title: Highlander
review: Since none of the characters makes sense even on the movie's own terms, Highlander keeps on exploding for almost two hours, with nothing at stake.

title: Cool Hand Luke
review: Stuart Rosenberg's direction is a horror, but the cast teems with so many familiar faces that this 1967 film can't help but entertain.

title: Cool Hand Luke
review: A picture of chilling dramatic power.

title: Cool Hand Luke
review: Newman gives an excellent performance, assisted by a terriffic supporting cast, including George Kennedy, outstanding as the unofficial leader of the cons who yields first place to Newman.

title: Cool Hand Luke
review: A caustically witty look at the American South and its still-surviving chain gangs, with Newman in fine sardonic form as the boss-baiter who refuses to submit and becomes a hero to his fellow-prisoners.

title: Cool Hand Luke
review: A tough, honest film with backbone.

title: Cool Hand Luke
review: It's as fresh and effective in 2004 as it was in 1967.

title: Cool Hand Luke
review: That traditional object of sorrow and compassion in American folk song and lore, the chain-gang prisoner, is given as strong a presentation as ever he has had on the screen.

title: Cyrano de Bergerac
review: Audiences, traditionally willing to meet this impossibly romantic classic half way, may have to go a bit further this time.

title: Cyrano de Bergerac
review: Withal, there is beauty and magic in the things that Cyrano says. He is still a magnificent character. Thank goodness, he is on the screen.

title: Cyrano de Bergerac
review: At least some of the lines in the Rostand play are good.

title: Young Frankenstein
review: Wilder's hysteria seems perfectly natural. You never question what's driving him to it; his fits are lucid and total. They take him into a different dimension -- he delivers what Harpo promised.

title: Young Frankenstein
review: More about the myth of Karloff than the monster, this Mel Brooks pastiche is probably his best early film.

title: Young Frankenstein
review: For a really delightful parody, James Whale's own Bride of Frankenstein is far better value.

title: Young Frankenstein
review: It shows artistic growth and a more sure-handed control of the material by a director who once seemed willing to do literally anything for a laugh. It's more confident and less breathless.

title: Young Frankenstein
review: Some of the gags don't work, but fewer than in any previous Brooks film that I've seen, and when the jokes are meant to be bad, they are riotously poor. What more can one ask of Mel Brooks?

title: Young Frankenstein
review: Young Frankenstein emerges as a reverently satirical salute to the 1930s horror film genre.

title: Night on Earth

title: Night on Earth
review: With this, his fourth commercially released feature, Mr. Jarmusch again demonstrates his mastery of comedy of the oblique.

title: Night on Earth
review: At the end, we have learned no great lessons and arrived at no thrilling conclusions, but we have shared the community of the night, when people are unbuttoned and vulnerable - more ready to speak about what's really on their minds.

title: Night on Earth
review: Unfortunately, Jarmusch's lackadaisical minimalist aesthetic and his chronic lack of energy are the only unifying elements.

title: Night on Earth
review: "Night on Earth" sounds better than it turns out to be.

title: Night on Earth
review: Night on Earth dawdles a bit, and a couple of the segments, notably the one in Helsinki, feel like half-baked epiphanies. Throughout, though, there are moments that catch you delightfully off guard.

title: Da hong deng long gao gao gua

title: Da hong deng long gao gao gua
review: A beautifully crafted and richly detailed feat of consciousness-raising and a serious drama with the verve of a good soap opera.

title: Da hong deng long gao gao gua
review: Gong Li delivers a performance of exquisite expressiveness that, like the film itself, is unnerving in its emotional nakedness.

title: Da hong deng long gao gao gua
review: A near-perfect movie that often recalls the visual purity and intensity of silent films.

title: Da hong deng long gao gao gua
review: In purely aesthetic terms, Raise the Red Lantern is breathtaking.

title: Da hong deng long gao gao gua
review: The story never amounts to much more than a rather tepid Chinese rendition of The Women.

title: Da hong deng long gao gao gua
review: A defining example of Chinese movie-making and one of the best films of the '90s.

title: Da hong deng long gao gao gua
review: A Chinese film of voluptuous physical beauty and angry passions.

title: The Great Dictator
review: The first full-blown talkie from the biggest star of the silent era, complete with a message that Chaplin couldn't have sent more loudly or clearly.

title: The Great Dictator
review: Through no fault of Chaplin's, during the two years he was at work on the picture dictators became too sinister for comedy.

title: The Great Dictator
review: Chaplin is at his most profound in suggesting that there is much of the Tramp in the Dictator, and much of the Dictator in the Tramp.

title: The Great Dictator
review: Like all major Chaplin works, Dictator was a cheaply, but methodically, made film, a cardboard act of humanist defiance, and, thanks to its purity of purpose, the cheesier the jokes get, the harder they land.

title: The Great Dictator
review: It's when he is playing the dictator that the comedian's voice raises the value of the comedy content of the picture to great heights.

title: The Great Dictator
review: The representation of Hitler is vaudeville goonery all the way, but minus the acid wit and inventive energy that Groucho Marx managed.

title: The Great Dictator
review: It is a funny film, which we expect from Chaplin, and a brave one.

title: The Great Dictator
review: The film remains controversial to this day.

title: The Great Dictator
review: Now that the waiting is over and the shivers of suspense at an end, let the trumpets be sounded and the banners flung against the sky.

title: The Great Dictator
review: It's easy to forget the sheer cojones Charles Chaplin showed when he attacked Adolf Hitler in this 1940 satire.

title: Fantasia
review: The words most used to describe "Fantasia," besides the conventional "beautiful" and "wonderful" were "path-breaking" and "courageous." The phrase "courageous beyond belief" would be even more accurate.

title: Fantasia
review: Critics may deplore Disney's lapses of taste, but he trips, Mickey-like, into an art form that immortals from Aeschylus to Richard Wagner have always dreamed of.

title: Fantasia
review: There is something in Fantasia for every taste.

title: Fantasia
review: The concept and some of the episodes are tainted with kitsch, but there's no other animated film with its scope and ambition.

title: Fantasia
review: Certainly not to be missed.

title: Fantasia
review: Fantasia is simply terrific -- as terrific as anything that has ever happened on a screen.

title: Fantasia
review: This is animation in every sense of the word, as if you are seeing the world through the eyes of your tree-worshipping ancestors.

title: Fantasia
review: Throughout Fantasia, Disney pushes the edges of the envelope.

title: High Noon
review: High Noon combines its points about good citizenship with some excellent picturemaking.

title: High Noon
review: Zinnemann carefully and deliberately makes the most of the mood cast by the threat of impending violence.

title: High Noon
review: Some of the results ring false, but the memorable theme song and some equally memorable character acting (by Thomas Mitchell and Lon Chaney Jr. more than Lloyd Bridges and Katy Jurado) help things along.

title: High Noon
review: High Noon won a fistful of Oscars, but in these days of pasteboard screen machismo, it's worth seeing simply as the anatomy of what it took to make a man before the myth turned sour.

title: High Noon
review: More than a half-century later, Foreman was right after all: High Noon is a scorching and sour portrait of American complacence and capacity for collaborationism.

title: High Noon
review: Regarded as '50s melodrama, it's nearly perfect.

title: High Noon
review: Meaningful in its implications, as well as loaded with interest and suspense, High Noon is a western to challenge Stagecoach for the all-time championship.

title: High Noon
review: The Western may be one of the few truly American art forms, and High Noon shows exactly how much potential it can embrace.

title: The Big Sleep
review: The Big Sleep is wakeful fare for folks who don't care what is going on, or why, so long as the talk is hard and the action harder.

title: The Big Sleep
review: The Big Sleep, though, is witty and sinister, and in an odd way is a realistic portrayal of big-city life with Arabian Nights overtones.

title: The Big Sleep
review: Brittle Chandler characters have been transferred to the screen with punch by Howard Hawks' production and direction, providing full load of rough, tense action most of the way.

title: The Big Sleep
review: What you remember here are moments.

title: The Big Sleep
review: This is arguably the high-water mark of Hollywood's love affair with the infinitely slippery possibilities of the English language.

review: A super-smart black comedy about high school politics and teenage suicide that showcases a host of promising young talents.

title: Heathers
review: Two decades later, Heathers is so on the money, with its vague but unmistakable parallels to several school shootings, that it could never be made today.

review: A super-smart black comedy about high school politics and teenage suicide that showcases a host of promising young talents.

review: Its inanities and glib pretensions are so thick that it mainly comes across as tacky and contrived.

title: Heathers
review: As snappy and assured as it is mean-spirited.

review: Lighter and less filling than usual.

title: Gandhi

review: Well-constructed crowd-pleaser.

review: [A] gooey fable.

review: The original is still creepy, but this Horror will have fans jumping in their seats and talking back to the screen.
