review: Beneath all of this elaborate feather bedlam lies a Hitch cock-and-bull story that's essentially a fowl ball.

review: Whale's most perfectly realised movie, a delight from start to finish.

review: The film's spooky atmosphere is accentuated by Anthony B. Richmond's cinematography and Philip Glass's score.

review: It's all good scary fun.

review: Still stands on its own as an intriguing and chilling example of how horror works best when the characters and the audience don't have to be lobotomized.

review: A masterpiece of the German silent cinema and easily the most effective version of Dracula on record.

title: Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens
review: Murnau's classic vampire movie, though not his best film, remains one of the most poetic of all horror films.

title: Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens
review: As vampire movies go, few are more memorable than Nosferatu, which is not only the first screen version of Dracula, but, in some ways, remains the best.

title: Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens
review: It doesn't scare us, but it haunts us. It shows not that vampires can jump out of shadows, but that evil can grow there, nourished on death.

title: The Omen
review: Richard Donner directs more for speed than mood, but there are a few good shocks.

title: The Omen
review: Richard Donner's direction is taut. Players all are strong.

title: The Omen
review: This apocalyptic movie mostly avoids physical gore to boost its relatively unoriginal storyline with suspense, some excellent acting (especially from Warner and Whitelaw), and a very deft, incident-packed script.

title: The Omen
review: A member of the Exorcist family, it is a dreadfully silly film, which is not to say that it is totally bad.

title: The Omen
review: As long as movies like The Omen are merely scaring us, they're fun in a portentous sort of way.

title: Blood and Wine
review: An amusingly caustic, straight-up serving of film noir staples spiced with star charisma.

title: Blood and Wine
review: An engrossing thriller - and one sparkling with intelligence, with the surprising twists grounded in credible human behaviour.

title: Blood and Wine
review: When Bob Rafelson decides to get nasty, he really means it.

title: Blood and Wine
review: It's a morality play, really, but dripping with humid sex and violence.

title: Blood and Wine
review: The movie's own payoff is compelling enough, but the project has a weightless feel that limits involvement. Better you give it an hour-and-a-half on video someday, surrounded by wine and snacks.

title: Blood and Wine
review: Rafelson is so true to his sour vision of crime, deception and a rottenness at the core of our natures -- he's as cheerful as a Jim Thompson potboiler -- that we never get a chance to like or care about his characters.

title: Blood and Wine
review: Nicholson is good, but the movie isn't.

title: Albino Alligator
review: Pretentious and show-offy, the noirish drama fairly reeks of film-student overkill.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: The punchy, nonstop visual effects crowd out coherent storytelling.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: For a good hour and change, the film is a big toy box that teases you out of the Gloom.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: It has a refreshing Old World take on a never-ending fantasy war between vampires and the forces of 'light.'

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: What a rabid beast is Night Watch. What a pungent Russian fantasy-horror cheeseathon.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: This mostly incoherent, enormously eccentric helping of mayhem breaks into so many fragments that watching the movie can be a bit like trying to assemble the pieces from several jigsaw puzzles.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: Night Watch was one of the most popular movies ever released in Russia. That just proves there's no accounting for taste, in film or in human sacrifice.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: Goth thrill-junkies will probably get a giddy charge out of this overheated fantasy. The rest of us can have an equivalent experience by putting our brains in a blender and hitting puree.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: Clarity may be lost, but rare is the movie that grabs viewers by their throats and never lets go. Bekmambetov's Night Watch is one of the grabbers.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: The faux mythology may be cheesy, the grandiose plot stretched thin and full of holes, but underneath the recycled story and style is a hint of something troubling and real.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: Even though you couldn't call it a great science fiction movie, on the level of Tarkovsky's Solaris and Stalker it's often a great, heart-pumping, blow-you- to-the walls movie experience.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: While the movie's inspirations might be glam-Hollywood action fantasies, Night Watch fairly wallows in damp, post-Soviet decay.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: Though Night Watch is impressive at creating atmosphere, the movie is an impenetrable narrative tangle with plot strands running in every direction.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: If [Director] Bekmambetov had any skill in actually telling a story, his kitchen-sink trilogy would be something to celebrate. It presently qualifies as a dubious achievement.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: Although it doesn't have Kate Beckinsale, her guns ablazin', vamped out in the latest vampire-slaying couture, Night Watch is vastly more fun than the similar-themed Underworld pics.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: Night Watch works better as a demo reel for the state of Russian effects work than as a first installment in an epic trilogy.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: Unfortunately, by Hollywood standards, Night Watch is about three Wookies and two Neos short of convincing. All the gobbledygook is in place, but the special effects are minimal and somewhat frustrating.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: The original plan was to remake Night Watch in English, and then thought was given to dubbing it. Thankfully both ideas were scuttled, as the film's Russian-ness and its allusions to post-communist fears and frustrations add greatly to its appeal.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: Night Watch is shabby chic, with hints of Russia's great silent-cinema past.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: Ultimately, it's a formulaic, predictable take on a Hollywood staple: the vampire horror film. That's a pretty tired genre, no matter what language it's told in.

title: Nochnoy dozor
review: As opposed to the dreary domestic dramas that are [Russian] cinema's stock in trade, this one is a full-stops-out fantasia that is often disgustingly gloppy and looks as if it was birthed by the Wachowski brothers and Quentin Tarantino.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: In zooming out from Picard's glinty eyeball, this eighth feature film from the Trek factory displays a zippy new energy and a sleek, confident style fully independent of its predecessors.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: First Contact is no grab bag of camp gewgaws; it stands proud and apart, accessible even to the Trek-deficient. This old Star, it seems, has a lot of life in it.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: The elegance of the story is enhanced by the sure direction of Jonathan Frakes, who also plays Commander William Riker.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: A smashingly exciting sci-fi adventure that ranks among the very best in the long-running Paramount franchise.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: This makes little concession to non-initiates.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: The series now lacks all of its original stars and much of its earlier determination. It has morphed into something less innocent and more derivative than it used to be, something the noncultist is ever less likely to enjoy.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: The excitement comes from Frakes's direction.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: A nicely constructed science-fiction film, with a simple premise, a charismatic villain and a good back-story to enhance the action.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: Blessed with clever plot devices and a villainous horde that makes the once-dread Klingons seem like a race of Barneys, First Contact does everything you'd want a Star Trek film to do, and it does it with cheerfulness and style.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: The first stretch and the home stretch are so filled with visual interest and, more importantly, with the patented Star Trek philosophical and humorous tidbits that fans will gladly suffer the dull Borg patch for the pleasure of the rest.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: While First Contact espouses the usual lofty Trek ideals, it never forgets to factor in the fun. As the Borg likes to say, resistance is futile -- and also unnecessary.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: Star Trek: First Contact is one of the best of the eight Star Trek films: Certainly the best in its technical credits, and among the best in the ingenuity of its plot.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: Following in the wake of a trio of disappointing features, First Contact proves to be the most entertaining Star Trek in more than a decade.

title: Star Trek: First Contact
review: A thoroughly enjoyable visit with the crew of TV's Star Trek: The Next Generation.

title: Shine
review: Shine has a story to reckon with and powerhouse male performances.

title: Sling Blade
review: A masterpiece of Southern storytelling.

title: Sling Blade
review: An abundance of long, flat medium shots that rob the film of intimacy and give it a sleepy pace.

title: Sling Blade
review: A mesmerizing parable of good and evil and a splendid example of Southern storytelling at its most poetic and imaginative.

title: Sling Blade
review: If there were the slightest justice and curiosity in the Academy Award process, Thornton's work here would get a nomination.

title: Sling Blade
review: In Sling Blade, Thornton lays claim to the title of hyphenate of the year.

title: Sling Blade
review: The lure of Sling Blade is both elemental and hauntingly familiar, and I would not be surprised if Thornton's breakthrough film is one day considered a classic in its own right.

title: Sling Blade
review: A fine motion picture.

title: Sling Blade
review: [Thornton] does wonders with Yoakam, who could have played a standard villain but always manages to suggest a man trapped within his prejudices.

title: Sling Blade
review: By its midpoint, however, Thornton has begun forcing both the film's poetry and the preternatural goodness of its simple-minded protagonist, and Sling Blade's sweet charms begin to curdle.

title: Sling Blade
review: All the actors in Sling Blade do magnificent work, but it's Thornton who stays with you for days.

title: Sling Blade
review: Sling Blade takes you down paths full of primitive, almost biblical implications, but it also finds comic relief in moments of palpable tension.

title: Sling Blade
review: [Thornton] performance is so good that his directing may be slighted.

title: Jingle All the Way
review: In this formulaic star vehicle, Schwarzenegger gets to fly like Peter Pan, act like Superman--and fulfill all the fantasies kids may have about their fathers.

title: Jingle All the Way
review: I liked a lot of the movie, which is genial and has a lot of energy, but I was sort of depressed by its relentlessly materialistic view of Christmas, and by the choice to go with action and (mild) violence over dialogue and plot.

title: Jingle All the Way
review: Here's Arnie, of all people, playing a bedraggled suburbanite, and his perversely amusing casting boosts a crass, sometimes nasty and finally funny celebration of holiday mass-merchandising and greed.

title: The Preacher's Wife
review: There are many good reasons for going to see The Preacher's Wife.

title: The Preacher's Wife
review: The Preacher's Wife qualifies as old-fashioned Hollywood movie making at its corniest and most saccharine. But the mostly African American cast puts an engaging spin on the chestnut, and it works beautifully.

title: The Preacher's Wife
review: For a movie that might have offered a new twist of the mistletoe, The Preacher's Wife delivers the Scrooge-like acceptable market minimum.

title: The Preacher's Wife
review: The Preacher's Wife is one Christmas picture that actually is in the spirit of the season. It's warm, sentimental, amusing yet serious, bringing fantasy to bear upon the painfully real.

title: The Preacher's Wife
review: A welcome boost for audiences seeking images of black characters without criminal tendencies.

title: The Preacher's Wife
review: This movie could have done more, but what it does, it makes you feel good about.

title: The Preacher's Wife
review: Penny Marshall's remake of The Bishop's Wife is very uneven -- sometimes sweet or soulful, often stiff.

title: The Preacher's Wife
review: If not for the pervasive spirit of the season, something like this could easily send me into sugar shock. It's a little too nice and happy.

title: The Preacher's Wife
review: As warm and cheery as a mug of hot cocoa on a frosty morn.

title: Ridicule
review: Audiences will respond favorably to its overall warmth, and the motion picture academy may, too.

title: The Crucible
review: Then there's always Mr. Scofield, bringing an almost unbearable, yet entirely believable, lightness of spirit to his loathsome character. It's a bold stroke by a great actor, making zealotry and evil seem positively beneficent.

title: The Crucible
review: I recommend Hytner's movie highly, but a part of me resists a work that makes the audience feel as noble in our moral certainty as the characters it invites us to deplore. Some part of its power seems borrowed from the thing it hates.

title: The Crucible
review: Her cheeks flush, her winsome beauty seared with erotic rage, Ryder exposes the real roots of the piece. Forget McCarthyism; The Crucible is a colonial Fatal Attraction.

title: The Crucible
review: Too bad, though, that The Crucible fails to probe deeper into the sexual, religious, and political conditions that can give false accusations so much power -- even today.

title: The Crucible
review: I very much admire how Hytner... keeps the pace swift and doesn't fetishize the 17th-century decors and clothes. But I can't help feeling that in more ways than one, The Crucible is a period piece.

title: The Crucible
review: What happened in long-ago Salem does still seem to matter.

title: The Crucible
review: Handsome and well-acted, the film's ultimate success depends on the heat between Ryder and Day-Lewis, and it simply isn't there. The attraction is fatal alright, but it certainly doesn't seem mutual.

title: The Crucible
review: Neither the establishing dramatic linchpin nor the final conversion of conscience is terribly convincing, leaving this pared-down rendition of the original work diminished in power and meaning as well.

title: The Crucible
review: Hytner holds the action together with solid, unflashy, well-paced direction, ensuring that this is no mere period piece but a compelling, pertinent account of human fear, frailty and cold ambition.

title: The Crucible
review: Nothing in the movie is quite up to Scofield's Danforth. But what a mighty performance that is!

title: The Crucible
review: Day-Lewis, Ryder and Scofield will be odds-on favorites for Oscar nominations, as will the movie itself.

title: The Crucible
review: There's an awful, piercing truth in the performances of Daniel Day-Lewis, Winona Ryder, Joan Allen and Paul Scofield as members of a community destroyed by guilt, paranoia and betrayal.

title: The Crucible
review: This stirring film lets you feel the heat of Miller's argument and the urgent power of his kick.

title: The Crucible
review: Despite these involving moments, The Crucible finally seems too schematic, more useful as an allegory than as drama, and possibly owing that undoubted popularity to its simplistic qualities as much as its insights into group psychology.

title: The Crucible
review: With a head on its shoulders and the rawest emotions in its craw, Arthur Miller's stage hit The Crucible has become a cinematic grabber for grown-ups -- without that castor oil taste.

title: The Crucible
review: This version illuminates the story's numerous strengths, resulting in a motion picture of surprising emotional and intellectual impact.

title: The Crucible
review: Though Hytner remains essentially a stage director, he makes fine use of Massachusetts locations and period interiors; some of the visual details recall Dreyer's Day of Wrath, a film that likely had an influence on Miller's play

title: The Crucible
review: The first scene in "The Crucible'' strikes the first wrong note.

title: One Hundred and One Dalmatians
review: It is the wittiest, most charming, least pretentious cartoon feature Walt Disney has ever made.

title: One Hundred and One Dalmatians
review: While not as indelibly enchanting or inspired as some of the studio's most unforgettable animated endeavors, this is nonetheless a painstaking creative effort.

title: One Hundred and One Dalmatians
review: This was the last Disney animated feature (1961) that Uncle Walt lived to see through personally; it can't be a coincidence that it's also the last Disney animated feature of real depth and emotional authenticity.

title: One Hundred and One Dalmatians
review: Brilliant entertainment.

title: One Hundred and One Dalmatians
review: A rather clever idea, if a bit unsettling.

title: One Hundred and One Dalmatians
review: If there's one thing that's absolutely first-rate about the film, it's the character of Cruella.

title: Star Trek: The Motion Picture
review: Nothing but a long day's journey into ennui.

title: Star Trek: The Motion Picture
review: The expensive effects (under supervision of Douglas Trumbull) are the secret of this film, and the amazing wizardry throughout would appear to justify the whopping budget.

title: Star Trek: The Motion Picture
review: This 1979 movie adaptation of the cult TV series is blandness raised to an epic scale.

title: Star Trek: The Motion Picture
review: For non-addicts, the smart plot and effects go some way towards compensating for the plastic characters and costumes.

title: Star Trek: The Motion Picture
review: [It's] like attending your high-school class's 10th reunion at Caesar's Palace. Most of the faces are familiar, but the decor has little relationship to anything you've ever seen before.

title: Star Trek: The Motion Picture
review: Star Trek - The Motion Picture: Director's Edition is no 2001 (its obvious inspiration -- a fact that is more evident here than ever before), but it represents thought-provoking, well constructed science fiction.

title: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country
review: Weighed down by a midsection even flabbier than the long-in-the-tooth cast, director Nicholas Meyer still delivers enough of what Trek auds hunger for to justify the trek to the local multiplex.

title: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country
review: Though patchy, this is a lot more fun than the disastrous Star Trek V.

title: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country
review: The principals' enthusiasm for their material has never seemed to fade. If anything, that enthusiasm grows more appealingly nutty with time.

title: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country
review: Director/coscripter Nicholas Meyer moves this vehicle efficiently. He employs some tremendous visuals.

title: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country
review: If, indeed, Star Trek VI turns out to be the last of the series, it couldn't have made a more felicitous or more satisfying exit.

title: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country
review: For a movie that begins with such promise, The Undiscovered Country ends with a whimper.

title: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier
review: William Shatner's inauspicious feature directing debut is a double letdown.

title: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier
review: [The] special effects, despite the hefty budget, look strictly bargain basement.

title: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier
review: The plot, about a quest for the Ultimate Answer, resembles something Douglas Adams would have thrown in the bin.

title: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier
review: Captain Kirk and his crew go where too many film makers have too often gone before.

title: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier
review: Bloated, bombastic and maddeningly pretentious.

title: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier
review: The whole point of the movie has something to do with the search for God and Eden, but the theme is presented in the most mundane fashion imaginable.

title: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier
review: A snoozola of astronomic proportions.

title: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier
review: Of all of the Star Trek movies, this is the worst.

title: Star Trek: The Wrath of Khan
review: There is something comfortable, even old-shoeish, about the new film, a sense, appropriate to its theme of coming to terms with middle age, that all aboard are pleasurably rediscovering their best selves.

title: Star Trek: The Wrath of Khan
review: Star Trek II is a very satisfying space adventure, closer in spirit and format to the popular TV series than to its big-budget predecessor.

title: Star Trek: The Wrath of Khan
review: If only director Nicholas Meyer had grasped the implications of his tale more fully and enthusiastically, this might have become a classic piece of cornball SF poetry, but as it stands the tepid acting and one-set claustrophobia take a heavy toll.

title: Star Trek: The Wrath of Khan
review: The net effect, between embarrassed guffaws, is incredulity: a movie at once post-TV and pre-DW Griffith.

title: Star Trek: The Wrath of Khan
review: Although I liked the special effects in the first movie, they were probably not the point; fans of the TV series wanted to see their favorite characters again, and Trek II understood that desire and acted on it.

title: Star Trek: The Wrath of Khan
review: Here comes a sequel that's worth its salt. The second Star Trek movie is swift, droll and adventurous, not to mention appealingly gadget-happy. It's everything the first one should have been and wasn't.

title: Star Trek: The Wrath of Khan
review: Star Trek II added hefty doses of action, adventure, and suspense, injecting life into a concept that had been left moribund by its first big-screen feature.

title: Star Trek III: The Search for Spock
review: These are classic directorial occasions, and Nimoy rises to them with fervor, in effect beaming his film up onto a higher pictorial plane than either of its predecessors.

title: Star Trek III: The Search for Spock
review: An emotionally satisfying science fiction adventure.

title: Star Trek III: The Search for Spock
review: This 1984 film's few and unimpressive special effects evidently qualify it as science fiction, but the genre it really belongs to is the male weepie: there hasn't been a gooier buddy romance on the screen since Joe Buck took Ratso Rizzo to Miami.

title: Star Trek III: The Search for Spock
review: Decent SFX, but a little more action wouldn't have gone amiss.

title: Star Trek III: The Search for Spock
review: This is a good but not great Star Trek movie, a sort of compromise between the first two.

title: Star Trek III: The Search for Spock
review: The humanity of the Star Trek series, unexpected as it is in a sci-fi setting, remains the series' best feature.

title: Star Trek III: The Search for Spock
review: 'Star Trek III' takes nearly forty minutes, much of which is filled with silly, mystical exposition about the current state of Spock's soul, before things start moving. The last twenty minutes are equally slow, but the stuff in between is quite enjoyable.

title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home
review: Latest excursion is warmer, wittier, more socially relevant and truer to its TV origins than prior odysseys.

title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home
review: I suspect the unconverted will want to be beamed up pronto.

title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home
review: Kirk & Co return to present-day San Francisco to save the whales in the most enjoyable film of the series so far, also returning to the simplistic morality-play format that gave the original TV series its strength.

title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home
review: Mr. Nimoy directed this Star Trek installment, and indeed he should probably direct all of them. His technical expertise leaves much to be desired. But his sincerity is unmistakable, and it counts for a lot.

title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home
review: This is easily the most absurd of the Star Trek stories -- and yet, oddly enough, it is also the best, the funniest and the most enjoyable in simple human terms.

title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home
review: An effective and enjoyable sample of entertainment -- not good science fiction, but a lightweight piece of comic fantasy utilizing characters so familiar that they feel like old friends.

title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home
review: A happy, heartfelt chapter that reunites the original cast with the original TV format, shying away from the cold and epic scale of the preceding movie adventures.

title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home
review: Immensely pleasurable.

title: Batman Returns
review: As Beetlejuice and Edward Scissorhands reminded us, Burton always has been more absorbed by what his audience sees than by what his movies say.

title: Batman Returns
review: Batman Returns is the rarest of Hollywood beasts -- a sequel that's better than the original

title: Batman Returns
review: Burton, once an animator at Disney, understands that to go deeper, you must fly higher, to liberation from plot into poetry. Here he's done it. This Batman soars.

title: Batman Returns
review: As in the first movie, Burton gives the material a luxurious masked-ball quality and a sly contemporary wit without violating the myth's low, cheesy comic-book origins.

title: Batman Returns
review: Burton and company return to the prickly humor that gave such a jolt to the earlier film -- frequently finding it in unexpected places.

title: Batman Returns
review: This time the richness of the Batman movie is not in its production design but rather in Burton's and screenwriter Daniel Waters' Freudian view of adult human behavior.

title: Batman Returns
review: Something about the filmmaker's eccentric, surreal, childlike images seems to strike a deep chord in the mass psyche: he makes nightmares that taste like candy.

title: Batman Returns
review: Exhaustingly inventive.

title: Batman Returns
review: More of the same, but nowhere near as good (funny, disturbing, obsessive) as the uneven original, revealing arrested development on every level.

title: Batman Returns
review: Where Burton's ideas end and those of his collaborators begin is impossible to know, but result is a seamless, utterly consistent universe full of nasty notions about societal deterioration, greed and other base impulses.

title: Batman Returns
review: Bigger, louder, more relentlessly action-packed than its predecessor, Batman Returns batters its audience into submission.

title: Batman Returns
review: Because the film's predominant motif is that of wounded individuals re-inventing themselves as wily villains, its most memorable episodes are early ones explaining each main character's transformation.

title: Batman Returns
review: Burton uses the summer's most explosively entertaining movie to lead us back into the liberating darkness of dreams.

title: Batman Returns
review: Like a hyperactive 11-year-old, the director seems both uncomfortable with adult emotions and unable to focus on the overall portrait.

title: Batman Returns
review: Comes closer than ever to Bob Kane's dark, original strip, which began in 1939.

title: Batman Returns
review: Odd and sad, but not exhilarating.

title: Young Guns
review: Christopher Cain directed this western from a script by John Fusco, and on the whole seems much more comfortable with the scroungy and scatological dialogue than he does with the action sequences.

title: Young Guns
review: Little more than a flawed romp, but energetic and enjoyable, with sterling performances from Sutherland and Estevez.

title: Young Guns
review: Young Guns is best watched in the playful, none-too-serious spirit in which it was made.

title: Young Guns
review: They behave as if our adoration were their birthright.

title: Grease
review: The screenplay is a prepubescent shambles, the direction is by acne out of disposable douches, the dubbing and looping of the songs is painfully obvious, the characterizations are generally repulsive and the whole thing is utterly without style.

title: Grease
review: Travolta is a riot. Alternately swaggering to prove his "coolness" and re-affirming his ability on the dance floor, the actor gives the kind of performance that's perfect for the role.

title: Grease
review: Grease holds up for new generations because it captures the enthusiasm of youth and the vibrancy of California's sunshine-and-cars culture.

title: Grease
review: Grease has got it, from the outstanding animated titles of John Wilson all the way through the rousing finale as John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John ride off into teenage happiness.

title: Grease
review: Limp, cheaply made.

title: Grease
review: An unembarrassed movie musical, something my generation experienced only in Sunday-afternoon movies on TV.

title: Grease
review: Its flashy opportunism (nostalgia pitched squarely at an audience too young to even recall the era) quickly becomes very irritating.

title: Grease
review: Its sensibility is not tied to the past but to a free-wheeling, well informed, high-spirited present.

title: Grease
review: The friskiness of the performers, the choreography by Patricia Birch and most of all Travolta's phenomenal charm give it its value.

title: Grease
review: Just an average musical, pleasant and upbeat and plastic.

title: Grease
review: Grease seems kickier now than it did 20 years ago.

title: Jaws
review: It may be the most cheerfully perverse scare movie ever made. Even while you're convulsed with laughter you're still apprehensive, because the editing rhythms are very tricky, and the shock images loom up huge, right on top of you.

title: Jaws
review: The result is a fast-paced, straight-line thriller that moves without pause toward the climactic contest at sea between three men and a 25-foot, 3-ton great while killer shark.

title: Jaws
review: It is a coarse-grained and exploitive work which depends on excess for its impact. Ashore it is a bore, awkwardly staged and lumpily written.

title: Jaws
review: What this movie is about, and where it succeeds best, is the primordial level of fear.

title: Jaws
review: A near Hitchcockian exercise in transference of guilt and making the audience pay for its illicit pleasures.

title: Jaws
review: Spielberg may be the man who created the new Hollywood, but in his first megahit he summed up what was best in the old -- the humor, the perversity, and the storytelling integrity of Alfred Hitchcock.

title: Jaws
review: Mr. Spielberg has so effectively spaced out the shocks that by the time we reach the spectacular final confrontation between the three men and the great white shark, we totally accept the makebelieve on its own foolishly entertaining terms.

title: Jaws
review: Spielberg works self-effacingly, with subtly correct camera placement and meticulous editing. He twists our guts with false alarms, giving us the real thing with heart-stopping suddenness.

title: Jaws
review: Steven Spielberg's mechanical thriller is guaranteed to make you scream on schedule.

title: Jaws
review: The fast-moving 124-minute film engenders enormous suspense as the shark attacks a succession of people.

title: Jaws
review: It's no wonder a generation of holidaymakers still thinks twice before stepping into the water.

title: Jaws
review: When it comes to this kind of thriller, no movie has been able to top Jaws, although many have tried. And, as the years go by, it seems increasingly unlikely that anything will come close.

title: Jaws
review: One of the most effective thrillers ever made.

title: Jaws 3-D
review: Surprisingly tepid.

title: Jaws 3-D
review: Put in a baking tray, gas mark 7, and enjoy a turkey.

title: Jaws 3-D
review: It's harmless but unsurprising.

title: My Fellow Americans
review: Using talent of this order on a script this weak, along with merely decorative appearances by the likes of Lauren Bacall and Wilford Brimley, amounts to the Hollywood equivalent of government waste.

title: My Fellow Americans
review: As political satire, My Fellow Americans makes a poor candidate.

title: My Fellow Americans
review: Yes, it's Grumpy Old Presidents, in which most of the comedy comes from the supposed shock of hearing two senior citizens cursing at each other in terms Beavis and Butt-head would find inelegant.

title: My Fellow Americans
review: I'd cheerfully vote the writers, director and producers of My Fellow Americans out of office.

title: My Fellow Americans
review: The movie suggests we get the government we deserve, but do we really deserve this movie?

title: Crash

review: Contrived, obvious and overstated, Crash is basically just one white man's righteous attempt to make other white people feel as if they've confronted the problem of racism head-on.

review: One of the finest American movies to engage our diverse richness and our casual and not-so-casual ethnic hostility.

title: Amistad
review: As Spielberg vehicles go, Amistad -- part mystery, action thriller, courtroom drama, even culture-clash comedy -- lands between the disturbing lyricism of Schindler's List and the storybook artificiality of The Color Purple.

title: Amistad
review: Halfway into Amistad comes the point where Steven Spielberg pulls the lever, and the stink and horror and bestialities of slavery spill around our ankles. We can't look away.

title: Amistad
review: The best parts of Amistad are those that simply bring their pride, fear and outrage to life.

title: Amistad
review: What is most valuable about Amistad is the way it provides faces and names for its African characters, whom the movies so often make into faceless victims.

title: Amistad
review: Amistad is prestige filmmaking bereft of inspiration -- sometimes even of the nuts and bolts of craft.

title: Amistad
review: Thematically rich, impeccably crafted, and intellectually stimulating, the only area where this movie falls a little short is in its emotional impact.

title: Bent
review: The screen version of Sherman's play about homosexuals in Nazi Germany shows that tyro director Mathias doesn't know much about film for his erratic approach and inconsistent style bring out the play's weaknesses, though the acting is good.

title: The Butcher Boy
review: Director Neil Jordan and Patrick McCabe adapted McCabe's novel for this bland 1998 shocker that fails miserably as satire, character study, and anything else it might have aspired to.

title: The Butcher Boy
review: Though the movie sometimes looks as if the authentic Irish wit, colour and blarney has been filtered through the sensibility of a Bunuel or Polanski, Jordan never allows the surreal/expressionist aspects to dominate.

title: The Butcher Boy
review: Neil Jordan's most accomplished and brilliant film to date, Butcher Boy is satisfying as faithful literary adaptation and inense cinematic experience that brings to mind in theme Kubrick's equally brilliant Cloakwork Orange.

title: The Butcher Boy
review: I find myself in an embarrassing position: I think this is a great movie, but I'm not sure.

title: The Butcher Boy
review: Instead of bathing his story in the warm, lyrical glow of an Irish lament, Jordan mixes domestic tragedy with fierce gallows humor and the stark horror of a Goya painting.

title: The Butcher Boy
review: Jordan is remarkable in his ability to reveal people's inner lives and the interaction between everyday life and an individual's imagination and driving passions.

title: The Butcher Boy
review: Anecdotal and increasingly chilling, The Butcher Boy moves from its early prankster spirit into parts unknown with the help of many pungent background touches.

title: The Butcher Boy
review: The Butcher Boy works best as a dark comedy and social satire, and is somewhat less successful as a character study of a deeply-troubled young boy whose violent impulses are fed by his unstable environment.

title: The Butcher Boy
review: Jordan's adaptation of The Butcher Boy (co-written with McCabe) remains a compelling exploration of the permeable border between normal childhood and full-on insanity.

title: The Butcher Boy
review: The movie held me outside; I didn't connect in the way I wanted to, and by the end I was out of sympathy with the material.

title: Deconstructing Harry
review: The dialogue lacks snap, and Allen-the-actor's comic timing seems a beat off.

title: Flubber
review: Manage[s] to squeeze the very bounce out of what should have been a can't-miss update.

title: For Richer or Poorer
review: for tube addicts who wish sitcoms were really, really long so they could be crammed with even more bedroom jokes, bathroom humor and 'nudge, nudge' line readings.

title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil
review: An oppressively long cinematic oddball.

title: Mousehunt
review: It's a not-bad gift for those who prefer their laughs black.

title: Office Killer
review: Some of this is insulting, all of it is tedious.

title: Office Killer
review: It can't decide what it wants to be -- slasher fest, social satire or revenge comedy -- and ends up being an awkward goulash.

title: Office Killer
review: It doesn't offer a single moment of visceral or emotional electricity.

title: Scream 2
review: The rest of the cast of disposable archetypes deadpanned about why ''sequels suck'' -- a particularly funny joke, since this one didn't.

title: Scream 2
review: Visceral, witty and appropriately redundant...

title: Scream 2
review: If you liked Scream there's no reason you shouldn't like this sequel.

title: Scream 2
review: The film itself is stuck in a cycle of repetition, with slight variations.

title: Scream 2
review: Wes Craven was born to direct this material. One of the most successful of horror filmmakers.

title: Scream 2
review: The movie is enjoyable.

title: Scream 2
review: Williamson's script is funny and smart.

title: Scream 2
review: A horror movie balancing gore and terror with personality, humor and a nifty gimmick.

title: Scream 2
review: A yum-yum cast of pretties pull off the neat trick of affectionately counting the many ways available to horror sequels to suck, without making a sequel that sucks.

title: Scream 2
review: Scream 2 is an ingenious, often hilarious, movie that does nothing to diminish the well-deserved cult reputation of its director.

title: Scream 2
review: Scream 2 is a clever and wittily manipulative copycat sequel to Scream.

title: Scream 2
review: Smart and scary like its predecessor, it delivers the shocks and a fair amount of sly wit.

title: Scream 2
review: The real fun of Scream 2, like Scream, isn't seeing people slaughtered. It's the smart-mouth dialogue and in-joke ironies.

title: Scream 2
review: Scream 2 has so much tongue-in-cheek trickery that it virtually escapes the horror genre.

title: Scream 2
review: Wes Craven and writer Kevin Williamson have sharpened the focus along with their copycat killer's knives.

title: Scream 2
review: There's enough ingenuity and scariness to please plenty of fans of the first film.

title: Scream 2
review: If you liked Scream, you're going to like Scream 2, simple as that.

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: A delicate and touching story.

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: Canadian writer-director Atom Egoyan's most ambitious work to date, The Sweet Hereafter is a rich, complex meditation on the impact of a terrible tragedy on a small town.

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: Though this is Egoyan's first adaptation, The Sweet Hereafter could serve as a model for how to do it right.

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: Audience is almost bound to be absorbed for the duration.

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: In a season of expertly adapted contemporary fiction (like "L.A. Confidential" and "The Ice Storm"), this fusion of Banks's and Egoyan's sensibilities stands as a particularly inspired mix.

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: a new moral urgency seems to invigorate this film

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: This is one of the best films of the year, an unflinching lament for the human condition.

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: Elegiac and yet straightforward as haiku

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: solemn, subtly structured, beautifully acted and ultimately hypnotic

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: As in Egoyan's Exotica and The Adjuster, past and present are intricately fused by the crisp editing, the mournful shadings of Mychael Danna's score and Paul Sarossy's austere wide-screen cinematography

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: The film searches for that place in the heart where we feel sadness and squeezes it persuasively.

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: A beautiful elegy about family and community, death and healing...

title: The Sweet Hereafter
review: The movie has an impact that extends far beyond the walls of a movie theater - a quality shared by a distressingly few of today's releases.

title: Titanic
review: Cameron has devised a tender love story between Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio that serves as the main focus of Titanic's storyline, and it works beautifully.

title: Titanic
review: If computer-generated special effects have overpowered human-generated drama, Cameron seizes that dangerously cold technology and recasts it as dream and delirium, profoundly human in its sources and longings.

title: Titanic
review: The execution is state-of-the-art and breathtaking. Titanic offers the full compass of courage and cowardice, and it stands as an achievement that truly is a night to remember at the movies.

title: Titanic
review: Titanic is indeed a ship of dreams. Climb aboard and bon voyage.

title: Titanic
review: Take one of history's most compelling tragedies, tell it through the lives of two engaging young lovers and show it with some of the best-ever special effects and you have a dazzling, exciting movie that is also poignant and personal.

title: Titanic
review: With his beatific, sweet, open face, DiCaprio gives us a rooting interest in hoping that someone important to us survives the wreck.

title: Titanic
review: We know the story ends badly but Cameron still sweeps us up in the romance between Kate Winslet's rebellious posh girl and DiCaprio's steerage kid.

title: Titanic
review: Cameron's three-hour disaster epic is a triumph of popular art -- of folk art, really.

title: Titanic
review: "Titanic" still amazes as the kind of massive, build-and-destroy production that few filmmakers have the ambition or budget to make.

title: Titanic
review: [Cameron] stages the sinking with a flawless sense of detail, pacing, import and dread.

title: Titanic
review: This version has deepened and enriched a film that was already rich in emotions and remarkable for its depth of detail.

title: Titanic
review: How is Titanic in 3D? The answer is pretty damn dazzling.

title: Titanic
review: Cameron is a genius at instilling narrative dread and designing a hokum-drenched fairy tale of a certain size.

title: Titanic
review: If any film should be redone in 3-D, it's "Titanic." And if any filmmaker should be the one doing the redoing, it's James Cameron.

title: Titanic
review: Sure, it's corny, but there's something endearing about the tale of young love and its earnest lack of irony.

title: Titanic
review: Like Kathy Bates' "unsinkable" Molly Brown, "Titanic" is unabashedly American: It's big, brash and sometimes gauche, yet also unapologetically earnest, amazing to look at and devoted to its own cause. And it knows how to win us over.

title: Titanic
review: Overall, for a blockbuster movie about one great big thing hitting another great big thing, the new film shows distinctly upper-deck restraint.

title: Titanic
review: The letdown factor has been most keenly felt in conversions from 2D, but Titanic 3D shows how the ambition can be realized if the will and skill are there. We can only hope that other filmmakers follow Cameron's example.

title: Titanic
review: But the power of Titanic didn't come from originality; it came from punching cliches across with a seldom-seen directness and sincerity that seemed pure of heart, "old-fashioned," or plain corny, depending on your perspective.

title: Titanic
review: James Cameron's spectacular new 3-D version of "Titanic'' is everything I'd hoped for, and more.

title: Twisted
review: This thriller seems most interested in lingering over battered and bloodied male faces.

title: Twisted
review: Sarah Thorpe's screenplay is a compendium of by-the-book cliches; Kaufman's direction leaves the material stranded in a limbo between po-faced and trashy; Judd's approximation of drunkenness is worrying to behold.

review: The outdated, cliche-riddled direction is so inept and indifferent that it's hard to believe Twisted was lensed by the same Philip Kaufman who made The Right Stuff.

title: Twisted
review: A suspense thriller without thrills or suspense.

title: Twisted
review: Judd is let down by Twisted because tearful, confused victim doesn't come naturally to her; she's not fun to watch suffer if you can't see her calculating the payback.

review: This movie plays like they were reading [Roger Ebert's] little movie glossary and they took every cliche in there.

title: Twisted
review: Gives new meaning to the word 'obvious.'

review: A nasty, formulaic and unforgivably obvious procedural.

title: Twisted
review: It's all perfectly rote and only occasionally satisfying.

title: Twisted
review: It begins pretty, and ends up ugly.

title: Twisted
review: The film is too simple to hold our interest for nearly two hours.

review: A chill-deficient suspense flick that shares too much common ominous ground with [Judd's] past thrillers.

review: Utterly devoid of suspense, energy or credibility.

title: Twisted
review: We can only regret that this is the kind of script [Kaufman's] being offered these days. Now, that's twisted.

title: Twisted
review: Bearable but hardly riveting.

title: Twisted
review: It's always rather sad to watch gifted performers stranded in a tepid thriller.

review: The script is credited to Sarah Thorp but has all the hallmarks of one of those screenplays that has gotten worse with every rewrite.

title: Twisted

review: Earnest but evocative, and in moments touching, chronicle of the turbulent childhood of a Cherokee orphan during the Depression.

review: That lack of identifiable passion is The Horse Whisperer's most vexing problem.

review: A film as rich in its visual presentation as it is in its emotional resonance.

review: ...an intelligent, lush-looking tale...

review: ...there is a magnificence in his treatment here that dignifies what is essentially a soap opera.

review: Tarantino's finest, most mature movie to date.

review: Between Jackson's opining and De Niro's hopeless alibis when he messes up, Jackie is good for a bundle of bloody ho-ho-hos.

review: [Tarantino] wanted to give Grier a role worthy of her, and he has. If only he'd given her a movie worthy of her as well.

review: [A] surprisingly sluggish Tarantino piece.

title: Kundun

title: Kundun
review: A great film about a good man.

title: Kundun
review: Careful and respectful, it is everything a movie about the Dalai Lama should be except dramatically involving.

title: Kundun
review: I admire Kundun for being so unreservedly committed to its vision, for being willing to cut loose from audience expectations and follow its heart.

title: Kundun
review: In imagining an exalted Buddhist version of a personal road not taken, Mr. Scorsese has made a film that is as much a prayer as it is a movie.

review: Once you settle into the pace of the movie, you experience it as a continuous flow of incidents and images.

title: Kundun
review: Kundun is ceaselessly lovely to look at. But it is also exquisitely, meticulously, intently (gulp) ... dull.

title: Kundun
review: While Kundun boasts impressive cinematography (by Roger Deakins) and an effective score (by Philip Glass), the images and music aren't enough to hide the picture's essential hollowness.

title: Kundun
review: It's an extremely beautiful, boring movie.

title: Kundun
review: In many ways, a remarkable achievement but also a singularly undynamic entry in the director's canon

title: Kundun
review: Throughout the film cause and effect, the mainspring of most narratives, is replaced by a sense of spiritual synchronicity.

title: The Big Lebowski

title: The Big Lebowski
review: The Dude and Sobchak begin as caricatures too, but they're allowed to grow into something deeper, if only because the humanist economy of the Coens' surrealist vaudeville allows for a couple of human beings within the tapestry of freaks.

title: The Big Lebowski
review: It's weirdly engaging, like its hero.

title: The Big Lebowski
review: There are more ideas here, more wacko side characters and plot curlicues than the film can support, and inevitably it deflates from having to shoulder so much.

title: The Big Lebowski
review: A genial spoof about life on the unhinged margins of L.A. that's a lot more carefully constructed than it pretends to be.

title: The Big Lebowski
review: This plot need not be taken too seriously. Watching it amble along is enough of a treat, since the Coens populate this story with oddballs and bowling balls of such comic variety.

review: Nearly everything in The Big Lebowski is a put-on, and all that leaves you with is the Coens' bizarrely over-deliberate, almost Teutonic form of rib nudging.

title: Afterglow

review: How mysterious and intriguing some performances can be.

review: God (or the Devil) is in the detail: every time a fluid is taken into the body, the fidgety camera zooms in, fascinated, suspicious.

review: A stylish if seriously far-fetched nightmare.

review: A crafty piece of work, ending with a pair of marvelous twists.

review: A human trifle that can be safely ignored in this eschatological genre.

review: If you have an interest in capital-letter Good and Evil, in the abstract-theological sense, Fallen could engross you.

title: Fallen

title: Fallen
review: The idea is better than the execution.

title: Fallen
review: Despite the negatives, I'm still recommending Fallen on the strength of its complex plot and especially its ending, which I loved.

title: Fallen

title: Fallen
review: An unholy union between Seven and The Exorcist.

review: This isn't a sequel, it's a remake.

title: Joy Ride

review: It's encouraging to see more than passing attention paid to character development.

review: Dahl permeates the film with enough quirky detail ... and horror-movie staples ... to keep things interesting.

title: Joy Ride
review: Terrific escapist fare, stylish, outrageous and compelling.

review: Dahl and his screenwriters spoil it by turning the trucker and his rig into a metallic-sheathed monster willing and able to do anything to get back at his enemies.

review: Lives up to its title.

review: Zahn's hilariously electric performance is the best thing in the movie.

review: Feels like a long drive in circles, with no destination worth getting to.

review: An empty shell.

review: Three major stars being involved, it all wraps up happily but implausibly.

review: Unfortunately, it just didn't work.

review: A darn good hunk of pop moviemaking.
