review: Twilight is, by its very nature, all about unfinished business, the story of a brooding, caring romantic hero and the woman who cannot -- although she wants to -- yield to him. Only his eyes penetrate her. For now, that's enough.

title: Twilight
review: My advice: Focus on Pattinson and Stewart. They make you understand why the books sold 17 million copies.

title: Twilight
review: Combines the plot of HBO's True Blood with the intensity level of Saved by the Bell.

title: Twilight
review: Screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg does a decent job adapting the first book in Meyer's series, and despite a tendency toward cheesy effects, Hardwicke keeps things moving swiftly.

title: Twilight
review: Teenage girls are going to love Twilight, and many are sure to see it more than once. Hang on to those earplugs: This time next year, you'll need them again.

title: Twilight
review: Gothic wooziness stifles many of Hardwicke's lighter impulses, such as her knack for jiving humor in scenes among friends and family. And some of the more cartoonishly gymnastic CG stunts look plain silly.

title: Hush
review: Hush is gussied up by its classy distaff cast members, but remains trashy all the same.

title: Hush
review: Jessica Lange establishes a spark of interest in this psychological thriller with her giggly demonic performance. But the film never adds up to anything more than an elaborate tease.

title: Hush
review: Hush has three very simple problems: it's incredibly dumb, it's incredibly boring, and it's incredibly predictable (at least up to the stupefying ending).

title: Hush
review: Lange seems at a loss to know how to convey Martha's malevolence -- and writer-director Jonathan Darby offers almost no guidance.

title: Hush
review: Hush is the kind of movie where you walk in, watch the first 10 minutes, know exactly where it's going, and hope devoutly that you're wrong.

title: Hush
review: The film is so awful it doesn't even qualify as a B-movie.

title: The Newton Boys
review: A handsome production that nicely evokes the 1920s and a likeable cast headed by McConaughey can't compensate for a Western-gangster film that's too diffuse and lacks a discernibel POV to be dramatically engaging.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: 'Where the Wild Things Are' stands out for its unusually potent evocation of the timbre of childhood imagining, with its combination of the outre and the banal, grand schemes jumbled up with delicate feelings and the urge to smash things up.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: [Jonze has] achieved with the cinematic medium what Sendak did with words and pictures: He's grasped something true and terrifying about love at its most unconditional and voracious.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Wild Things, you do not make my heart sing.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Intellectually interesting, visually arresting and filled with invention, there's just one crucial thing Where the Wild Things Are is missing: wildness.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Spike Jonze, we salute you.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Director Spike Jonze gets that Max's subsequent journey to the far-off island of the wild things is nothing less than an odyssey into his mind.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: This blend of the real and unreal is successful because Jonze's feeling for childhood binds everything together.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Some very good books were just never meant to be turned into movies. Sadly, you can now add Maurice Sendak's 1963 classic Where the Wild Things Are to that list.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Where the Wild Things Are is audacious in its refusal to be reassuring, which makes it hard to love, but also hard to dismiss.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: It's a joy for thinking moviegoers of any age. It doesn't seek to "keep out all the sadness," yet neither does it wallow in gloom. Instead it presents childhood as a journey filled with things both wonderful and fearful, and ultimately all of the mind.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Where the Wild Things Are may not be a great film for children (or, at least, most children). But it is something rarer still: a great, and unsparing, film about childhood.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: The film is lacking as a whole -- it's individual moments and scenes that make it worth seeing.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Jonze's ideas, visual and otherwise, spill out in a faux-philosophical ramble that isn't nearly as deep as he thinks it is; at best, it's a scrambled tone poem. Even the look of the picture becomes tiresome after a while.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Where the Wild Things Are is a fiercely innovative film with surprising texture and nuance. It captures the joy and exuberance of childhood without shying away from its very real pains and woes.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Where the Wild Things Are honors the book in every imaginable way, and in ways no one could have imagined until Spike Jonze and his collaborators came along.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Sometimes you are better off with 10 sentences than tens of millions of dollars, and this is one of those times.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: Where the Wild Things Are is an alternately perfect and imperfect if always beautiful adaptation of the Maurice Sendak children's book.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: For all the money spent, the film's success is best measured by its simplicity and the purity of its innovation. Jonze has filmed a fantasy as if it were absolutely real, allowing us to see the world as Max sees it, full of beauty and terror.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
review: In an era glutted with sanitized, prefabricated, computer-generated kids' stuff, this is an experience of sophisticated cross-generational appeal. It digs deep into childhood's bright, manic exuberance and also its confusion and gloom.

title: Paulie
review: Paulie has moments of minor charm but lacks the magic to fully capture the imaginations of either children or adults.

title: Paulie
review: Shalhoub gives an impressively nuanced performance in the dangerously cliched role, and Paulie -- a combination of trained parrots, animatronics, and the voice of Mohr -- comes across as a fully developed character.

title: Paulie
review: A perfect family movie with the intelligence, humor and hug-me moments to be a great first-date movie, too. Just remember to bring a hankie.

title: Paulie
review: Unusual and surprisingly agreeable.

title: Paulie
review: The film is aimed at children, I suppose, although I don't think they'll like Paulie all that much. I didn't.

title: Paulie
review: Paulie has elements of a good weepy, but overall it never quite gels beyond being a passable novelty.

title: Paulie
review: It is something to behold.

title: A Cool, Dry Place
review: The kind of plodding, conventional fare usually reserved for TV movies.

title: Hana-bi
review: Takeshi Kitano, who made it, must be very serene or very angry; only extreme states allow such a narrow focus.

title: Primary Colors
review: As satire, it's toothless and indulgent; as drama of conscience, it's not a patch on real life...

title: Primary Colors
review: A smart and savvy piece of work.

title: Primary Colors
review: Travolta's warmth and expansiveness effectively amplify and embellish the likable and personable side of Stanton.

title: Primary Colors
review: Dramatically weak.

title: Primary Colors
review: The movie loses something by downplaying the book's arresting contrast between Stanton's smooth dishonesty and Picker's raw sincerity.

title: Primary Colors
review: The film seldom displays much in the way of directorial hallmarks.

title: Primary Colors
review: The movie is endlessly inventive and involving.

title: Primary Colors
review: A slack, tepid picture stuck in a no man's land between satire and drama.

title: Primary Colors
review: The movie itself makes no judgment. It's smart enough to ask you to do that by yourself and for yourself.

title: Primary Colors
review: This entertaining but rather peculiar movie asks extraordinary questions, and I wish it were better equipped to give the answers.

title: Primary Colors
review: Primary Colors is the Mr. Smith Goes to Washington of our jaded era.

title: Primary Colors
review: Adapting Joe Klein's roman a clef of the same name, ferociously witty screenwriter Elaine May and her smooth old compatriot in comedy, director Mike Nichols, have made a zingy drama and have staffed it well.

title: Primary Colors
review: A hilariously entertaining movie.

title: Primary Colors
review: There are piecemeal wonders in Primary Colors, but not the grand and resonant vision the film should have been.

title: Primary Colors
review: May and Nichols may not be right for the material, especially the Searching for Jimmy Stewart component, which feels more labored as the film proceeds.

title: Primary Colors
review: Like its politicians, the movie is savvy about using whatever it takes to achieve a goal.

title: Primary Colors
review: It's hard for me fully to express how deeply rotten I think Primary Colors is. Adjectives like 'glib,' 'coarse,' and 'sour' don't fully do it.

title: Primary Colors
review: Those who wonder how good a Clinton impersonation Travolta does miss the point.

title: Wide Awake
review: A wonderful family film that deals sensitively, and even with humor, with a fairly unusual situation for the screen: a 9-year-old's struggles with his faith in God.

title: Wide Awake
review: Children, too, will be bored to tears navigating through some of the talky spiritual gunk.

title: Wide Awake
review: I was aware of the problems, but that didn't diminish the warm, fuzzy glow I was experiencing.

title: Wide Awake
review: The fact is, just too many of the characters and plot points are right out of the stock room: the obligatory fat kid; the obligatory bully; the obligatory kid whose parents can't really afford Catholic school tuition ...

title: Wide Awake
review: Beneath its suffocating, smug sentimentality, you have to look hard to uncover a single moment of truth and genuine feeling.

title: Wide Awake
review: I wonder who the movie was made for.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: The young actresses Graham and Wagner here create two characters who feel whole, distinct and weighty.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: An edgy, gabby, salaciously subversive sex farce.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: You gotta admire a director who can come up with a way to hang out in such luxurious digs for two weeks, acting out sexual situations with three of the dishiest young actors in the business.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: A lively, if slender, perpetuation of the battle between the sexes on a modern battleground.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: Writer-director James Toback must believe his audience is hopelessly prudish if he thinks this pedantic story, which takes place over several hours in a Manhattan loft, is provocative.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: Toback has somehow managed to prolong and expand this sketchy egg-on-your-face situation with a series of unexpected ironies and power role reversals that are not without wit, humor and intelligence.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: A thoroughly engrossing, intelligent and enjoyable experience.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: A small movie with some big moments and a lot of unfinished business.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: Two Girls and a Guy isn't a satisfying movie, but Downey is alarmingly brilliant in it.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: Robert Downey Jr.'s Blake Allen is enough of a raging dynamo to find the dark humor and desperate romanticism at the heart of Mr. Toback's ego trip of a premise, and to make Blake sympathetic too.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: Wagner doesn't wink at the audience to let it know she's not as ignorant and naive as the character she plays. It's a performance that risks being misunderstood, and it probably will be.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: Downey's last scene knocks the wind out of you: You may feel you need a moment or two before you can get up out of your seat.

title: Two Girls and a Guy
review: Sometimes the story behind a movie can bring an angle to what's on the screen.

title: The Proposition
review: A beautifully shot tracker's western that brings the Fordian poles of garden and desert to bear on the bushrangers' Outback, this is also a revenge drama of substantial horror.

title: The Proposition
review: A visionary tale of a fragile civilizing impulse crushed by family loyalty and a lust for revenge in the vast Outback of the late 19th century.

title: The Proposition
review: It doesn't offer much that hasn't already been said about lawless frontier towns, bonds between outlaws or the settling of the West.

title: The Proposition
review: By the end, it all pays off exactly the way a hundred earlier Westerns did.

title: The Proposition
review: In-your-face combativeness is The Proposition's power, and for those of you who value your westerns, the effect is not unlike that of The Wild Bunch or Unforgiven.

title: The Proposition
review: It's fitting that The Proposition is set Down Under, because in many ways, it's a reverse Western.

title: The Proposition
review: An intense piece of wilderness ugliness that mixes family, honor, decency, revenge, racism and mindless blood lust in a manner that satisfies even if it never astounds.

title: The Proposition
review: The squeamish should skip this film. But its recurring violence seems justified in terms of the story Cave sets out to tell and is up a familiar alley for the songwriter who has an album called Murder Ballads.

title: The Proposition
review: Murder ballad for the slice-and-dice age, a film of sensitive artistry laced with gore.

title: The Proposition
review: This is the crucial proposition The Proposition misses: To make us truly despair about the face of violence, it must be firmly attached to someone we know, and not merely blown off someone we don't.

title: The Proposition
review: A near-masterpiece of mood and menace, and one that deserves to be seen on the largest screen possible.

title: The Proposition
review: It's consistently compelling and thought-provoking. This one will stay with you, and despite its disturbing moments, you'll welcome it.

title: The Proposition
review: A revisionist western that brings its own brand of sanguinary honesty to the genre.

title: The Proposition
review: Offering proportionate measures of raw violence and lyrical soliloquizing, the Peckinpah-influenced The Proposition is for those who prefer their western action unvarnished but immaculately framed.

title: The Proposition
review: Hillcoat creates a vision as nihilistic as any horror film ever put on a screen, but so well acted and carefully conceived that it transcends exploitation.

title: The Proposition
review: The movie gets at something primal in the pit of your stomach, something that speaks of loyalty and betrayal, of men's souls -- or the lack thereof.

title: The Proposition
review: A pitiless yet elegiac Australian Western as caked with beauty as it is with blood.

title: The Proposition
review: I'm guessing that Hillcoat wants us to see The Proposition as a howling, heartsick message from our savage selves. The story is ugly, but there's some beauty in the telling.

title: The Proposition
review: Over the top, Down Under.

title: The Object of My Affection
review: The plot's hokey contrivances and the theatrical shtick tend to prevail over the sporadic moments of insight and emotional truth.

title: The Object of My Affection
review: It never persuades you it belongs on the big screen.

title: The Object of My Affection
review: The best romantic comedy so far this year.

title: The Object of My Affection
review: This comedy is content to enjoy the beguiling antics of Ms. Aniston, who is as skillful here as she is miscast, and to let its colorful minor characters give it a sitcom spin.

title: The Object of My Affection
review: There is a movie fighting to get out of The Object of My Affection, and I like it better than the movie it's trapped in.

title: The Object of My Affection
review: Paul Rudd is charming, and some of the scenes are intelligently written and played, but at a recent screening people on all sides of me were squirming in discomfort.

title: The Object of My Affection
review: While some of the solutions are a little facile, the film nevertheless succeeds, due in large part to a luminous performance by Jennifer Aniston...

title: Big
review: A delightful comedy-fantasy.

title: Big
review: Penny Marshall brings a logic to the premise that is sustained through most of the movie. And where the other movies snickered at the sexual possibilities in the idea, she faces up to them with both candor and taste.

title: Big
review: This setup isn't exactly what you'd call plausible, but the follow-through is consistent and clever.

title: Big
review: Big, which has been directed by Penny Marshall with verve and impeccable judgment, drops a child's innocence into the corporate rat race as if it were a depth charge.

title: Big
review: When Marshall brings Hanks and Perkins together, she discovers a grace and lightness in their relationship that transcends the pinched thematics of the script.

title: Big
review: Not a major movie but a pleasing one.

title: Big
review: As far as the movie's message is considered -- if only grown-ups could be more like kids -- Jerry Lewis did an infinitely better job of plugging it in the 50s.

title: Big
review: Unspools with enjoyable genuineness and ingenuity.

title: Big
review: Marshall, Hanks, and his co-stars seldom put a foot wrong.

title: Big
review: For any other full-grown actors who try their hands at fidgeting, squirming, throwing water balloons and wolfing down food in a huge variety of comically disgusting ways, this really is the performance to beat.

title: Big
review: What's great about it is that it shows how wonderfully full of toys the world of adults can be. And though this may fall under the heading of tiny, perhaps even fatuous, revelations, it does send you out of the theater with a lighter step.

title: Big
review: The film is funny, sweet, and even a little edgy. It's also emotionally honest and almost never crass.

title: The Last Days of Disco
review: Sharp-eyed and charming.

title: The Last Days of Disco
review: The pleasures in The Last Days of Disco come when the friends rant and quarrel and sulk and circle each other with an unstable mixture of need and resentment.

title: The Last Days of Disco
review: [Stillman] nails his characters with perfectly heard dialogue and laconic satire.

title: The Last Days of Disco
review: In its last hour, the picture becomes more clumsy and tiresome, but the stray laugh and the disco sound keep it pulsing.

title: The Last Days of Disco
review: The combination of sharply-realized dialogue and infectiously energetic dance sequences keeps The Last Days of Disco from losing steam.

title: The Last Days of Disco
review: If this film ... doesn't fully rise to the lovely vibrancy of Barcelona, it still extends the witty, quizzical style of Stillman's social comedies onto inviting new terrain.

title: He Got Game
review: Lacking the moral indignation and militant politics of Lee's former work, this vibrantly colorful father-son melodrama is soft at the center, but it's one of the most accessible films Lee has made and Denzel Washington is terrific.

title: He Got Game
review: At the end of Mr. Lee's movie, all you feel is the distraction of Mr. Lee's stylistic exhibitionism, without which, I concede, he might not be regarded as a genius in some quarters.

title: He Got Game
review: [Lee] gets a charming performance from Allen, who, in his acting debut, occupies his pedestal with grace and diffidence.

title: He Got Game
review: As usual, Lee tries many kinds of stylistic effects and uses wall-to-wall music (by Aaron Copland and Public Enemy); what's different this time is how personally driven the story feels.

title: He Got Game
review: Most scenes play too long, with a surplus of ideas, textures, tones and characters, and after 134 minutes it's clear Lee's problem with closure hasn't gone away.

title: He Got Game
review: Washington's Jake Shuttlesworth looks tough and hard, an odd but refreshing turn for an actor long associated with handsomely heroic roles.

title: He Got Game
review: A two-hour air ball.

title: He Got Game
review: Washington is so consistently effective an actor that it hardly needs be said that his excellent performance as the beleaguered Jake carries the film.

title: He Got Game
review: The movie is a volatile combination of ambitious mythmaking and nasty reality, and like most of Spike Lee's work, it is also an inextricable combination of good and bad.

title: He Got Game
review: an effective companion piece to Hoop Dreams and Blue Chips.

title: He Got Game
review: Milwaukee Bucks guard Ray Allen delivers nothing less than the best performance ever put on film by a pro athlete.

title: He Got Game
review: The year's first Hollywood movie to burst with palpable feeling.

title: He Got Game
review: Lee is a long way from the size and scope of his best film, Do the Right Thing, but at least he is working on a subject he cares about and is doing it with polish.

title: He Got Game
review: He Got Game is Lee's best film since Malcolm X.

title: He Got Game
review: Lee may never have the narrow focus to sustain a film on storytelling alone, and he may never need it. What he has here is an explosion of spectacular gambits and a great high-concept hook.

title: He Got Game
review: The wildly uneven script includes both disciplined, lively riffs and amateurishly artificial exchanges.

title: He Got Game
review: He Got Game is a little too sappy to be a great movie, but it puts the ball in the hole.

title: The Gingerbread Man
review: Robert Altman the up-and- down director meets John Grisham the constant mediocrity. Just where, in our hypothetical picture, should we place that unlikely scene?

title: The Gingerbread Man
review: Altman had a fine time composing difficult shots, through screens, bushes and sheets of rain, and Chungwei's images, sometimes delicate, sometimes harsh, stick with you long after you've forgotten their context.

title: The Gingerbread Man
review: If you like movies more than you do John Grisham, you can leave the story behind and listen to the filmmaking master class that Altman conducts on the screen.

title: The Gingerbread Man
review: There's great pleasure in watching a movie in which the director has thought out everything beforehand.

title: The Gingerbread Man
review: The Gingerbread Man isn't any more profound than other thrillers, but the distinctive talents of director Robert Altman make it a lot more potent.

title: The Gingerbread Man
review: Although The Gingerbread Man is a finely-tuned example of mainstream entertainment, and holds the audience's interest for most of its running length, it is a little disappointing.

title: The Gingerbread Man
review: Unless one counts a few running gibes against lawyers that can easily be imagined coming from Grisham, Altman basically chooses to treat this hackneyed story straight.

title: The Gingerbread Man
review: With unexpected success, Robert Altman plays a John Grisham mystery in a seductive new key.

title: The Gingerbread Man
review: That it seems a step up from sensationalism is because Grisham has a sure sense of time and place, and Altman and his actors invest the material with a kind of lurid sincerity.

title: Carne trémula
review: The overall purpose of Live Flesh, the latest and reputedly most 'mature' work from Spanish bad-boy director Pedro Almodovar, remains engigmatic.

title: Carne trémula
review: Almodovar, whose work here has newly sophisticated polish, appreciates the dark twists of this story along with the eroticism that bring heat to all the scheming.

title: Carne trémula
review: Despite his erotic fixations, Pedro Almodovar is the cinema's last true innocent.

title: Carne trémula
review: I can only conclude that the people who think Flower and Live Flesh represent the new, mature Almodovar think that his earlier pictures were immature.

title: Carne trémula
review: This is the first Almodovar movie that could be called boring.

title: Carne trémula
review: Like the gorgeous cinematography (which is used to good effect to eroticize a sex scene), this is all part of Almodovar's stylistic package. Never has it been more impressive than here, where everything (not just the flesh) is vibrant with life.

title: Carne trémula
review: Almodovar seems more assured here, confident that he can interest us without overt winking and tomfoolery.

title: Zero Effect
review: There's an idiosyncratic talent at work here with the potential to blossom into bigger, better and more accomplished films.

title: Zero Effect
review: Kasdan's is a very promising debut, its own dearth of feeling offset by able writing, engaging playing and a sure sense of pace.

title: Zero Effect
review: It turns out to be disappointingly ordinary.

title: Zero Effect
review: Try as it might, "Zero Effect" just doesn't amount to much.

title: Zero Effect
review: This is one of those movies that creeps up on you, insidiously gathering power. By the end, I was surprised how much I was involved.

title: Zero Effect
review: Both Mr. Pullman and the slyly restrained Mr. Stiller keep their characters entertaining even when Mr. Kasdan's interest is elsewhere.

title: Zero Effect
review: Kasdan is onto something, but he needs to develop it. If he tries to bring Daryl Zero back for a sequel, maybe he'll have a better idea of what to do with his eccentric private eye.

title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn
review: The level of humor could be called sophomoric, but that would insult most sophomores.

title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn
review: A comedy without laughs, an expose without point.

title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn
review: What turns the witlessness rancid is the way the movie is saturated in the very corruption it thinks it's ridiculing.

title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn
review: A caustic but under-funny "expose" of the venality of the motion picture business.

title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn
review: If you harbor an interest in watching so-called "industry smarts" autodestruct, this carries a certain morbid appeal, but that's about the extent of it.

title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn
review: Burning is too good for such a wretched fiasco; only a surgical nuclear strike could suitably destroy what has to be one of the most enervating comedies ever made.

title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn
review: The picture is just a spoof, getting by on wit and a parade of celebrity cameos. Within its modest scope, it pretty much succeeds.

title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn
review: A spectacularly bad film -- incompetent, unfunny, ill-conceived, badly executed, lamely written, and acted by people who look trapped in the headlights.

title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn
review: Incidentally, it's a bad idea to try bailing out hopelessly flat comedy with outtakes that are funnier than the in-takes manage to be.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: Our culture has notoriously short attention spans and memories, but Kurt and Courtney goes a long way toward undoing the meticulous public relations campaign that Love has orchestrated in an effort to whitewash her tarnished image.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: The true circumstances of Cobain's death remain cloudy, but one comes away from the film unnerved by the distance travelled.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: Kurt and Courtney is an entertaining swim through the muck of the rock underworld. But as journalism, it's an utterly sloppy piece of work.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: We do get a strong sense that Love is a loose cannon with a short fuse. But in a freewheeling documentary about a drug-addled rock-star couple that hardly qualifies as a news flash.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: It would be one mondo bizarro freak show but for the participation of some who clearly cared for the troubled young Cobain.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: We're left with only one credible impression of Courtney Love: That she is incredibly ambitious. What a shock!

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: In the Kurt-and-Courtney relationship, Broomfield has gotten ahold of an engrossing subject. And he pretty much has what it takes to do it justice.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: You know little more about the subject when you leave the theater as when you came in.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: This patchwork portrait is hard to look away from, partly because it exposes how one man rationalizes the dirty job of being a documentary filmmaker.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: In the end, too, we've learned very little about Cobain's demons --- his alleged chronic stomach pains from stress, etc. --- or why he, and Nirvana, became so important to so many people

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: [A] funny, angry, provocative film.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: Unreliable and categorically unfriendly to Love though it is, Kurt & Courtney is thoroughly watchable in a bad car accident, trash TV kind of way.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: When Kurt and Courtney veers into speculation and gives voice to bizarre and unreliable witnesses, it reeks of tabloid excess.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: In all of Broomfield's films, you meet people you can hardly believe exist.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: Mr. Broomfield doesn't ultimately prove, or even believe, that Mr. Cobain died under incriminating circumstances. But he makes it wrenchingly clear why the world in which he lived had become impossible to bear.

title: Kurt & Courtney
review: Lurid and freakishly arresting.

title: Ta'm e guilass

review: The film is such a lifeless drone that we experience it only as a movie.

review: The talk flows persuasively; the picture pulses with art and humanity.

review: Kiarastomi, like no other filmmaker, has a vision of human scale that is simultaneously epic and precisely minuscule.

review: As the film's design becomes clear to us, a quiet spaciousness begins to inhabit it.

review: This third outing in the Major League series... won't set any box office records [b]ut it's an amusing film in its own right...

review: I can't easily remember a film I've enjoyed less.

title: Wild Man Blues

review: [Kopple] might seem an unlikely choice for this material, but no doubt her track record gained Allen's trust.

review: Wild Man Blues has a tendency to become repetitious, especially during the final forty minutes.

review: In her unexpectedly delightful documentary about Woody Allen as jazz musician, Barbara Kopple demonstrates cinema verite at its most seductive.

review: ...crude and bloody but effective action comedy...

title: Slumdog Millionaire

title: Slumdog Millionaire

title: Slumdog Millionaire

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: From an early footchase in which the careening camera gives us a tour of the maze-like slums, to the ridiculously uplifting Bollywood dance number that plays over the end credits, Slumdog Millionaire makes for kinetic, exhilarating entertainment.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: [A] taut, tense and witty tale of human tragedy and triumphant humanity set against the sweep of modern India.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: An intoxicating mix of genres: comedy, drama, suspense, even Bollywood-style musical.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: Watching Slumdog Millionaire, it's easy to believe director Danny Boyle has been working toward this brilliantly woven masterwork with each entertaining and diverse tale he's delivered.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: I'll keep this simple: Cancel whatever you're doing tonight and go see Slumdog Millionaire instead.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: Don't let the exotic setting put you off; this is a massively cool cross-cultural crowd-pleaser.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: It doesn't happen often, but when it does, look out: a movie that rocks and rolls, that transports, startles, delights, shocks, seduces. A movie that is, quite simply, great.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: The film is a delight.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: Not that the movie from director Danny Boyle isn't satisfying, isn't more than worth seeing. But I had been expecting cinematic fireworks to justify the claim that it's the best movie of the new millennium.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: Look for multiple Oscar nominations for this movie.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: Worth seeing.

title: Slumdog Millionaire

review: Danny Boyle's Slumdog Millionaire is trying very hard to be a Dickensian fable for our time.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: The movie brushes against some of India's worst social ills, but it's essentially a fairy tale.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
review: Slumdog Millionaire is skillful entertainment, with the simple message that the most intense life experiences yield the greatest education.

review: This is a story that has been told many times before, but generally with more energy than this.

review: It's really a series of sketches on one theme.

review: A dark and fidgety picture from Christopher Nolan, who made such a splash with Memento.

review: The highlight is Pacino, who gives his best performance in years.

review: Despite its linear storyline, the film is very recognisably the work of the sharp, probing intelligence that gave us Following and Memento.

review: It's a crafty story told with more style and gray areas than your average thriller.

review: The Hollywood version (which is half an hour longer) transports the action to Alaska, and works up a respectable level of bleary-eyed paranoia.

review: A thriller whose style, structure and rhythms are so integrated with the story, you cannot separate them.

review: You see Robin Williams and psycho killer, and you think, hmmmmm. You see the movie and you think, zzzzzzzzz.

review: This remake gets all there is to get out of a peculiar premise with promise: Al Pacino loathing Robin Williams.

review: Continually challenges perceptions of guilt and innocence, of good guys and bad, and asks us whether a noble end can justify evil means.

review: Pacino, his creased face looking like it's been aged in a smokehouse, is wonderfully bleary as the increasingly confused Dormer.

review: A high-spirited, synthetically raucous house-party comedy.

review: It's not supposed to be a revelation--just a pleasant rendition of a teen-comedy trope.

review: The directors get good performances from a talented cast.

title: Pi

review: Maybe the problem of the pacing is simply the nature of the beast these days with expensive period pieces. Once the difficult details are all in place, it may be too much to expect a director to resist milking every scene for more than it's worth.

review: Sydney Pollack applies craftsmanship and restraint to a classic plot curve of longing, fulfillment, and loss, and although the denouement is a bit overextended, he never yields to facile, insistent sentimentality -- his effects are honestly won.

title: Out of Africa
review: For all that it may come out of Africa, the film's final destination is not many miles from Disneyland.

title: Out of Africa
review: With the exception of Miss Streep's performance, the pleasures of Out of Africa are all peripheral -- David Watkin's photography, the landscapes, the shots of animal life -all of which would fit neatly into a National Geographic layout.

title: Out of Africa
review: Out of Africa is a great movie to look at, breathtakingly filmed on location. It is a movie with the courage to be about complex, sweeping emotions, and to use the star power of its actors without apology.

title: Out of Africa
review: It tells a grand love story in less-than-grand fashion but is nevertheless worth seeing because of all the other things it does right.

title: The Last Emperor
review: It is a hesitant, conservative approach that yields great elegance and a rhythm that carries the viewer along. Yet the film is haunted by a sense of opportunities not taken, of an artist deliberately reining in his artistry.

title: The Last Emperor
review: If there is such a thing as voluptuous detachment, Bertolucci and John Lone have found it. Lone's achievement in his absorbing account of Pu Yi is to place him at a distance and yet make his plight totally involving.

title: The Last Emperor
review: There's probably a truly great movie in the story of Pu Yi, but The Last Emperor is not that movie. Still, what director Bernardo Bertolucci (Last Tango in Paris) has accomplished here is both ambitious and impressive.

title: The Last Emperor
review: As coolly lavish an epic as we may ever see.

title: The Last Emperor
review: The expanse of time is saturated with an expanse of visual beauty that feels absolutely right for the story.

title: The Last Emperor
review: It works astonishingly well.

title: The Last Emperor
review: Constantly absorbing and tremendously interesting.

title: The Last Emperor
review: John Lone is superb as the sad mediocrity; and if spectacle finally triumphs over sympathy, it is not without a decent struggle.

title: The Last Emperor
review: It's a tribute to the film's intelligence and its feeling for dialectics that it views both the Forbidden City and the detention center as prisons, and that when Pu Yi winds up as a gardener there's a sense of gain as well as loss.

title: The Last Emperor
review: The Last Emperor is like an elegant travel brochure. It piques the curiosity. One wants to go. Ultimately it's a let-down.

title: The Last Emperor
review: Everything involving the life of Pu Yi was a waste. Everything except one thing: the notion that a single human life could have infinite value.

title: The Last Emperor
review: A remarkable achievement.

title: The Last Emperor
review: We need more than elegant parallels and lavish production values. We need tension, characterization, drama.

title: Rain Man
review: Everything about the acting and direction of Rain Man is so exquisitely calibrated and so right that it's all too easy to forget how much could have gone wrong.

title: Rain Man
review: A fascinating, often very moving, frequently funny film.

title: Rain Man
review: It's an honorable effort, touched by a certain lightness and grace.

title: Rain Man
review: What no one can argue is that Rain Man is Cruise's quantum leap, so that it can be said unblushingly that he holds his own with the masterly Hoffman.

title: Rain Man
review: The strength of the film is really that of Cruise's performance, his finest since Risky Business.

title: Rain Man
review: Rain Man's restraint is, finally, rather like Raymond's gabble. It discourages connections, keeping you out instead of drawing you in.

title: Rain Man
review: Uneven, slightly off-target.

title: Rain Man
review: Valeria Golino is appealing as Cruise's girlfriend; Hoffman makes his character pretty believable without milking the part for pathos and tears, and it's nice to see Cruise working for a change in a context that isn't determined by hard sell and hype.

title: Rain Man
review: There is no story, no motor, and given the nature of the premise, nothing much can happen.

title: Rain Man
review: Its end effect depends largely on one's susceptibility to the sight of an actor acting nonstop and extremely well, but to no particularly urgent dramatic purpose.

title: Rain Man
review: Rain Man is so fascinating because it refuses to supply those questions with sentimental but unrealistic answers.

title: Rain Man
review: Neither Levinson nor Hoffman was able to penetrate the mystery of their subject.

title: Rain Man
review: Rain Man is far from a washout but you can't help feeling all those missed opportunities raining down on you.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: Driving Miss Daisy spans a quarter-century in the intricate relationship of a Southern dowager and her chauffeur, and it is a movie that invites you to appreciate the passage of time in more than one way.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: Jessica Tandy and Morgan Freeman give exceptional performances

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: Freeman and Tandy have their own performer's pride, and that transfers to their characters. Tandy, in particular, is almost astringent in her denial of easy emotion.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: This is a story about people, not politics. And perhaps because we can see the actors in closeup on the screen, that is even truer of the movie than the play.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: For Tandy, it's her most substantial film role since her sublime work in Alfred Hitchcock`s 1963 The Birds, and she takes full advantage of it; never playing for sympathy, she earns it completely.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: Alfred Uhry's adaptation of his Pulitzer-prizewinning play aspires more to complex observation of human behavior than to simple moralism about it. Precisely because it has its priorities straight, it succeeds superbly on both levels.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: Bruce Beresford's sensitive direction complements Alfred Uhry's skillful adapation of his Pulitzer Prize-winning play.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: The movie also has something legitimate and instructive to say about the subtlety and intricacy of everyday race relations in the south during the period covered (roughly 1948 to '73).

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: Far too cosy to serve as an effective social or political metaphor; better to regard it as a solid ensemble piece.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: There is an exhilarating, singularly theatrical lightness of touch that is often lost when these settings are made manifest in a movie.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: This is Tandy's finest two hours onscreen in a film career that goes back to 1932.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: The story holds a potential for sap that is mostly unfulfilled thanks to Beresford's stately approach, the stars' better judgment and the protagonists' sharp wits.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: Driving Miss Daisy is a film of great love and patience, telling a story that takes 25 years to unfold, exploring its characters as few films take the time to do.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
review: The movie gets you mainly because Morgan Freeman, who played chauffeur Hoke Colburn in the original stage production (and won his third Obie for it), takes the wheel and drives Daisy all the way home.

title: Take the Money and Run
review: Whatever its genesis, Allen's scraggly rhetoric evolved into the dominant comic style of the 70s.

title: Take the Money and Run
review: A few good laughs in an 85-minute film do not a comedy make.

review: It has plenty of hilarious jokes and concepts, like the ventriloquists' dummies at prison visiting time, and the return home from a chaingang break with five shackled cons in tow.

title: Take the Money and Run
review: Allen has made a movie that is, in effect, a feature-length, two-reel comedy -- something very special and eccentric and funny.

title: Take the Money and Run
review: Woody Allen's Take the Money and Run has some very funny moments, and you'll laugh a lot, but in the last analysis it isn't a very funny movie.

title: Klute
review: [Fonda] makes all the right choices, from the mechanics of her walk and her voice inflection to the penetration of the girl's raging psyche. It is a rare performance.

title: Klute
review: For once, a genuinely psychological thriller.

title: Klute
review: With Fonda and Sutherland, you have actors who understand and sympathize with their characters, and you have a vehicle worthy of that sort of intelligence. So the fact that the thriller stuff doesn't always work isn't so important.

title: Klute
review: Pakula, when he is not indulging in subjective camera, strives to give his film the look of structural geometry, but despite the sharp edges and dramatic spaces and cinema presence out of Citizen Kane, it all suggests a tepid, rather tasteless mush.

title: Repo Man
review: Repo Man has the type of unerring energy that leaves audiences breathless and entertained.

title: Repo Man
review: Cox's style is a step beyond camp into a comedy of pure disgust; much of the film is churlishly unpleasant, but there's a core of genuine anger that gives the project an emotional validation lacking in the flabby American comedies of the early 80s.

title: Repo Man
review: There are endless things to enjoy, from Robby Muller's crisp camerawork to a superb set of performances, from witty movie parodies to a tremendous punk soundtrack.

title: Repo Man
review: Repo Man comes out of left field, has no big stars, didn't cost much, takes chances, dares to be unconventional, is funny, and works. There is a lesson here.

title: Repo Man
review: It's very entertaining, and though it's rude in an R-rated way, it has the good taste never to promise more than it can deliver.

title: Metropolitan
review: Whit Stillman's crafty independent feature about wealthy Park Avenue teenagers and a middle-class boy who joins their ranks over one Christmas vacation is certainly well imagined, and impressively acted by a cast of newcomers.

title: Metropolitan
review: Filmmaker Whit Stillman makes a strikingly original debut with Metropolitan, a glib, ironic portrait of the vulnerable young heirs to Manhattan's disappearing debutante scene.

title: Metropolitan
review: None of Stillman's endearing characters quite fits their prescribed social context, and in its exhilarated final movement, Metropolitan finds an exit out of the stifling UHB salon.

title: Metropolitan
review: True appreciation for this movie may be restricted to those with firsthand experience in this kind of world, or a certain upper-haute stamina.

title: Metropolitan
review: Not very much happens in Metropolitan, and yet everything that happens is felt deeply, because the characters in this movie are still too young to have perfected their defenses against life.

title: Metropolitan
review: Like chamber music, Metropolitan is sprightly, intimate and all too self-aware.

title: The Breakfast Club
review: In nine hours of threatening, bickering and, eventually, poignant (but never maudlin) self-revelation, the stereotypes dissolve and re-form.

title: The Breakfast Club
review: John Hughes's 1985 film seems meant to explain 80s youngsters to yesterday's youth, and comes to the comforting conclusion that they're just as alienated, idealistic, and vulnerable as the baby boomers of the 1960s.

title: The Breakfast Club
review: Does director John Hughes really believe, as he writes here, that 'when you grow up, your heart dies.' It may. But not unless the brain has already started to rot with films like this.

title: The Breakfast Club
review: An iconic movie of the '80s, with all the unappealing baggage that suggests.

title: The Breakfast Club
review: The Breakfast Club doesn't need earthshaking revelations; it's about kids who grow willing to talk to one another, and it has a surprisingly good ear for the way they speak.

title: The Breakfast Club
review: Mr. Hughes, having thought up the characters and simply flung them together, should have left well enough alone.

title: The Breakfast Club
review: In The Breakfast Club, Hughes has created a surprisingly enduring motion picture that is still effective 13 years after its theatrical debut.

title: A Nightmare on Elm Street Part 2: Freddy's Revenge
review: Episodic treatment is punched up by an imaginative series of special effects.

title: A Nightmare on Elm Street Part 2: Freddy's Revenge
review: The film hangs reasonably well together, not least because of good performances from all concerned.

title: A Nightmare on Elm Street Part 2: Freddy's Revenge
review: Mr. Patton and Miss Myers make likable teen-age heroes, and Mr. Englund actually turns Freddy into a welcome presence.

review: Debuting director Chuck Russell elicits poor performances from most of his thesps, making it difficult to differentiate between pic's comic relief and unintended howlers.

title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors
review: A creepy score and Russell's sure grasp of the skewed logic of nightmares helps to sustain the ambiguity between the 'real' and 'dream' worlds, while Englund's Freddie now fits like a glove.

review: The film's dream sequences are ingenious, and they feature some remarkable nightmare images and special effects.

review: While it's better than its predecessor, it's still not quite up to its inspiration.

title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors
review: This is filmmaking by the numbers, without soul.

review: Consistently watchable and inventive.

review: Though the Elm Street series contains the most intelligent premise in current genre films, none of the movies take much advantage of their potential.

review: As always, the teen actors are disposable, and even Robert Englund seems to be sleepwalking through Freddy.

review: A flimsily plotted but visually impressive addition to the endless Freddy Krueger saga.

review: As for Englund, he still looks as if he's been working at Domino's too long, and he still sounds as if he's stealing his material from Don Rickles.

review: Even the much-heralded 3-D finale is murky and unimaginative.

title: Freddy's Dead: The Final Nightmare
review: The Elm Street films have always been a cut above the competition, so to speak, with their playfully malevolent dream sequences and their mocking, ever-resourceful villain.

title: Freddy's Dead: The Final Nightmare
review: So long, Freddy, it's been good to know you.

title: Friday the 13th
review: For all its shoddiness, the film manages, just barely, to achieve its ignoble goals -- it delivers what it promises.

title: Friday the 13th

title: Friday the 13th

title: Friday the 13th Part III

review: Eventually, the novelty wears off, and what remains is the now-familiar spectacle of nice, dumb kids being lopped, chopped and perforated.

review: The end result is a bit of a mess but hugely enjoyable, and often (thanks to Dean Cundey's camerawork and John Carpenter's close supervision as producer) as striking visually as its predecessors.

title: Halloween III: Season of the Witch
review: This is one of those Identikit movies, assembled out of familiar parts from other, better movies.

title: Halloween III: Season of the Witch
review: Mr. Wallace clearly has a fondness for the cliches he is parodying and he does it with style.

review: H4 is very much the cheap knockoff of its prototype, but not half as visceral.

title: Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers
review: Of all the Halloween sequels, including the irrelevant and unwatchable Halloween III, Halloween 4 stands out as the best of a generally uninspired lot.

title: Halloween 5
review: A prime example of the principle of diminishing reruns.

title: Prom Night
review: There's no need to wear a corsage to Prom Night. And leaving your higher brain functions at home might be a good idea, too.

review: There's absolutely zippo to fear about this movie, unless you're the kind of person who jumps when formula bogeymen do exactly what you'd expect them to do.

review: There's no suspense or perversity. You don't care who lives or who dies -- just please make it soon.

review: About as spine-tingling as an algebra exam.

review: It's a bore, even taking into account unintentional moments of humor that resulted in audience members jeering. This is a case study for Filmmaking Ineptitude 101.

title: Prom Night

review: The film delivers honest special-effects shocks without forfeiting its good nature.

review: Given the talents, Poltergeist is an annoying film because it could have been so much better.

title: Poltergeist
review: Though the shocks are well conveyed, it's the sweetness that lingers, making this the first cute and cuddly entry in the genre.

title: Poltergeist
review: It is consistently redeemed by its creator's dazzling sense of craft.

review: Hooper and Spielberg hold our interest by observing the everyday rituals of this family so closely that, since the family seems real, the weird events take on a certain credibility by association.

title: Poltergeist

title: The Exorcist

review: Some movies aren't just movies. They're closer to voodoo -- they channel currents larger and more powerful than themselves.

review: Friedkin and Blatty seem to care nothing for their characters as people, only as victims-props to be abused, hurled about the room, beaten and, in one case, brutally murdered.

title: The Exorcist
review: The Exorcist is not an unintelligently put-together film, which makes one all the more impatient with it.

title: The Exorcist
review: If movies are, among other things, opportunities for escapism, then The Exorcist is one of the most powerful ever made.

title: The Exorcist
review: There's something elemental about The Exorcist.

title: The Exorcist
review: There is nothing dated about The Exorcist, which remains an effective excursion into demonic possession more than a quarter of a century after it was first unveiled to the public.

title: The Exorcist
review: An expert telling of a supernatural horror story.

title: The Exorcist
review: This 1973 horror thriller is highly instructive as well as unnerving.

title: Gremlins
review: A wildly original roller-coaster ride of hilarious mischief.

title: Gremlins
review: A horror-comedy about cute little Christmas toy/pets who turn into murderous monsters wreaking havoc on a Norman Rockwellian town.

title: Gremlins
review: The humans are little more than dress-extras for the mechanics.

review: What's confusing yet ultimately illuminating is the way his gremlins function as a free-floating metaphor, suggesting at separate junctures everything from teenagers to blacks to various Freudian suppressions.

title: Gremlins
review: Dante is perhaps the first filmmaker since Frank Tashlin to base his style on the formal free-for-all of animated cartoons; he is also utterly heartless.

review: Dante gleefully sinks his teeth into the kind of fluffy, sugary, sickly small town fantasy beloved of his pal and sometime producer Spielberg.

title: Gremlins
review: At the level of Serious Film Criticism, it's a meditation on the myths in our movies: Christmas, families, monsters, retail stores, movies, boogeymen. At the level of Pop Moviegoing, it's a sophisticated, witty B movie.

title: Gremlins
review: Gremlins is far more interested in showing off its knowledge of movie lore and making random jokes than in providing consistent entertainment.

title: Gremlins 2: The New Batch
review: This uninhibited and uproarious monster bash, directed by Joe Dante, is more quick-witted and ironic than the original; it sets forth a savvy, slaphappy agenda before the opening credits and follows it straight through to the end, and even beyond.

review: An hilarious sequel featuring equal parts creature slapstick for the small fry and satirical barbs for adults.

title: Gremlins 2: The New Batch
review: There's almost enough in-joke ingenuity to justify the total absence of plot.

title: Gremlins 2: The New Batch
review: Speaks to the gleeful hell-raising monster in each of us, and it speaks with much more verve, cleverness and good humor than the film on which it is based. Add this to the very short list of sequels that neatly surpass their predecessors.

review: Too many gremlins and not enough story line.

title: Gremlins 2: The New Batch
review: Wicked fun.

review: For a good hour it's less like a wild-spirited comedy than a '60s Disney film with Dean Jones or Fred MacMurray.

title: The Goonies

review: While the pre-pubescents continually scream, their doting parents prove equally odious in a finale of astounding sentimentality.

review: The Goonies has every imaginable funhouse flourish. It has crooks, bats, cobwebs, skeletons, a lovable monster, an underground grotto and a treasure hidden by some of the most considerate, clue-loving pirates who ever lived.

review: Polish Wedding is a confident, light drama.

review: A nearly laugh-free comedy!

review: Pregnant With Problems!

review: Too many scenes float above reality!

review: Uneven and slightly muddled futuristic horror story -- not really science fiction, more like an antipollution PSA gone berserk.

review: Good, solid stuff, assembled efficiently enough to be pretty persuasive.

title: Soylent Green
review: Their 21st-century New York occasionally is frightening but it is rarely convincingly real.

title: Metropolis
review: Occasionally it strikes one that [Lang] wanted to include too much and then that all one anticipates does not appear. But at the same time the various ideas have been spliced together quite adroitly.

review: Each frame of this classic is drop-dead stunning.

review: I have just had a sensational night at the movies, and the picture was only 83 years old.

review: A fully realized work of art whose influence on science fiction, set design and symbolism can scarcely be put into words.

review: Too bad that so much really artistic work was wasted on this manufactured story.

title: Metropolis
review: This movie is certifiably nuts and naive in many ways, but it is so exciting.

review: There's no denying either the influence of Lang's vision -- so much of what he did in this film lives on that we take it as cultural assumption -- or the still valid energy of his storytelling.

review: Here's a coincidence: The first must-see movie of 2010 is also the must-see movie of 1927. The difference is that you can actually see it now. Or most of it.

review: The stunning cinematography, made crisper by present-day technology, and the film's overall visual concept continue to make your jaw drop with admiration.

review: Cleverly plotted, but commercially overloaded.
