title: Back to the Future Part III
review: Affectionate, innovative, and vaguely lunatic.

title: Back to the Future Part III
review: Except for Mr. Lloyd, the film is so sweet-natured and bland that it is almost instantly forgettable.

title: Back to the Future Part III
review: Divinely frivolous, nearly perfect fun.

title: Back to the Future Part III
review: Ties up all the loose ends but runs out of energy and inspiration.

title: Back to the Future Part III
review: Makes a few bows in the direction of time-travel complexities, and then settles down to be a routine Western comedy.

title: The AbsentMinded Professor
review: Flubber provides fuel for a very funny piece of hyperbolic humor in the grand American tradition of Paul Bunyan, and Director Robert Stevenson and Scriptwriter Bill Walsh get plenty of bounce out of every ounce.

title: The AbsentMinded Professor
review: MacMurray is ideally cast as the car-hopping prof, and plays the role with warmth and gusto.

title: Babes in Toyland
review: The film is an authentic children's entertainment and quite the merriest of its kind that Hollywood has turned loose on the nation's screens in a long time.

title: Babes in Toyland
review: This is a kid's movie rife with all the Freudian squalor that Disney repressed.

title: Bambi
review: This animated feature based on Felix Salten's book about the coming of age of a fawn and his various forest friends (including the beloved Thumper) does convey some of the primal emotional power of Disney's features during this period.

title: Bambi
review: For the first time, Disney has done his backgrounds in oils instead of watercolors. The result is striking.

title: Bambi
review: The glow and texture of the Disney brush reach new heights, especially in the treatment of a summer thunderstorm and a raging snowstorm.

title: Bambi
review: From Disney's richest period, interleaving splendid animation with vulgar Americana.

title: Bambi
review: In colors that would surprise even the spectrum itself, Disney's cartoon craftsmen have re-created a woodland that shimmers and glows and darkens altogether magically.

title: Dangerous Liaisons
review: This incisive study of sex as an arena for manipulative power games takes too long to catch fire and suffers from a deficient central performance.

title: Dangerous Liaisons
review: The creepy plot still holds a certain fascination.

title: Dangerous Liaisons
review: A sombre, manipulative affair in which the dA (C)cor is never allowed to usurp our interest.

title: Dangerous Liaisons
review: Witty, entertaining, if occasionally overripe.

title: Dangerous Liaisons
review: Director Stephen Frears accelerates entertainingly through Christopher Hampton's wig-and-powder sado-comedy about sexual mind games in 18th-century France.

title: Dangerous Liaisons
review: Tantalizingly wicked -- watching it makes the color rise to your cheeks.

title: Dangerous Liaisons
review: An absorbing and seductive movie.

title: The Last Temptation of Christ
review: In an age of post-Christian facetiousness, Martin Scorsese's work daringly attempts to restore passion and melodrama to the Gospel story.

title: The Last Temptation of Christ
review: A film of challenging ideas, and not salacious provocations.

title: The Last Temptation of Christ
review: Concentrating on the humanity and fallibility of Jesus in continual conflict with his divinity, the film falters as a contemporary statement mainly in its primitive view of women.

title: The Last Temptation of Christ
review: A sincere, typically ambitious and imaginative work from America's most provocatively intelligent film-maker.

title: The Last Temptation of Christ
review: What emerges most memorably is its sense of absolute conviction, never more palpable than in the final fantasy sequence that removes Jesus from the cross and creates for him the life of an ordinary man.

title: The Last Temptation of Christ
review: Among those who do not already have rigid views on the subject, this film is likely to inspire more serious thought on the nature of Jesus than any other ever made.

title: The Last Temptation of Christ
review: In spite of all [Scorsese] accomplishes, he is unable to bring Jesus close to us, to realize his stated goal of creating a universal figure who symbolizes the spiritual anguish of all men.

title: The Last Temptation of Christ
review: There are too many epic moments and impassioned performances to dismiss Scorsese's work.

title: The Godfather: Part III
review: The film is a slow fuse with a big bang -- one that echoes through every family whose own tragedy is an aching for things past and loved ones lost.

title: The Godfather: Part III
review: The movie, a heady thicket of political intrigue and double crosses, is slower, talkier, and more prosaic than the first two films, and its narrative seams sometimes show. And yet it's more than the sum of its mazelike convolutions.

title: The Godfather: Part III
review: The Godfather Part III matches its predecessors in narrative intensity, epic scope, socio-political analysis, physical beauty and deep feeling for its characters and milieu.

title: The Godfather: Part III
review: Represents a certain moral improvement over its predecessors by refusing to celebrate and condemn violence and duplicity in the same breath, or at least to the same degree.

title: The Godfather: Part III
review: The acting is merely passable, several characters are given nothing to do, and Michael's paranoid self-pity lends the film an absurd morality: Coppola expects us to sympathise with the semblance of virtue.

title: The Godfather: Part III
review: Most film sequels are strictly optional. The Godfather Part III is inevitable, and as such it's irresistible.

title: The Godfather: Part III
review: It may be that Coppola was right to put off filing this last installment all these years; from the evidence here, he had nothing more to say.

title: The Godfather: Part III
review: The Godfather Part III is a good movie, with moments of rare power, but it is not a great one -- a reason why many fans of the series have voiced their disappointment.

title: The Godfather: Part III
review: It is, I suspect, not even possible to understand this film without knowing the first two, and yet, knowing them, Part III works better than it should, evokes the same sense of wasted greatness, of misdirected genius.

title: The Godfather: Part III
review: [An] offer director Francis Ford Coppola should have refused.

title: Lolita
review: Where Nabokov was witty, Kubrick is sometimes merely snide, but fine performances (particularly from Peter Sellers, as the ominous Clare Quilty) cover most of the rough spots.

title: Lolita
review: Far more satisfying than his later works (one hesitates to call them mere movies).

title: Lolita
review: The picture has a rare power, a garbled but often moving push toward an off-beat communication.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Spielberg accomplishes these goals with a technical virtuosity that no other director, arguably in the history of the cinema, can even approach.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Saving Private Ryan is the war movie to end all war movies. It's the ultimate combat film, far outdistancing what until now had been the genre's World War II classics.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: The cast functions as an effective and believable unit. And Hanks gives a strong, increasingly solemn performance as its mysterious leader.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Dramatic lapses notwithstanding, Saving Private Ryan goes beyond technical dazzlement to put a new, indelibly terrible face on war.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Anyone who would like to know what superb filmmaking is all about need look no further than this overpowering movie.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: What Steven Spielberg has accomplished in Saving Private Ryan is to make violence terrible again. Nothing in the movie's melodramatic narrative can diminish the shocking immediacy of its combat scenes.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Searing, heartbreaking, so intense it turns your body into a single tube of clenched muscle, this is simply the greatest war movie ever made, and one of the great American movies.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Spielberg goes a long, long way toward overcoming his tendencies toward the shallow, but the visceral punch of his not-quite-masterful film is softened by an almost neurotic slickness that keeps getting in the way of the [issues it raises].

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Spielberg obviously decided that blood and guts meant just that, and so he arranged his violence into a semblance of pure disorder. The illusion holds, complete with severed limbs and wellsprings of blood, and it feels honorable.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Saving Private Ryan is Steven Spielberg's best war film and one of the two or three best movies the director has made.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: The great Hollywood battle films have told us repeatedly that war is hell. Saving Private Ryan, more than any other, is the one that shows it.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: War may be a faceless affair, but war movies shouldn't be.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: No further commentary is needed when the raw brutality of combat is presented as indelibly as it is here.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: I found it tediously manipulative despite its Herculean energy.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Why did Spielberg make it? He wants us to imagine we can feel the terror of being there, but does that make us any wiser about this or any other conflict? Probably not.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: The greatest Steven Spielberg movie since the last great one? Sure.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: A powerful and impressive milestone in the realistic depiction of combat, Saving Private Ryan is as much an experience we live through as a film we watch on screen.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: For all the care and thoughtfulness that follow in the story, I never could shake the impression that all I was watching was every other war film Spielberg had ever seen.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: As compelling, intimate and brutally realistic an account of men at war as you've ever seen.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: A powerful experience.

title: The Barefoot Executive
review: In this genial but strained and arch frolic, the one real joke is not only "in" but it wears thin and even frantic.

title: The Black Cauldron
review: The characters, though cute and cuddly and sweet and mean and ugly and simply awful, don't really have much to do that would remain of interest to any but the youngest minds.

title: The Black Cauldron
review: It's quite good, though by the impossible standards the film sets for itself it inevitably falls short.

title: The Black Cauldron
review: As usual it is technically excellent, but the charm, characterisation and sheer good humour that made features like Pinocchio and Jungle Book so enjoyable are sadly absent.

title: The Black Cauldron
review: This is the 25th full-length animated feature from Walt Disney studios, and professionally put together as it is, many of the ingredients may seem programmed to those who have seen some of the others.

title: The Black Cauldron
review: The backgrounds are as richly textured and detailed as in any other Disney film.

title: The Black Cauldron
review: By the end of The Black Cauldron I was remembering, with something of a shock of nostalgia, the strength and utter storytelling conviction of the early Disney animators. The Black Cauldron is a return to the tradition.

title: The Black Hole
review: It is good to see the Disney craftsmen doing what they do best on such a grand and risky scale. If one has time for only one space opera this season, this is the one to choose.

title: The Black Hole
review: Disney's most ambitious and costly production to date -- about a spaceship crew which encounters a Black Hole and a long-lost madman -- and if looks were everything, you could hardly fault it.

title: The Black Hole
review: It cost half as much as Star Trek and looks better -- not as lavish, perhaps, but more original. The special effects are fancy, and the design even more so.

title: The Black Hole
review: Takes us all the way to the rim of space only to bog us down in a talky melodrama whipped up out of mad scientists and haunted houses.

title: Cheetah
review: Cheetah brings to focus the concerns of experts and laymen alike.

title: Condorman
review: An ideological intervention from the Disney machine: the Cold War re-heated for the kiddies.

title: Condorman
review: It is painless and chaste, and it has a lot of beautiful scenery and beautiful clothes. There are worse things to watch while you eat popcorn.

title: Darby O'Gill and the Little People
review: [An] overpoweringly charming concoction of standard Gaelic tall stories, fantasy and romance.

title: Darby O'Gill and the Little People
review: For those of a sentimental turn, there is the delight of watching young Connery romancing the ineffably wholesome Janet Munro, a couple of years before things turned nasty for Commander Bond at Crab Key with the somewhat more knowing Ursula Andress.

title: The Devil and Max Devlin
review: The script has its moments, especially when Cosby is around as the Devil's aide, but the film finally subsides in a welter of structural flaws and heartwarming sentiment.

title: The Devil and Max Devlin
review: The performances are attractive though, with one exception, not especially memorable.

title: Flight of the Navigator
review: When the film shifts into the action mode in its second half -- the flying saucer returns to aid in David`s rescue -- it becomes quite bright and lively.

title: Flight of the Navigator
review: If there is more than a little something borrowed from Spielberg, Kleiser's movie is amiably undemanding entertainment that says the right things, albeit without great originality.

title: Flight of the Navigator
review: There's no mistaking Flight of the Navigator for a really first-rate children's picture like, say, The Black Stallion. But Flight of the Navigator is an enjoyable film that encourages kids to use their heads.

title: Flight of the Navigator
review: Whereas its plot may be derivative--and at several junctures, unconvincing--"Flight of the Navigator" nevertheless manages to develop considerable humor and poignancy from David's predicament and what he does about it.

title: Flight of the Navigator
review: This children's adventure turns out to be, despite its title, less of a Star Wars trip than an entertaining variation on the time-travel adventure Back to the Future.

title: Flight of the Navigator
review: Instead of creating an eye-opening panorama, Flight of the Navigator looks through the small end of the telescope. Life on Earth is magnified but without an expansive vision.

title: Flight of the Navigator
review: One for the none too discerning youngster.

title: Flight of the Navigator
review: This is a film with its head in the clouds, its feet on the ground and -- just often enough -- its heart on its sleeve, in which space-age special effects take second place to family emotions.

title: Flight of the Navigator
review: At times a bit too precious, especially inside the young navigator's spacecraft, but the warm regard for character, as well as for our often-inhospitable planetary home, makes for a reasonably good time.

title: The Great Mouse Detective
review: As usual with film noir, however, it is the villain who steals the heart and one is rooting for in the breathtaking showdown high up in the cogs and ratchets of Big Ben.

title: The Great Mouse Detective
review: Small children may be afraid of some of the bad characters -- the Disney Studio's gift for creating really nasty bad guys means that they are scary -- but they will love the cute, brave mice and cheer their triumphs. Adults will enjoy the wit and style.

title: The Great Mouse Detective
review: It's a lot of fun.

title: Herbie Goes Bananas
review: It's not surprising that they haven't got around to changing the plot formula, only the scenery.

title: Herbie Goes Bananas
review: A cheerful, four-cylinder children's movie, though its car jokes aren't good for much mileage.

title: Honey, I Shrunk the Kids
review: [It's] in the best tradition of Disney -- and even better than that, because it is not so juvenile that adults won't be thoroughly entertained.

title: Honey, I Shrunk the Kids
review: Sterling entertainment...

title: Honey, I Shrunk the Kids
review: As sweet, straightforward and funny as its title.

title: Honey, I Shrunk the Kids
review: Though it relies on special effects, this cutie-pie caper never loses sight of the protagonists amid the bigger-than-life Cheerios and 40-foot blades of grass.

title: Honey, I Shrunk the Kids
review: The special effects are all there, nicely in place, and the production values are sound, but the movie is dead in the water.

title: BASEketball
review: I was bored well before the end, but found the first half hour pretty funny.

title: BASEketball
review: Jenny McCarthy and Ernest Borgnine -- together at last.

title: BASEketball
review: Their incessant, obscene banter is meant to be endearing; their total lack of presence makes it simply annoying.

title: BASEketball
review: What kind of movie is it where Yasmine Bleeth is the best thing about it?

title: BASEketball
review: The vulgar, obvious humor of Zucker brother David and South Park creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone elicits easy, guilty laughs, yet the material has an underlying innocence that's just shy of good clean fun.

title: BASEketball
review: The kind of flick that serves itself up as the object of its own satire.

title: BASEketball
review: If you're old enough to see this movie without a parent or guardian and all that sounds encouraging, this review has failed, and failed badly.

title: BASEketball
review: The comedy sets up some very big targets -- the commercialization of sport, crass franchise owners, sentimental idolatry of players, exploitation of foreign workers by superstar merchandisers -- and then lobs tiny spitballs at them.

title: BASEketball
review: [A] funny, gleefully offensive spoof of professional sports.

title: BASEketball
review: It's not very funny and tries to buy laughs with puerile shocks.

title: Full Tilt Boogie
review: A bit late in the day, but nevertheless welcome.

title: Out of the Past
review: Each change of angle and shift of light evokes an inner disturbance; the actors seem to push through the dense shadow as through water, revealing fast people in slow motion ...

title: Out of the Past
review: Direction by Jacques Tourneur pays close attention to mood development, achieving realistic flavor that is further emphasized by real life settings and topnotch lensing by Nicholas Musuraca.

title: Out of the Past
review: The most delicate and nuanced of film noirs, graced with a reflective lyricism that almost lifts it out of the genre.

title: Out of the Past
review: All these B movie poets were under contract to RKO in the winter of 1946, and produced the best movie of everyone involved -- once seen, never forgotten.

title: Out of the Past
review: One of the greatest of all film noirs.

title: Out of the Past
review: It's very snappy and quite intriguingly played by a cast that has been well and smartly directed by Jacques Tourneur.

title: Out of the Past
review: Cinematic perfection, a Hollywood classic that's as great and as enjoyable as its reputation has promised.

title: Doctor Zhivago
review: Literate, oldfashioned, soul-filling and thoroughly romantic.

title: Doctor Zhivago
review: David Lean's 1965 adaptation of Pasternak's romance of the Russian Revolution is intelligent and handsomely mounted, though it doesn't use its length to build to a particularly complex emotional effect.

title: Doctor Zhivago
review: One of the most meticulously designed and executed films.

title: Doctor Zhivago
review: Steiger and Courtenay excepted, all the performances are very uncomfortable.

title: Doctor Zhivago
review: Mr. Bolt has reduced the vast upheaval of the Russian Revolution to the banalities of a doomed romance.

title: Doctor Zhivago
review: Although its portentous historical drama evaporates once you return to the fresh air, watching it can be seductive.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: A sprawling, ornately constructed entertainment.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: This premiere of the original cut, running at 312 minutes, leaves room for more than a story of one life.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: Sumptuous, haunting, and unusually tender... a nakedly psychological 'in' to [Bergman's] earliest artistic impulses; nothing else in his oeuvre addresses so directly his childhood escapes into fantasy as the by-product of a harsh Lutheran upbringing.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: Our young protagonist will be obsessed with death and see ghosts everywhere. Never has the prison of childhood seemed so inescapable.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: The result is one of Bergman's most haunting and suggestive films.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: A sumptuously produced period piece that is also a rich tapestry of childhood memoirs and moods, fear and fancy, employing all the manners and means of the best of cinematic theatrical from high and low comedy to darkest tragedy.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: It's a marvellously engrossing and thought-provoking film, filled with dazzling dramatic set-pieces and witty, knowing allusions to its creator's artistic conceits and deceits.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: Utterly enthralling.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: A fitting introduction to the very personal cinema of this master craftsman, not only because it exhibits Bergman's signature themes and stylistic devices, but also because it is one of his most life-affirming films.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: [Bergman] glides beyond the mere telling of his story into a kind of hypnotic series of events that have the clarity and fascination of dreams. Rarely have I felt so strongly during a movie that my mind had been shifted into a different kind of reality.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: It is very much, and in the best way, an old man's movie, the work of an artist resigned to life's mystery, full of wonder at the passage of time, full of forgiveness for past wrongs, and full of understanding.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: Bergman's 1982 career summation and the kind of rich, timeless, cautionless magnum opus we can only receive, like benedictions, from artists who've paid their generation's dues of sweat, risk, tears, and honesty.

title: Fanny och Alexander
review: A big, dark, beautiful, generous family chronicle, which touches on many of the themes from earlier films while introducing something that, in Bergman, might pass for serenity.

title: The 'burbs
review: A long shaggy dog story.

title: Il portiere di notte
review: A strange, brooding tale.

title: Il portiere di notte
review: With a little application and imagination I suppose one might read themes of political and philosophical import into this work, but Cavani's style remains stupidly literal and gaga.

title: Il portiere di notte
review: Somewhere along the way, the film's handling of serious themes, and its attempts to examine the Nazi legacy in terms of repression and guilt, both sexual and political, get lost amid all the self-conscious decadence.

title: Il portiere di notte
review: The movie's visual virtues are negated by infinite absurdities -- particularly by the sentimentality with which the director views this luckless couple.

title: Il portiere di notte
review: The Night Porter is as nasty as it is lubricious, a despicable attempt to titillate us by exploiting memories of persecution and suffering.

title: Mephisto
review: Few have dared what Brandauer accomplishes: showing us a good actor responding to the same neurotic drive for the center of the stage, the immortalizing role. His is a great performance, nothing less.

title: Mephisto
review: A disappointingly thin, conventional film.

title: Mephisto
review: Hungaro pic shows extraordinary period flair for the Germany of the 1920s and '30s, balanced acting by a multinational cast, and exemplary direction.

title: Mephisto
review: A superbly modulated, fruitfully ambivalent central performance by Brandauer carries the emotional and intellectual weight of the political dilemma.

title: Mephisto
review: The actor is played by Klaus Maria Brandauer in one of the greatest movie performances I've ever seen.

title: Mephisto
review: Mephisto seems somewhat remote, without all the urgency of which Mr. Szabo has shown himself capable.

title: Blue Velvet
review: It made me feel pity for the actors who worked in it and anger at the director for taking liberties with them.

title: Blue Velvet
review: Not quite like any other thriller or erotic mystery you've ever seen.

title: Blue Velvet
review: The movie doesn't progress or deepen, it just gets weirder, and to no good end.

title: The Journey of Natty Gann
review: Director Jeremy Paul Kagan extracts an engaging performance from Meredith Salenger as the heroine.

title: The Journey of Natty Gann
review: There's a real sense of period, even if the film does occasionally become over-sentimental.

title: The Journey of Natty Gann
review: As Wolf, a dog named Jed gives a forthright and believable performance. Miss Salenger, for her part, gives one, too, and she carries the movie nicely.

title: The Journey of Natty Gann
review: It's nice to see a Disney film that follows the rules of the family-film genre as Walt laid them down.

title: Lady and the Tramp
review: Walt Disney has for so long parlayed gooey sentiment and stark horror into profitable cartoons that most moviegoers are apt to be more surprised than disappointed to discover that the combination somehow does not work this time.

title: Lady and the Tramp
review: The wider canvas and extra detail work reportedly meant an additional 30% in negative cost. It was a sound investment.

title: Lady and the Tramp
review: Disney's imagination seems at a low ebb, saddled with a shrunken, excessively naturalistic style in line with the diminished possibilities of postwar animation, and not yet graced by the inspiration that would redeem that style in Sleeping Beauty.

title: Lady and the Tramp
review: Happily the cameo lowlife, an excellent manic beaver, the famously villainous Siamese, and classic songs rescue the film from dumb animal sentiment.

title: Lady and the Tramp
review: The sentimentality is mighty, and the use of the CinemaScope size does not make for any less awareness of the thickness of the goo.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: The Little Mermaid -- impudent, grandiose, a multilevel crowd-pleaser -- almost returns the Disney animated features to their glory traditions of the '30s and '40s.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: It may not be a transcendent masterpiece of the Disney canon, but The Little Mermaid is still very heartening: It suggests the Disney magic isn`t lost after all.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: The latest Disney offering looks back to the studio's unrivaled heritage. It has the look of classic animation. More important, it has the skill required to make it work.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: In adapting this animated film from Hans Christian Andersen's sad and beautiful fairy tale, writers/directors John Musker and Ron Clements came up with a bright and perky movie.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: You could wish upon a star and not conjure up a more joyous animated movie than this graceful retelling of the Hans Christian Andersen tale.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: Within the apparently necessary aesthetic and ideological limitations (such as making the hero and heroine Americans surrounded by foreign servants a la Pinocchio), the animation manages to be fairly energetic.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: A fantastic success.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: May represent Disney's best animated feature since the underrated Sleeping Beauty in 1959.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: This return to traditional Disney territory is geared to captivate children while allowing them to maintain their street cred, largely by combining extravagant animated technique with ranging musical styles.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: A marvel of skillful animation, witty songwriting and smart planning.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: Even at its highest points, it cannot claim a place next to even the least of the great Disney classics.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: A movie that's so creative and so much fun it deserves comparison with the best Disney work of the past.

title: The Mighty Ducks
review: Very lame ice-hockey flick.

title: The Mighty Ducks
review: The film is remarkably oblivious to the fact that if the team weren't hell-bent on a championship, young moviegoers would be significantly less interested in its adventures.

title: The Mighty Ducks
review: It must be said that this movie is sweet and innocent, and that at a certain level it might appeal to younger kids. I doubt if its ambitions reach much beyond that.

title: The Mighty Ducks
review: Those not yet wise to formulaic pablum are likely to enjoy this ice hockey kiddie ensemble comedy. But their older escorts might want to bring a novel and a flashlight, or a Walkman or portable television with earphones.

title: The Mighty Ducks
review: Steven Brill, who has a small role in the film, constructed the screenplay much as one would put together some of those particleboard bookcases from Ikea.

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
review: The fit between sentiment and satire is not always a comfortable one and the more dedicated fans of either the story or the Muppets may leave theaters dissatisfied.

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
review: Nothing can really diminish the late Jim Henson's irresistibly appealing characters.

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
review: This is the dullest and least successful adaptation of the Christmas chestnut I've ever seen.

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
review: Good fun.

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
review: There's no great show of wit or tunefulness here, and the ingenious cross-generational touches are fairly rare. But there is a lively kiddie version of the Dickens tale, one that very young viewers ought to understand.

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
review: Like all the Muppet movies, this one is a musical, with original songs by Paul Williams (my favorite is the early chain-rattling duet by the Marley brothers). It could have done with a few more songs than it has.

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
review: The Muppet Christmas Carol isn't terrible, by any means. But it's resoundingly moderate, with merely passable songs by Paul Williams, and only occasional real laughter.

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
review: Neither drama nor comedy, it's safe stuff, and most un-Muppetlike. So much for great expectations.

title: Newsies
review: Certain movies engage your affections so strongly that, even if they start to fall apart, you tend to keep rooting for them. That's pretty much the case with Newsies.

title: Newsies
review: A Disney musical with an undistinguished score, fair to middling choreography, and clunky direction that still manages to be entertaining in spots because of its story.

title: Newsies
review: Bale and Menken are literally what make the movie sing.

title: Newsies
review: Despite Newsies' many flaws, it's bracing to see Disney attempt a PG movie about something as meaty as labor relations. Would that every strike be resolved with so little bloodshed and so many songs.

title: Newsies
review: Stop the presses! Newsies is the best live-action movie musical since Little Shop of Horrors.

title: Newsies
review: An old-fashioned musical that is better when its characters sing and dance than when they talk.

title: Newsies
review: Though the cast is large, no interesting or even moderately well-rounded personalities emerge from it, and no compelling relationships emerge between the characters.

title: Newsies
review: The movie stands as a textbook demonstration of why they don't -- and probably shouldn't -- make 'em like they used to.

title: Newsies
review: The writers have created cardboard cutouts instead of flesh-and-blood characters.

title: Newsies
review: It's a bit of a throwback and a solid family film and, at the time, represented a well-intentioned leap of faith of the sort that studios rarely take.

title: Newsies
review: If you have a soft spot for feisty, back-talking bambini with cute squints, backwards caps and names like Crutchy, Dutchy and Bumlets, your heart will melt.

title: Newsies
review: This film's real trouble lies in its joyless, pointless execution.

title: Newsies
review: Although the material does indeed involve young protagonists, no effort is made to show their lives in a way today's kids can identify with. This movie must seem as odd to them as a foreign film.

Flash: There is intelligent life in outer space. More, anyway, than in this amiable footnote of a movie.
A hodge-podge of bits and pieces.
Hyams' sequel to Kubrick's big daddy of sci-fi movies may not have the novelty of 2001: A Space Odyssey, but it is still a better film than anyone could have dared to expect.
A good-looking, sharp-edged, entertaining, exciting space opera.
A lot of care has gone into it, but it has no satirical substructure to match that of the Kubrick film, and which was eventually responsible for that film's continuing popularity.

Now that enough time has elapsed since the release of 2010 for outraged 2001 fans to calm down, it can be seen that, while there was no decisive creative reason for Hyams' sequel to exist, it's not a bad movie.

title: Rushmore

review: If happiness is finding something you love to do and doing it forever, one of my somethings might just be watching this oddly uproarious little flick.

title: The Killing
review: An engrossing little adventure.

title: Killer's Kiss
review: Kubrick's low-key lensing occasionally catches the flavor of the seamy side of Gotham life.

title: Killer's Kiss
review: A noirish thriller with experimental trimmings that holds back most of the emotions, sensitive as well as otherwise, that threatened to make Kubrick's first feature mawkish.

title: Killer's Kiss
review: Kubrick makes the most of flashback and dream sequences, and a surreal climactic fight in a warehouse full of mannequins.

title: Killer's Kiss
review: Kubrick worked in an uncharacteristically naturalistic style despite the genre material, with mixed but still fascinating results.

title: Spartacus
review: This may be the most literate of all the spectacles set in antiquity.

title: Spartacus
review: Asurprisingly apt companion piece to Paths of Glory in its consideration of the mechanisms of power.

title: Spartacus
review: It is a spotty, uneven drama.

title: Spartacus
review: The most courageous thing about it, from today's standards, is that it closes without an obligatory happy ending, and an audience that has watched for 187 minutes doesn't get a tidy, mindless conclusion.

title: Barry Lyndon
review: One of cinema's most heartfelt and sustained (it runs over three hours), if cynical, visions of an individual's powerlessness.

title: Barry Lyndon
review: Stanley Kubrick's magisterial Thackeray adaptation now stands as one of his greatest and most savagely ironic films, not to mention one of the few period pieces on celluloid so transporting that it seems to predate the invention of cameras.

title: Barry Lyndon
review: Ryan O'Neal's excellent performance captures the shallow opportunism endemic to the title character who is brought down as much by his own flaws as by the mores of the ordered social structure of 18th-century England.

title: Barry Lyndon
review: All of Stanley Kubrick's features look better now than when they were first released, but Barry Lyndon, which fared poorly at the box office in 1975, remains his most underrated. It may also be his greatest.

title: Barry Lyndon
review: Barry Lyndon isn't a great success, and it's not a great entertainment, but it's a great example of directorial vision: Kubrick saying he's going to make this material function as an illustration of the way he sees the world.

title: Barry Lyndon
review: The constant array of waxworks figures against lavish backdrops finally vulgarises the visual sumptuousness.

title: Barry Lyndon
review: The loveliest of Stanley Kubrick films. Indeed, Barry Lyndon is the one Kubrick movie that could even invite that adjective (or epithet).

title: Barry Lyndon
review: Another fascinating challenge from one of our most remarkable, independent-minded directors.

title: Barry Lyndon
review: Maybe the only abstract maxim that one can derive from Kubrick's new film is: 'Openness is everything.'

title: Les quatre cents coups
review: One of the first glistening droplets of the French New Wave.

title: Les quatre cents coups
review: Seems forever young.

title: Les quatre cents coups
review: Forget my curmudgeonly attitude and see it -- again, or for the first time -- for yourself.

title: Les quatre cents coups
review: A remarkable confluence of talents are at work here.

title: Les quatre cents coups
review: Distinguished by its intensity of feeling and freewheeling use of the wide-screen frame, the film ranks among Truffaut's best.

title: Les quatre cents coups
review: An engaging, moving film.

title: Les quatre cents coups
review: Still one of the cinema's most perceptive forays into childhood.

title: Les quatre cents coups
review: Amazingly, this vigorous effort is the first feature film of M. Truffaut, who had previously been (of all things!) the movie critic for a French magazine.

title: Les quatre cents coups
review: For all of Truffaut's mastery of the behind-the-camera aspects of The 400 Blows, an equal share of the credit must go to lead actor Jean-Pierre Leaud.

title: Les quatre cents coups
review: The later films have their own merits, and Stolen Kisses is one of Truffaut's best, but The 400 Blows, with all its simplicity and feeling, is in a class by itself.

title: Jules et Jim
review: More than 40 years old, Francois Truffaut's whirling dervish remains an ageless beauty.

title: Jules et Jim
review: With this 1961 film Truffaut comes closest to the spirit and sublimity of his mentor, Jean Renoir, and the result is a masterpiece of the New Wave.

title: Jules et Jim
review: Truffaut's third film may not look the masterpiece it seemed 40-odd years ago, but it remains one of his most enjoyable movies.

title: Jules et Jim
review: There is joy in the filmmaking that feels fresh today and felt audacious at the time.

title: Jules et Jim
review: To put it quickly and crisply, it is charming, exciting and sad.

title: Vibes
review: Vibes is a harmless, painless romp but it's an instance of a sincere attempt at screwball comedy that simply got screwed up.

title: Vibes
review: Vibes is a low-vibration romantic comedy about two incompatible psychics falling in love on an Ecuadorean treasure hunt, and everything in it seems nine or 10 beats off.

title: Vibes
review: Luckily, Vibes has those quirky stars, a wacky threesome who give off good vibes under any circumstances.

title: Vibes
review: The romantic suspense soon takes a back seat to some singularly unimpressive special effects.

title: Vibes
review: Vibes has all the ingredients of lighthearted adventure-comedy except the essential one: laughs.

title: Vibes
review: The miscast and downright miserable company attempts zaniness against the exotic South American backdrop.

title: Vibes
review: Movies like Vibes appear and disappear like fireflies in the dog days of summer. Nobody seems to have made them, nobody sees them, nobody remembers them.

title: The Golden Child
review: This film -- insignificant and lightweight and monumentally silly -- is entertaining from beginning to end.

title: The Golden Child
review: A half-baked comedy without a heart.

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
review: Awesome splendor and a striking essay on celebrity reward those who brave the 2 1/2-hour run time.

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
review: It's a view of the West beyond the myth that's worth enduring, if not relishing.

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
review: Brad Pitt as Jesse James: Seldom has an actor been so perfectly cast.

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
review: The one thing you're not supposed to do during a Western is doze off.

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
review: A better title might have been Jesse James in the Age of Pop Therapy.

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

review: Mostly ponderous, despite the unceasingly beautiful imagery.

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
review: As this old and twisted Jesse, Brad Pitt is quite good. But the movie really belongs to Casey Affleck as Robert Ford.

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
review: If you love classic and stylish mood Westerns such as McCabe and Mrs. Miller and The Long Riders, this is your film.

title: Crimes of the Heart

review: [It] has the dubious distinction of calling attention to just about everything the play isn't, and was never meant to be.

title: Crimes of the Heart

title: Crimes of the Heart

title: Crimes of the Heart

title: The Color Purple
review: It is a great, warm, hard, unforgiving, triumphant movie, and there is not a scene that does not shine with the love of the people who made it.

title: No Mercy

title: No Mercy
review: Count me among those who would be happy never to see another starring role for Gere, except maybe as Felix in a remake of The Odd Couple.

title: No Mercy
review: A standard-issue cop thriller that amounts to Beverly Hills Cop in a bad mood.

title: No Mercy

title: Native Son

title: Native Son
review: The movie understands that the story really is about the killer's point of view. It is not the story of a crime, not a docudrama, not a sociological essay.

title: Radio Days

title: Radio Days

title: Radio Days
review: As free in form as it is generous of spirit.

title: Radio Days
review: You peel and peel away at it only to find, in the end, nothing.

title: Radio Days
review: "Radio Days" is so ambitious and so audacious that it almost defies description.

title: Radio Days
review: Childhood anecdotes and charming vignettes are set against bright-light, big-city sets, a-dazzle with beautiful players.

review: Midler and Long are never less than fun to watch.

review: As a vehicle for their considerable comic talents, the enterprise is wheelclamped by typecasting.

title: The Iron Giant

title: The Iron Giant

title: The Iron Giant
review: It is in the best tradition of animation: an ideal tale for children that offers a lot to adults as well.

title: The Iron Giant
review: A smart live-and-let-live parable, full of glancing, acute observations on all kinds of big subjects...that you can talk about with the kids for a long time to come.

title: The Iron Giant
review: This is enjoyable in part because of its flavorsome period ambience and its lively and satiric characters.

title: The Iron Giant
review: A cool, unique-looking animated feature (the Ike-era design elements make for great eye candy), director Brad Bird's tale of a small-town boy and his outer-space robot is hip and entertaining without pandering, or condescending, to the kiddie set.

title: The Iron Giant
review: As entertaining as it's intelligent.

title: The Iron Giant
review: One of those rare films that will hold the attention of children in the 6 to 12 age range without insulting the intelligence of the adults who accompany them.

title: The Iron Giant

title: The Iron Giant

title: The Iron Giant
review: Imagine E.T. as a towering metal man, and you have some of the appeal of The Iron Giant, an enchanting animated feature about a boy who makes friends with a robot from outer space.

title: The Iron Giant
review: The Iron Giant is funny, warm, muscular and full of nuances that you can take home with you and talk about.

title: The Iron Giant
review: The Iron Giant remembers the wonder of being a child and understands how to convey that in a media-savvy age.

title: The Iron Giant

title: The Iron Giant
review: A lovely and touching daydream.

title: The Iron Giant

title: The Iron Giant
review: Beautifully animated!

title: The Iron Giant

title: The Sixth Sense

review: Techine keeps a tight rein on his actors' dramatics.

review: Inside Man is an exercise in showy, cynical hollowness.

title: Inside Man
review: Exceptionally well written with clever twists and witty dialogue by first-time screenwriter Russell Gewirtz, Inside Man is adroitly executed by director Spike Lee.

title: Inside Man
review: Intercutting post-robbery interrogation scenes with the action at hand, makes Inside Man a substantial and satisfying affair.

title: Inside Man
review: It's a leisurely stroll through the caper genre, with twists aplenty.

title: Inside Man
review: Lee seems less interested in scoring easy sociological points than ratcheting up the stakes of Gewirtz's cunning heist scenario, which offers little in the way of wiggle room for latecomers.

title: Inside Man
review: Inside Man is the sort of movie that makes you think. The big star heist thriller is coiled in tricky turns of plot.

title: Inside Man
review: Inside Man, a crackling, twisty thriller about a bank heist that shows he [Spike Lee] can make an expensive, mainstream movie that's every bit as well-crafted as the personal, arty films to which he has devoted most of his career.

title: Inside Man
review: Lee takes the usual potshots at this stewpot of race, power and politics. Only here it's effective as part of the story, as opposed to when it's wielded like a tire iron in the context of a polemic.

title: Inside Man
review: Unexpectedly funny, leisurely paced and oblivious to the demands of its genre, Inside Man has a loose, playful vibe that's at odds with its grave life-and-death scenario.

title: Inside Man
review: Inside Man may be a genre flick, but its direction is certifiably Lee -- sprinkled with trademark themes and visual cues, including his specialty, the strapped-to-a-factory-belt dolly shot.

title: Inside Man
review: Inside Man brings Lee back into the mainstream while still letting him have some fun, and he passes that fun on to the audience.

title: Inside Man
review: Inside Man gives us back the stuff that once made Lee's movies entertaining: the snappy, sassy dialogue, the hip attitude, the obvious insight into the racial divide.

title: They Shoot Horses, Don't They?

title: They Shoot Horses, Don't They?

review: Brian Yusna has replaced Stuart Gordon in the director's chair, without bringing new life to the affair. Even the jokes in the Woody Keith/Rick Fry screenplay seem refried, suggesting that all too much of this Bride is old and borrowed...

review: See it and worry.

review: The aftereffect of Coma is a catlike yawn, benign and bored.

review: Overwrought and overly facile look at accounts payable in the afterlife.

review: Stronger on mores than amore, a half smile for a summer night.

review: Prepare yourself to be demolished when you go to see it -- and go you must, because it's one of those films everybody will soon be buzzing about.

review: Mr. Lemmon is little short of brilliant...

review: As beneficial as helmer's influence may be to that aging franchise, his work here reps a fascinating use of the docu form.

review: A grand slam!

review: Offers a deeper immersion in that old '50s feeling than any other Hollywood film in recent memory.

review: A pleasant and worthy addition to a strong series of films.

review: It's alluring to see a costume drama that takes us inside the subtlest, most wrenching realities of money.

review: A fine addition to the filmed Austen canon.

review: Often deeply ludicrous, it's just as often deeply moving.

review: There are moments to treasure, but they're small and delicately crafted -- actors' moments.

title: Last Chance Harvey
review: There's not a believable minute in the 92 minutes of Last Chance Harvey, but Dustin Hoffman and Emma Thompson smooth over most of the problems just by showing up and doing what they do for a living.

title: Last Chance Harvey

review: This is as tepid as two-hours-in-the-cup old tea.

review: Add uniformly good acting to Sayles' script of dark coal pits, West Virginia spirit and cowboyish melodrama and you have stirring cinema.

review: The Grapes of Wrath is just about as good as any picture has a right to be; if it were any better, we just wouldn't believe our eyes.

review: The Grapes of Wrath was often named the greatest American film, until it was dethroned by the re-release of Citizen Kane.

title: The Shop Around the Corner

review: ...a pretty kettle of bubbling brew it makes under Mr. Lubitsch's deft and tender management and with a genial company to play it gently, well this side of farce and well that side of utter seriousness.

review: Let yourself go and be rewarded by the sight of a hero running home to victory through clouds of fire.

title: The Natural
review: Arguably the best baseball movie ever made.

title: Shampoo

review: This 1975 feature is slick and often funny, but the smugness of the satire and the stunted emotions are finally wearying.

review: Redford's movie is too little show and too much tell.

review: This has the feel of something genuine: sweet, touching, and sentimental.

review: It doesn't hurt matters that the story's set in one of the world's most beautiful corners -- rendered in pre-twilight glows by cinematographer Philippe Rousselot.

title: Fatal Attraction

review: While billed as a romance and a thriller, the film strictly qualifies as neither, appealing to our prurience, guilt, hatred, and dread.

review: A predictable dog's dinner of Pavlovian thriller cliches, this will appeal strongly to those who think women should be kept on a short lead.

review: Close should take pride in her performance. She should also expect a depressing avalanche of scripts requiring a she-wacko.

review: Fatal Attraction has an inescapable pull to it; it's suffocatingly exciting.

title: Fatal Attraction
review: Because the good things in the movie -- including the performances -- are so very good, it's a shame that the film's potential for greatness was so blatantly compromised.

title: Jagged Edge

review: The wholesome cast completely obliterates the unstated perversities that have been this genre's reason for being.

review: Supremely effective.

review: It's as honest and direct and entertaining as the considerable talents of everyone involved can make it.

title: Midnight Run

title: Midnight Run
review: Grodin and De Niro are different kinds of actors, but they share a knack for detail and a gift for understatement that keeps their scenes together crackling.

title: Midnight Run
review: Midnight Run touches on one of the great mysteries of the movies: How is it that the tritest material can come to life when touched by the right director and the right actors?

title: Midnight Run
review: Funny, unpredictable and refreshingly adult.

title: Midnight Run
review: The result is one of the most entertaining, best executed, original road pictures ever.

title: Midnight Run
review: That old formula, handcuffed captor and captive who become buddies on the run, gets an injection of new life from the playing of the cast.

title: Midnight Run
review: Mr. De Niro and Mr. Grodin are lunatic delights, which is somewhat more than can be said for the movie, whose mechanics keep getting in the way of the performances.

review: Much as he might try, Brest can't masquerade this mainstream Hollywood studio picture as an offbeat little character piece.

review: Whoever cast De Niro and Grodin must have had a sixth sense for the chemistry they would have; they work together so smoothly, and with such an evident sense of fun, that even their silences are intriguing.

title: Midnight Run
review: Brest propels the drama forward with planes, trains and automobiles (helicopters, too), but also makes time for De Niro, Grodin, and an excellent supporting cast, to make the frenetic ride well worth the trip.

title: Midnight Run
review: Miraculously, De Niro and Grodin turn this sow's ear into a plausible vehicle for a buddy movie, and thanks to both of them, this movie springs to life.

title: Backdraft

title: Backdraft
review: Visually, pic often is exhilarating, but it's shapeless and dragged down by corny, melodramatic characters and situations.

title: Backdraft
review: Visually speaking, the film does pretty well with fire-as-spectacle, less well with everything else (Howard tends to trot out fuzzy-toned Spielbergian backlighting on any pretext).

title: Backdraft
review: The fire sequences are stunning, and the build-up to them, complete with blaring sirens and bellowed conversations, has an aggressive immediacy.

title: Backdraft
review: The spectacular fire sequences, which must have been hellish to film, are powerfully enveloping on screen, thanks especially to the eerie effect of the title.

title: Backdraft
review: Backdraft is sure to do for fire what The Poseidon Adventure did for water.

title: Backdraft
review: [The scenes involving fire] are so good they make me recommend the movie anyway, despite its brain-damaged screenplay.

title: Backdraft
review: Director Howard is so mesmerized by the flames, he squirts formulaic lighter fluid over everything.

title: The Fisher King
review: Visually impressive, frequently pretentious, and extremely fluid as narrative (the 137 minutes sail by effortlessly), this mythic comedy-drama presents Gilliam as half seer, half snake-oil salesman and defies you to sort out which is which.

title: The Fisher King
review: The Fisher King has two actors at the top of their form, and a compelling, well-directed and well-produced story.

title: The Fisher King
review: Working within the constraints of a big studio film has brought out Gilliam's best: he's become a true storyteller and a wonderful director of actors. This time he delights not only the eye but the soul.

title: The Fisher King
review: Scary, touching, often hilarious, this modern fairytale is surprisingly enchanting.

title: The Fisher King
review: For every wild ride through Manhattan by an imaginary Red Knight trailing billows of flame, there is a small, comic encounter in a more down-to-earth mode.

title: The Fisher King
review: So what if it's not perfect? It's magic.

title: The Fisher King
review: A modern epic that fuses myth with hard-edged reality, it's a one-of-a-kind, thoroughly engaging experience.

title: The Fisher King
review: The Fisher King is a disorganized, rambling and eccentric movie that contains some moments of truth, some moments of humor, and many moments of digression.

title: Frozen River

title: Frozen River

title: Frozen River
review: There are moments of poetry on display.

title: Frozen River
review: It moves and it heals, finding hints of redemption in the jagged face of life.

title: Frozen River
review: The miracle of filmmaker Courtney Hunt's tense, carefully understated debut is that it is made better by its few flights of fancy.

title: Frozen River

title: Frozen River
review: Made with uncommon skill and assurance, the film never succumbs to rank sentimentality, but it manages to get at the nuances of human relationships.

title: Frozen River

title: Frozen River
review: We quickly sense that the director of this film has unusual perception, and that whatever the story and performances turn out to be, she will make the most of them.

title: Frozen River
review: Frozen River does what too many independent American movies only pretend to do: Takes you to an unnoticed corner of our country and shows what it's like to actually live there.

title: Frozen River
review: An impressive first feature by writer/director Courtney Hunt, Frozen River boasts considerable suspense-movie tension and a compelling emotional journey for its foreground characters.

title: Frozen River
review: It's fair to say that Hunt's first full-length feature, though uneven at times, holds the promise of better things to come.

title: Frozen River
review: An urgent and incomparably moving first feature from Courtney Hunt.

title: Frozen River
review: Courtney Hunt's Frozen River is the first great film of the fall. It has great actors playing vivid characters in a setting that makes for a clash of cultures.

title: Frozen River
review: Frozen River is one of those rare independent films that knows precisely what it intends, and what the meaning of the story is.

title: Frozen River
review: What a beautiful and impressive job by first-time writer-director Courtney Hunt.

title: Frozen River
review: All in all, Frozen River is gripping stuff.

title: Frozen River
review: A Sundance hit that is both absorbing and bleak, Frozen River is anchored by powerful performances, believable scenarios and excellent writing.

title: Frozen River
review: This is a debut feature, though you'd never know it from the filmmaker's commandingly confident style, or from the heartbreaking beauty -- heartbreaking, then heartmending -- of Melissa Leo's performance.

title: North Country

title: End of Days

title: Flawless

title: Flawless
review: Flawless more than compensates for its rough edges.
